The External
Position
Exchange Rates
lated. Stage Two was expected to last until about October 1973, when Stage
Three would come into effect. During Stage Two the Government held
consultations with representatives of the trade unions and employers on the
policies for Stage Three.
The Government continued with its search for an agreed, voluntary method
of dealing with pay and prices problems.
Britain’s economy is being adapted to take account of Community membership
over a transitional period which will end in 1977. The main economic adjust¬
ments required include: the elimination of tariffs on industrial products traded
between Britain and the eight other member countries by means of five
successive 20 per cent reductions which started in April 1973, and the pro¬
gressive alignment by Britain to the common external tariff in trade with non¬
member countries which do not have special association or trading arrange¬
ments with the Community; the movement, from February 1973, towards the
Community’s common price levels for agricultural products as part of
Britain’s implementation of the common agricultural policy; a contribution to
the Community budget, limited to about 8-75 per cent of the budget in 1973,
but rising annually to about 19 per cent by 1977; participation in the European
Monetary Co-operation Fund established in 1973, and consultation on
exchange rate fluctuations and short-term economic policies; accession to the
European Investment Bank; and the implementation of measures to allow the
free movement of labour within the member countries of the Community.
In the years following devaluation in 1967 exports of goods and services
increased rapidly in real terms. Helped by a record surplus on current transac¬
tions of over £1,000 million in 1971, and by massive capital inflows, the
reserves stood at the high level of just over ,£2,740 million by the end of May
1972. This was after the repayment of all official short- and medium-term debt
which had amounted to ,£3,363 million at the end of 1968.
In 1972 the trade balance began to deteriorate; imports were swollen by the
rapid growth of domestic demand, and exports were affected by various factors
including the slower growth of world trade. This deterioration, together with
growing fears about inflation, led to a large outflow of short-term speculative
capital in June 1972, and the Government decided to allow the pound to float
as a temporary measure and applied exchange control to transactions with the
sterling area (see p. 238). The initial impact of the lower sterling exchange rate
was a further worsening in the trade balance, which was also affected by a
sharp rise in world commodity prices. Over the year there was a large adverse
balance on visible trade which was more than offset by net invisible earnings,
leading to a small surplus on current transactions (see p. 238).
In the first half of 1973 the value of imports rose faster than that of exports,
largely because of the continued fall in the sterling exchange rate and rise in
commodity prices. An increase in the adverse balance on visible trade, exceed¬
ing net invisible earnings, resulted in a deficit on current transactions. How¬
ever, exports were running at record levels and, in volume terms, were growing
faster than imports.
INTERNATIONAL MONETARY SITUATION
During the early part of 1971 continued uncertainty about rates of exchange
against the United States dollar and lack of confidence in the dollar, due
mainly to a growing payments deficit in the United States, affected foreign
202
Monetary
Reform
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
exchange markets. This uncertainty grew in the months up to August with
heavy selling of the dollar against most currencies, including sterling. On
15th August the United States announced measures to stimulate its economy
and protect the dollar. Following these measures most currencies including
sterling were in effect allowed to float against the dollar.
In December 1971 a general international realignment of exchange rates
was agreed in Washington, in which all the main currencies were in effect
revalued against the US dollar. As part of this, the sterling rate for the dollar
moved up by just over 8^ per cent, the new middle rate being $2-60571
compared with the old par value of $2-40. However, under the settlement
Britain did not change the par value of sterling in terms of gold notified to the
International Monetary Fund—the new middle rate was the direct result of
the US decision to raise the dollar value of monetary gold from $35 to $38 per
fine ounce.
The sudden heavy pressure to which sterling was subjected in June (see p.
201) reflected growing anxiety about the prospects for Britain’s balance of
payments. As a result, sterling was allowed as a temporary measure to
float.
In the early part of February 1973 foreign exchange markets experienced a
further crisis of confidence with the dollar being sold very heavily, particularly
in Europe. The Finance Ministers of the countries most involved agreed on
12 February, after urgent discussions, that the dollar would be devalued by
10 per cent against gold, that most major currencies would not follow (and
would therefore effectively revalue again) and that the yen would be allowed to
float. Sterling continued to float, but its formal gold par value was unchanged.
In spite of this further dollar devaluation, the dollar continued to weaken in
the foreign exchange markets in early March. During the month a further
settlement was announced which resulted in the deutschemark being revalued
by 3 per cent against gold; six Community countries (Belgium, Denmark, the
Federal Republic of Germany, France, Luxembourg and the Netherlands)
maintained their margins scheme (introduced in May 1972, under which
rates between any two of their currencies could not diverge from their cross
parities by more than 2} per cent), but no longer maintained margins for the
US dollar; Sweden and Norway joined the Community scheme; and Britain,
the Irish Republic and Italy continued to float independently.
The events of 1971-72 gave an additional stimulus to international discussions
which had already begun about a possible reform of the international monetary
system. A new international group, the ‘Committee of Twenty (representative
of the major industrial and the developing countries), was set up within the
IMF framework. .
One of the major problems being considered as part of reform is the future
role of the present reserve currencies (the US dollar and the pound sterling).
The official sterling balances began as liabilities incurred by Britain towards
overseas sterling area countries largely during the second world war. In 1968,
Britain negotiated the Sterling Agreements with the main holders of these
balances. The agreements provided for a guarantee in dollar terms at the then
sterling parity for the sterling holdings on condition that certain minimum
proportions of these countries’ reserves were kept in sterling. On the expiry
of the agreements in September 1973 the Government extended the guarantee
for six months (at the market rate of exchange then prevailing of $2-4213—£1)
for holdings which were broadly maintained at existing levels.

THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years.
In 1972 Britain’s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled over £53,900 million. In real terms, that
is, after allowing for price changes, the increase over the 10 years since 1962
was nearly 30 per cent.
About a third of total output can be attributed to manufacturing industry
and this proportion has remained more or less constant for a number of years.
The expanding industry groups in recent years have been transport and com¬
munications and financial, health and educational services. Agriculture,
forestry and fishing account for a small and slowly declining share, and mining
for a small and more rapidly declining share. The relative contribution of the
distributive trades is also declining. Table 8 summarises the contribution of
each industry group to the gross domestic product (at current prices).

The main trends since 1962 are a fall in the proportion of total available
resources devoted to personal consumption and to public authorities’ current
expenditure and a significant rise in the proportion devoted to exports.
Personal incomes before tax at current prices rose rapidly and fairly steadily
from under £24,100 million in 1962 to over £53>000 m l972 a
compound rate of about 8 per cent a year. The increase in consumer expen¬
diture at constant prices has, however, been very much lower—3 per cent a
year. The difference is accounted for mainly by rising prices and to a lesser
extent by a higher incidence of direct taxation and increased personal savings.
Income from employment in 1972 totalled £37,H0 million and accounted
for nearly 70 per cent of total personal income (compared with nearly 72 per
cent in 1962). The three other main sources of personal income were self-
employment (9 per cent), income from rent, dividends and interest (10 per
cent), and grants from public authorities (11 per cent). The general pattern
of income distribution is thus dominated by income from employment.
The effects of income from rent, dividends and interest, which tends to add to
the income of the already affluent, are relatively slight and to some extent
counterbalanced by the effect of grants from public authorities to those in need.
British direct taxation falls heavily on the rich and the combined effect of
taxation and transfer payments and benefits in kind is a redistribution of
income on more egalitarian lines. According to studies by the Central Statis¬
tical Office, the effect in 1971 was to raise the highest income among the poorest
fifth of households (that is, the income at the lowest quintile) from 29 to 53
per cent of the median income of all households. There are a number of
theoretical and practical limitations to these studies, but the broad result is
too marked to be in dispute.
The rise in the volume of consumers’ spending has been accompanied, in
Britain as in other advanced industrial countries, by changes in its pattern.
The proportions of expenditure devoted to food and tobacco have been falling
while the proportions spent on housing, and cars and their running costs,
have risen.

Current expenditure on goods and services by the central Government
and local authorities rose by nearly 25 per cent at 1970 market prices over the
period 1962 to 1972 when it amounted to about 18 per cent of the gross
national product. The main cause of this increase was the continuing growth
of the social services, especially education. Defence has recently accounted
for a declining share of public expenditure on goods and services—25 per cent
in 1972 compared with 37 per cent in 1962 and a post-war peak of 48 per cent
in 1953-
In addition to their expenditure on goods and services, public authorities
transfer large sums to other sectors, mainly the personal sector, by way of
national insurance and other social security benefits, grants, and interest and
206
Investment

subsidies (see pp. 133 and 187). The Government also makes grants to local
authorities to finance about 50 per cent of their current expenditure.
Gross domestic fixed capital formation represents about 21 per cent of the
gross domestic product at factor cost. The total value of fixed assets in Britain,
valued at constant replacement cost, is estimated to have increased by 47 per
cent between 1962 and 1972 when their current replacement value, net of
depreciation, was some £155,900 million, of which about two-thirds was
accounted for by buildings and one-third by plant and machinery, and vehicles.

Within the total of gross domestic fixed capital formation in 1972 (£9,380
million compared with £8,560 million in 1967 at constant prices) private
sector investment accounted for 12-3 per cent of the gross domestic product at
factor cost (io*8 per cent in 1967) and the public sector for 8-9 per cent
(10-5 per cent). The broad components of fixed investment in 1972 analysed
by type of asset as percentages of the gross domestic product were: plant and
machinery, vehicles, ships and aircraft, io-i per cent (10-2 per cent); dwellings
3-8 per cent (4-1 per cent); and other new buildings and works 6-6 per cent
(6-4 per cent). The diagram shows the industrial components of fixed invest¬
ment in the same two years. There is a marked cyclical pattern in the flow of
investment by manufacturing industry; it was at a low point in 1967 an<^
probably in 1972 according to the rising trend shown in the first half of 1973*
Among the trends over recent years have been increases in investment in
agriculture, mining (other than coal mining), shipping and retail distribution.
In the manufacturing sector, the largest investments in 1972 were in the chemical
and allied industries, the metal manufacturing industries, the engineering
industries and the food, drink and tobacco industries.
Saving has made a significant contribution to the rising levels of investment
in all the main sectors of the economy. The extent to which each sector contri¬
buted on balance, by way of lending, to the capital formation of the other
sectors (and to net investment abroad) in 1970-72 or drew on the saving of
the other sectors is shown by the sector’s net acquisition of financial assets
(see Table 11).
The main features of 1972 were the large financial deficit of the public
sector and the return into surplus of the company sector. Although only a
small part of the public sector’s deficit was financed by the sale of debt to the

personal sector, the remainder was nearly all financed by transactions with
overseas rather than with the banks, and thus did not add to the reserve assets

The public sector’s financial deficit (a negative net acquisition of financial
assets) increased substantially in 1972 to some £1,590 million, almost seven
times that in 1971. While the public sector’s capital formation at current prices
was some £150 million higher, the main cause was the reduced saving by
central government as a result of the rapid increase in current expenditure
overtaking a more modest growth in revenue. Both public corporations and
local authorities had increased surpluses on current account, although in the
case of local authorities this reflected increased central government grants
which contributed to the reduction in central government saving. The company
sector was in substantial financial surplus in 1972 (following three years of
deficit) as company saving rose sharply, whereas capital formation showed
only a small increase. The personal sector’s financial position was little changed,
a considerable increase in saving being offset by a similar increase in capital
formation (mainly associated with the purchase of dwellings). National Savings
reached the record level of £10,076 million at the end of 1972, net savings
during the year totalling some £472 million (see p. 220).

THE PUBLIC SECTOR
Public expenditure comprises the current and capital expenditures of central
Government and local authorities, together with the debt interest and capital
expenditure of the nationalised industries and other public corporations. In
1972 total expenditure for 1972-73 was estimated at £27,884 million, of which
67 per cent was by the central Government, 26 per cent by local authorities,
and 7 per cent on the capital expenditure of the public corporations.
The wide range of function and purpose of this expenditure and its distri¬
bution is shown in Table 12 at 1972-73 outturn prices.

twice the rate of the economy as a whole. The social services programmes now
take 41 per cent of the total, whereas in i960 they represented just over 35
per cent. On the other hand defence budget expenditure has declined from
17 per cent to 11 per cent.
Of the £27,884 million in 1972-73, £16,635 million represented direct
purchases of goods and services. Some 68 per cent of this expenditure was
for current purposes, for example, salaries and wages of the armed forces,
police, teachers, nurses and civil servants, and the running expenses of, for
example, schools, prisons, the health service, and the armed forces. Capital
expenditure, on the hospitals and schools as well as on services such as housing
and roads, accounts for the remaining 32 per cent. Apart from the direct
purchases of goods and services public expenditure includes substantial trans¬
fers of money to individuals, companies and other institutions in the private
sector. The largest item of transfers is retirement pensions (£2,363 million
in 1972-73) but substantial amounts are paid also for supplementary benefits,
sickness benefit, family allowances, unemployment benefits and for a range of
subsidies, the largest being the agricultural subsidies to farmers, and grants
and loans. In total, transfer payments amounted to £10,751 million in 1972-73,
39 per cent of all public expenditure. These transfer payments, unlike public
authorities’ direct purchases of goods and services, do not represent a direct
demand on the nation’s product, but form part of the expenditure incurred by
the recipients; this transferred expenditure is smaller than the amount of the
gross sums transferred, because of the tax incurred on the payments and of
any savings that take place. Thus the public sector’s total payments are
equivalent to half the gross national product, while its expenditure on goods
and services accounts for about one-third of the nation’s output.
Up to i960 discussion of public expenditure centred on the expenditure of the
central Government departments, including grants to local authorities, set
out in the annual Supply Estimates which were presented to and approved by
Parliament for one year ahead. These Estimates did not (and do not) cover
certain major areas of public expenditure, such as the nationalised industries’
capital expenditure, the bulk of the payments from the national insurance fund,
and local authorities’ expenditure financed from the local rates on property.
Following the recommendations of the Plowden Committee on the Control of
Public Expenditure in 1961, surveys were instituted of the whole range of
public expenditure, for the period five years ahead. The surveys take place
each year, rolling forward the period to be covered. They are carried out by
officials in the spending departments and the Treasury, under the direction
of the Public Expenditure Survey Committee.
The primary purpose of the survey is to present to ministers an up-to-date
assessment of the cost of their existing policies as a basis for decisions about
the total and the composition of public expenditure over the whole area over
which the Government has control or influence. The five-year period covered
by the surveys gives the Government the opportunity to plan ahead significant
changes without causing wasteful disruption in existing services.
The initial recosting normally takes place in the first half of the year, to be
followed by ministerial consideration of the survey report. Since 1969 the
public expenditure plans as settled by the Government have been published
towards the end of the year, forming the basis of an annual public expenditure
debate in the House of Commons.1
1 Comparison of these plans with the Supply Estimates will be facilitated by changes to
be made in the form of the Estimates from 1974-75-

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In 1971 the Expenditure Committee of the House was created, replacing
the Estimates Committee, to consider public expenditure, and its reports
provide further information on which the debates can draw. The Expendi¬
ture Committee has formed sub-committees, one to consider general Govern¬
ment financial control and the presentation of information about public
expenditure, and others considering public expenditure in particular areas:
defence and external relations; education and the arts; employment and social
services; trade and industry, and environment; and the Home Office. These
committees can question departmental ministers as well as their officials, and
can take evidence also from witnesses outside Government.
Each department submits its estimates to the Treasury in the December before
the financial year beginning on the following 1st April.
After they have been approved by the Treasury, the Estimates are pre¬
sented to Parliament shortly before the presentation of the Budget (see p. 211)
and are approved by Parliament, by means of an annual Appropriation Act, in
July (expenditure to this date from 1st April is covered by a Vote on Account
approved by Parliament before the beginning of the financial year). There are
29 allotted days (known as supply days) in each session on which the choice
of subject for debate rests with the Opposition. Although Estimates can be
debated on these days, normally broad issues of policy are discussed.
Certain expenditures are not approved annually, but are covered by Acts
of Parliament allowing payments to continue from one year to another and are
paid direct from the Consolidated Fund. These include the financial provision
for members of the royal family, and salaries and pensions of judges. Further,
Government lending and service of debt are carried out on a continuing basis
by Act of Parliament through the National Loans Fund. Britain’s financial
obligations to the European Community are met either from the Consolidated
Fund or the National Loans Fund.
The Treasury’s authority is required for any new item of expenditure, for any
increase in expenditure beyond that originally authorised, for any change in
policy which means an increase in expenditure, and for extra-statutory pay¬
ments. This requirement is, however, subject to any delegated authority
which may be given to departments to deal with particular types of expendi¬
ture. Treasury control does not imply final sanction by the Treasury—in the
last resort the decision is taken by the Government as a whole, and carried
out subject to Parliamentary consent.
Control over issues of money to departments and the audit of accounts is
exercised by the Comptroller and Auditor General, a permanent officer of
the Crown. Since 1866 he has had two functions: as Comptroller he controls
receipts and issues of public money to and from the Consolidated Fund and
the National Loans Fund, and as Auditor General he audits departmental
accounts and submits his report on the Appropriation Accounts and other
accounts, as required by statute, to Parliament. His statutory function is to
ensure that all expenditure is properly incurred, for example, that no payments
are made which go beyond any relevant statutory authority, and that Treasury
sanction has been obtained wherever necessary. In addition, however, he has
been encouraged by successive Public Accounts Committees to examine
departmental expenditure for cost-effectiveness with a view to drawing their
attention to any cases of apparent waste or extravagance.

THE BUDGET
The accounts of each department and the reports on the accounts made by
the Comptroller and Auditor General are considered by a House of Commons
select committee called the Public Accounts Committee. This was first set up
in 1861 for the purpose of ensuring that expenditure was properly incurred in
accordance with the purpose for which it was voted and with any relevant Acts
of Parliament. The terms of reference of the committee are simply to examine
the accounts and these terms have been widely interpreted by successive com¬
mittees which have investigated whether full value has been obtained for the
sums spent by departments and have examined cases in which the administra¬
tion appears to have been faulty or negligent. The committee has therefore
become a powerful instrument for the exposure of waste and inefficiency. It
embodies the findings in reports which may be debated in the House of
Commons. Its recommendations are considered by the Treasury in consulta¬
tion with departments and put into effect, so far as they are accepted, according
to Treasury instructions. A reply to each report is submitted to Parliament by
Treasury Minute and both documents are debated at the beginning of the
following session.
The Budget (an old word which meant a bag containing papers or accounts)
is a set of proposals, made annually, in either March or April, for financing
Government expenditure. They are described by the Chancellor of the Exche¬
quer in the Budget speech, against the background of a statement of the
Government’s past and prospective revenue and expenditure, and the Chan¬
cellor’s assessment of the position and prospects of the economy as a whole.
The Budget speech is followed by the moving of a set of Ways and Means
resolutions, in which the proposals are embodied. These resolutions, when
passed by the House, become the foundation of the Finance Act, which
expresses the proposals in statutory form.
The Budget is principally an instrument of economic management, and the
annual Budget speech is normally the main occasion for a review of general
economic policy. The scale of Government expenditure and taxation has an
important influence on the general level of output and distribution of resources.
The Budget judgment is therefore concerned with the balance between the
total of goods and services which are likely to be available to the nation and
the total claims which are likely to be made on them. Taxation provides the
Government with a means of exerting a considerable influence on the pressure
of demand. Taxation measures can also have a broader influence on the
pattern of demand and the long-term performance of the economy.
The Budget deals with the means of financing expenditure and particularly
with changes in taxation and not primarily with expenditure itself. On occa¬
sions, changes affecting expenditure, such as increases in pensions and family
allowances, have been announced in the Budget speech as have financial and
monetary measures not related to the Finance Act, such as changes in exchange
control policies. Such measures, however, are not reflected in the resolutions
or the Finance Act but are applied by whatever procedure is appropriate to
implement them—separate legislation, statutory instruments or administra¬
tive action.
The scope of the Budget and that of the Finance Act which follows it are
different although they are closely interrelated. The Budget is essentially
concerned with the measures that give effect to the Chancellor’s decision to
increase or reduce to an appropriate extent the predicted level of demand on
economic resources by use of the instruments at the Chancellor’s disposal, and
especially by increasing or reducing the yield of central Government taxes.
212
Public Sector
Accounts
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL FIANDBOOK
The tax changes made necessary by the Budget judgment are enacted in the
Finance Act. But the Finance Act also provides the annual opportunity for
non-Budgetary changes in the tax system and for certain other financial
matters, such as provisions relating to Government borrowing.
The bulk of the taxation proposals in the Budget are concerned with changes
in the rates or coverage of existing taxes, the introduction of new taxes or the
abolition of existing ones, and changes in the administrative machinery relating
to taxation. In two cases however—income tax and corporation tax—annual
Ways and Means resolutions followed by a Finance Act clause are necessary
to maintain the taxes in existence at all, since they are annual taxes. It is this
which makes an annual Budget at or about the beginning of each financial year
a necessity.
New taxes and changes in certain existing taxes, like other changes in statute
laws, do not come into effect until the Finance Act has received Royal Assent
(in the case of the annual Budget, normally at the end of July) or at some other
date laid down in the Bill. Some changes, however, come into effect earlier,
usually from Budget Day or from the start of the tax year, under the Provi¬
sional Collection of Taxes Act. This enables the Government to collect certain
taxes provisionally, income tax for example, either at the rates previously in
operation or at new rates following the passing of the appropriate Ways and
Means resolutions. Tax proposals are not limited to the annual Budget and
may be made at other times in the year to meet changes in economic circum¬
stances.
The economic background to the Budget and the transactions of the central
Government and the public sector as a whole are presented in the Financial
Statement and Budget Report (see Bibliography, p. 476) which is laid before the
House of Commons by the Chancellor of the Exchequer when opening the
Budget. The report is in three parts: the economic context of the Budget;
the accounts of the public sector; and the accounts of the central Government
for the past financial year and the one immediately ahead. The accounts are
designed to assist in assessing the impact of changes in revenue and, where
relevant, public expenditure on the economy.
The accounts of the public sector show the transactions of the central
Government, local authorities, nationalised industries and other public corpora¬
tions combined into a consolidated account covering the whole of the public
sector. The transactions within the public sector cancel out on consolidation
and the net balance on the consolidated account represents therefore the
borrowing required by the public sector from the private and overseas sectors.
The accounts of the central Government show transactions both on the
conventional cash basis of exchequer accounting and in accordance with the
framework of the national income accounts.
Central Government borrowing may be in the form of borrowing from the
public either through the National Savings Movement (see p. 221) or by
borrowing on the market by means of new issues of securities. New issues of
government securities are made from time to time for the purpose of refinanc¬
ing maturing issues (conversion loans) or to raise new money (issues for cash).
The capital requirements of the nationalised industries are met by the central
Government while those of the local authorities are met partly by the central
Government through the Public Works Loan Board (see p. 75) an<^ partly
by borrowing direct from the public, although some nationalised industries
and local authorities have obtained statutory power enabling them to borrow,
with Treasury consent, in foreign currencies.

SOURCES OF
REVENUE 1973-74
Income Tax
After allowing for the Budget changes in 1973 the central Government’s
borrowing requirement for 1973-74 is expected to be £3,996 million, com¬
pared with £2,118 million in 1972-73, and that for the public sector as a whole
£4,423 million compared with £2,855 million in 1972-73.
Table 13 shows total revenue from taxation and other sources in 1972-73
and 1973-74 together with the effects of the Budget changes.
Far-reaching changes in the structure of personal and company taxation and
in taxes on expenditure were introduced in the 1973 Budget. A single gra¬
duated personal tax replaced the old system of income tax and surtax. Company
taxation was reformed on an imputation basis so as to remove the discrimina¬
tion against distributed profits. A 10 per cent value added tax (VAT) became
operative, replacing selective employment tax and purchase tax which were
abolished.
The over-riding aim of the 1973 Budget was to sustain a higher rate of
economic growth in Britain. A key part of that strategy is the control of
inflation.
Full details of Budget proposals are published each year in the Financial
Statement and Budget Report.
The three principal sources of tax revenue are first, taxes on income, which
include income tax and corporation tax; second, taxes on capital, which in¬
clude estate duty and capital gains tax; and third, taxes on expenditure
(including taxes on the ownership or use of certain assets)—these include
protection and revenue duties, VAT, local rates, stamp duties and licence
duties (for example, on motor vehicles). Taxes on individual (but not cor¬
porate) incomes are progressive taxes in that larger incomes and estates bear a
proportionately higher rate of tax. The Board of Inland Revenue collects the
taxes on income and capital and the stamp duties; the Board of Customs and
Excise collects the most important taxes on expenditure, the customs and
excise taxes and VAT while a variety of authorities is responsible for the
collection of the remainder.
Income tax is imposed for the year of assessment beginning on 6th April. Under
the unified system of direct personal taxation, which became effective in April
1973, the basic rate of 30 per cent applies to the first £5,000 of taxable income
(that is, total income less deductions and personal allowances). A rate of 40 per
cent is charged on the £5,ooo-£6,ooo band of taxable income, and the rate for
successive bands rises in steps of 5 per cent until a maximum rate of 75 per
cent is reached at a level of £20,000. These rates are charged on both earned
and investment incomes; larger investment incomes are also liable to a sur¬
charge of 15 per cent of the amount by which they exceed £2,000. The tax
imposed on an individual is graduated by means of personal allowances and
reliefs. Married couples receive higher allowances than a single person. Hus¬
band and wife may choose to have the wife’s earnings charged separately for
tax on condition that the former receives the single personal allowance instead
of the married allowance.
A single person earning £2,000 a year pays £421-50 in income tax, while a
married man with the same earned income pays £367-50; if he has two children
under the age of 11 and his earnings plus the family allowance total £2,000,
his tax falls to £265-50; when the children are between the ages of n and 16,
the tax is £244-50; if the children are over 16 and receiving full-time educa¬
tion, £226-50. The range of tax (including the higher rates under the unified

The Government is to introduce a tax credit system to replace the present
system of income tax personal allowances and family allowances (see p. i30)-
FINANCE
215
Taxpayers would be entitled to credits related to family responsibilities. If
credit exceeded tax, the difference would be paid to the taxpayer; if tax exceeded
credit, the difference would stand as a tax deduction. Through the introduction
of an automatic form of family support the system would reduce substantially
the numbers of people relying on means-tested benefits.
Most wage and salary earners pay their income tax under a PAYE (‘Pay as
You Earn’) system whereby tax is deducted (and accounted for to the Inland
Revenue) by the employer, thus enabling them to keep as up to date as possible
with their tax payments.
In general, income tax is charged on all income which originates in the
United Kingdom and on all income arising abroad of persons resident in the
United Kingdom. The main exceptions are that interest on certain United
Kingdom government securities belonging to persons not ordinarily resident
in the United Kingdom is exempt; and income from certain classes of posses¬
sions abroad is chargeable not on the amount of income arising but on the
amount of income remitted to the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom has
entered into agreements with many countries providing for relief from double
taxation; where such agreements are not in force unilateral relief is allowed.
Company
Taxation
Estate Duty
Capital Gains
Tax
Since April 1973, companies pay corporation tax at a single rate on all their
profits, whether distributed or not. However, a proportion only of any capital
gains is included in total profits, with the result that chargeable gains as a
whole are subject to a lower effective rate of tax. Income tax is no longer
deducted from dividends but a company which distributes profits to its
shareholders is required to make to the Inland Revenue an advance payment
of corporation tax. In general, this advance payment is set against a company’s
corporation tax bill and the recipient of the distribution in respect of which
the advance payment was made is entitled to a tax credit. The rate of corpora¬
tion tax is fixed retrospectively in the Budget for the past financial year; for
1972 it is 40 per cent. The tax is assessed on the profits of accounting periods,
the rate of tax being the rate for the financial year in which the accounting
period falls. The basic rule for the calculations of income and capital gains for
corporation tax purposes is that, except for special provisions, these are
computed in accordance with principles of the income and capital gains taxes.
Estate duty is chargeable on the value of all property which passes at death.
The charge to duty is not limited to property owned by the deceased but may
extend to other property, for example, to trust funds from which the deceased
received income in his lifetime and to gifts made by the deceased within seven
years of his death (one year in the case of a gift for public or charitable pur¬
poses). Since the 1972 Budget estates not over £15,000 are exempt from duty.
On estates of a higher value duty is chargeable by reference to rates ranging
from 25 per cent to 75 per cent, applied to successive slices of the estate. In
addition, property going to a surviving spouse up to a sum of £15,000 is left out
of account for estate duty purposes, so that where a man leaves his whole
estate to his widow no duty is payable at all unless the estate exceeds £30,000.
Capital gains accruing on the disposal of assets are liable to capital gains tax
or, in the case of companies, to corporation tax. The rate of tax for persons
other than companies is 30 per cent, but in the case of individuals may be less,
depending on their circumstances. Certain assets are exempt from tax includ¬
ing the principal private residence, chattels worth less than £1,000 (and any
chattels, except those used for the purpose of a trade, with a predictable life of
Taxes on
Expenditure
Value Added Tax
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
less than 50 years), private motor cars, and National Savings Certificates. The
1971 Finance Act also exempted an individual from capital gains tax where the
total proceeds of disposals do not exceed £500 in any year. All gains are now
subject to long-term capital gains tax whatever the length of period of owner¬
ship except for gains on gilt-edged securities which continue to be exempt from
capital gains tax if held for more than 12 months.
The largest group of taxes on expenditure are those administered by the
Customs and Excise Department, namely VAT and the duties on tobacco,
hydrocarbon oil, alcoholic drinks, protective duties, betting and certain mis¬
cellaneous items. In British usage the distinction between customs and
excise depends on whether the goods are imported (customs duties) or pro¬
duced in Britain (excise duties). These taxes are usually referred to as indirect
taxes since they are normally paid by the importer, manufacturer, or whole¬
saler, who adjusts the prices charged to customers accordingly. The Treaty of
Accession to the European Community provides that the revenue duties
should be converted to internal taxes chargeable alike on imported and home-
produced goods. With the introduction of VAT from 1st April 1973 all the
revenue duty goods (other than hydrocarbon oil, which is zero rated under
VAT) became subject to the standard rate of VAT. Simultaneously the rates
of all the revenue duties (other than the duty on hydrocarbon oil) were reduced.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has power to vary by up to 20 per cent
the rate of VAT, and by 10 per cent any of the other main groups of customs
and excise duties (that is, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, oil and the minor revenue
duties). This power, known as the ‘regulator’, requires annual renewal.
Value added tax (VAT) is collected at each stage in the production and distri¬
bution process (unlike purchase tax which was collected at a single stage).
The final tax is borne by the consumer. A taxable person (generally, a trader
carrying on a business with a turnover of more than £5,000 a year) is charged
by suppliers of goods and services with VAT (‘input’ tax). The trader then
charges the customer with VAT on goods and services supplied ( output
tax) The trader pays to Customs and Excise the difference between output
and input tax. Although VAT falls on imported goods, most exports are zero
rated and, unlike purchase tax, VAT entering directly into export costs can be
VAT, which is chargeable at the standard rate of 10 per cent, is a broadly
based tax falling on final consumers’ expenditure except where there are
strong social or economic reasons for giving relief. There are two basic
methods by which supplies of goods and services may get relief from VA .
zero rating, when a trader does not have to charge tax to a customer but can
reclaim any input tax paid to suppliers, and exemption, when a trader does not
have to charge a customer any output tax but is not entitled to ^duct or
reclaim any input tax included in the price of these goods or services. The most
important supplies to which zero rating applies are food (except in the course
of catering); books, newspapers and periodicals, coal, gas and electricity,
petrol and oil; construction of buildings; exports (goods and most services);
public transport fares; young children’s clothing and footwear; and drugs and
medicines supplied on prescription. Exemption applies to land (including
rents); insurance; postal services; betting, gaming and lotteries; finance,
education; health; and burial and cremation.
New cars, whether British made or imported, are chargeable with car tax at
10 per cent on the wholesale value. VAT falls on the price including car tax.

The principal betting duties are: the pool betting duty (which applies to
football pools and betting by coupon at fixed odds) charged at a rate of 33^ per
cent of the stake money; and the general betting duty, which is charged at the
rate of 6 per cent of stake money except for on-course betting which is charged
at 4 per cent. Gaming is taxed at different rates mainly by licence fees.
Taxes on motor vehicles are collected for the Department of the Environment
by local offices; the proceeds are paid into the Consolidated Fund. The
licence duty on a private motor car is ^25 a year; motor cycles and three-wheel
vehicles, etc., pay £2*50, £5 or ^10 a year according to engine capacity. Goods
vehicles are taxed by unladen weight, and taxis and buses by seating capacity.
The National Debt increased rapidly during and immediately after the first and
second world wars. It rose from £650 million in 1914 to £7,435 million at the
end of the first world war, and from £7,131 million in 1939 to £23,647 million
in 1946. On 31st March 1973 the total National Debt (provisional) was £36,910
million, of which £1,651 million was repayable in currencies other than
sterling, mainly to the United States and Canadian Governments. Of the
£35>259 million of internal debt, £3,727 million was short-term debt, mainly
in the form of 91-day Treasury bills, while the long-term loans included a
variety of stocks, bonds, loans and certificates carrying fixed rates of interest
(ranging from 2^ to 9^ per cent) and with fixed or indeterminate dates of re¬
payment.
The general system of public finance in Northern Ireland is, in its main
features, similar to that operating in the United Kingdom as a whole. The
major sources of revenue are the main national taxes imposed by the United
Kingdom Parliament over the whole country. Revenue also accrues from
locally levied taxes such as rates and some licence fees. Because of the transi¬
tional nature of the situation, the arrangements proposed for the future
administration of finance in Northern Ireland are outlined in the supple¬
ment.
Various funds have been established in Northern Ireland, in addition to
statutory Reserve and Sinking Funds, for specific purposes. In general, these
funds follow the United Kingdom pattern, the principal funds being those
relating to national insurance and government loans. The latter constitutes a
pool of capital money available mainly for local and public authority borrow¬
ings; on 31st March 1973 a sum of approximately £354 million was outstand¬
ing against such borrowers.
THE CENTRAL BANK
The British banking system is long established and well integrated. It com¬
prises a central bank; deposit banks which carry on the usual main banking
services; the United Kingdom offices of banks whose main business is in other
countries; merchant banks and other specialised institutions.
The Bank of England was established in 1694 by Act of Parliament and
Royal Charter as a corporate body; the entire capital stock was acquired by
the Government under the Bank of England Act 1946. As the central bank,
the Bank acts as banker to the Government, to overseas central banks and to
commercial banks; it is the note-issuing authority and the registrar for some
200 government, nationalised industry, local authority, public board and
Commonwealth government stocks. As agent for the Government the Bank
2l8
BRITAIN 1974* AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
administers exchange control. On behalf of the Treasury it manages the
Exchange Equalisation Account (EEA), which holds Britain s offic.a reserves
of gold and foreign exchange; using the resources of the EEA the Bank designs
its*1 interventions in the foreign exchange market both to prevent undue
fluctuations in the exchange value of sterling and to conserve the means ot
making payments abroad. . . .
As banker to the Government the Bank examines and seeks to anticipate
banking and financial problems and to undertake the appropriate operations
in the money, capital and the foreign exchange markets; consequently the Ban
has a major responsibility for advising the Government on the formulation of
monetary policy and for its subsequent execution. .
In implementing monetary policy the Bank is ready to act daily m the money
market, by buying or selling Treasury and other bills, and similar y in th
market for government stocks. A prime concern is to maintain orderly con 1-
tions and, when necessary, the Bank also exerts influence on interest rates
through market operations; an important indication of its intentions is t
minimum lending rate (known as ‘Bank rate’ until 1972), which ^ the minimum
rate at which the Bank will normally lend to the members of the London
Discount Market and is normally £ per cent above the average rate of discount
for Treasury bills. The Bank can also influence market and money supply
conditions through its power to call for special deposits. , .
The Bank is the recognised channel of communication between the deposit
banks and other financial institutions of the City of London on the one han ,
and the Government on the other. , _T7. . c .
The Bank of England has the sole right in England and \\ ales of issuing
bank notes. The note issue is fiduciary, that is to say, it is no longer backed y
gold but by government and other securities. The Scottish clearing and
Northern Ireland banks have limited rights to issue notes; these issues, apar
from an amount specified by legislation for each bank, must be fully covered
by Bank of England notes. The provision of com for circulation is the respo
sibilitv of the Royal Mint, a government department.
Following discussions by the Bank of England with the banks, the hire pur¬
chase finance houses and the discount houses, new arrangements for e
control of credit came into effect from September 1971. While it is still neces¬
sary for the Government, as an indispensable part of economic management to
regulate the development of credit and the money supply, the new system has
replaced rigid quantitative controls over lending in sterling with policies f
influencing^bank and finance house lending which combine effective control
with greater flexibility and freedom for these institutions. The techniques now
in operation involve more reliance upon changes in interest rates, in Particu
through calls by the Bank for special deposits from other banks superimposed
on a minimum reserve assets ratio of 12$ per cent of eligible liabilities.* Calls
for special deposits also restrict the growth of money supply by reducing
banks’ lending base. The ceiling controls on lending by the banks and finance
houses have been removed and the London and Scottish clearing banks have
abandoned their collective agreements on interest rates. Moreover they now
set their base rates for lending independently of the minimum lending rate
which closely reflects short term market rates. Greater scope for composit
Ind innovation by these institutions has thereby been introduced into the
domestic economy.

THE PRIVATE SECTOR
The primary business of the deposit banks is the receipt, transfer and encash¬
ment of deposits. The principal deposit banks are the six London clearing
banks, three Scottish clearing banks and two Northern Ireland banks. Mergers
have resulted in the formation of six banking groups, four based in London
and two in Scotland. The two Northern Ireland banks are owned by London
clearing banks, but two groups of banks based in the Irish Republic also
operate in Northern Ireland.
At the end of 1972 current and deposit accounts with deposit banks operat¬
ing in Britain totalled some ^18,170 million, and accounted for nearly 36 per
cent of the total deposits (in sterling and foreign currencies) of the banking
sector, which also includes the National Giro, the accepting houses, overseas
banks, other banks and the discount market. The deposit banks provide full
banking services throughout Britain, and operate through over 14,000 branches.
Several of them have interests in British overseas and Commonwealth banks,
and in other banks which have been formed specially to compete in inter¬
national markets. They have also acquired substantial interests in hire-
purchase finance houses, and some have set up their own unit trusts.
Together with the Bank of England the London clearing banks make up the
membership of the London Bankers’ Clearing House. In 1972 cheques, drafts,
bills and bankers’ effects passing through the interbank debit clearing system
averaged in value nearly ^89,320 million monthly, while the average monthly
value of the credit transfer clearing wras over ^1,690 million.
Current account balances with the deposit banks are repayable on demand
and no interest is paid on them, but on deposit account balances interest is
paid at a rate generally 1 -75 per cent below individual banks’ base rates. The
deposit banks’ more liquid assets consist of: cash, balances at the Bank of
England, money at call (mainly loans to discount houses), and their holdings
of Treasury and commercial bills. The banks also hold a proportion of their
assets as portfolio (mainly British Government securities) or trade investments.
The banks’ profits are largely earned through their advances to customers
partly in the form of overdrafts and partly in the form of loans (with or with¬
out collateral security). The ratio of London clearing bank advances to total
deposits in 1972 averaged 66 per cent.
The bank giro, originally introduced as the credit transfer scheme, and the
direct debiting system, by which a creditor with the prior approval of the
debtor may claim money due to him direct from the latter’s banking account,
have helped to improve the money transmission services. Another banking
innovation has been the introduction by some banks of automatic cash
dispensing machines. Credit cards are in widespread use for the settlement of
accounts in retail shops; and cheque cards enable the card holder to cash a
cheque up to £30 at any office of the major British and Irish banks, and at
offices of many banks in overseas countries.
The Post Office National Giro, which was introduced in 1968 to provide a
low-cost current account banking and money transfer service, is operated
through most post offices in Britain. All accounts and transactions are main¬
tained by means of a computer complex at the National Giro Centre near
Liverpool. Giro now has more than 450,000 accounts with deposits in excess
of £65 million. The number of weekly transactions had risen from 500,000 in
September 1969 to 1*3 million by September 1972 and the weekly turnover is
nearly £148 million. In addition to its services to individuals its services to

commerce, industry and the public utilities include a facility whereby organisa¬
tions with dispersed branches, depots and representatives can rapidly channel
receipts into their central accounting system. Many local authorities use Giro s
rent collection services. Giro’s international services also provide money
transfer facilities in Europe linking over 16 million account holders in the
European Community and other countries in Western Europe.
There are also some 40 British overseas and Commonwealth banks, many of
which have their headquarters in London. They provide a comprehensive
banking service in many parts of the world and engage in the financing ot
trade not only between Britain and other countries but also between third
countries. There are also in London about 50 United States banks, 60 Euro¬
pean banks, 19 Japanese banks, 73 other foreign banks and 35 consortium
banks.
The merchant banks have an influence on Britain’s financial affairs which is
much greater than their size in relation to other financial institutions mig t
suggest. Traditionally merchant banks have been primarily concerned wit
acceptance credits1 and with the sponsoring of capital issues on behalf of their
customers. Today they have a widely diversified and complex range of activi¬
ties with an important role in: international finance and the short-term capita
markets; the provision of expert advice and financial services to Bntis
industrial companies especially where mergers, takeovers and other forms ot
corporate reorganisation are involved; and the management of investment
holdings, including trusts, pensions and other funds.
The Money or Discount Market is an institution which is unique to the City of
London. Its function in the monetary system is to provide a financial mecha¬
nism designed to promote an orderly flow of short-term funds. The market
consists of 12 discount houses which borrow money ‘at call’ or short notice and
lend for somewhat longer periods. They have recourse to the Bank of England
as lender of last resort and normally the Bank lends to the houses at minimum
lending rate for seven days, although it may charge a higher rate and has also
at times lent overnight, or for short periods, at the rates of interest prevailing
in the market. Most of the market’s borrowed funds come from the banks,
which are thus provided with a flexible means of earning a yield on surplus funds
which they have at any given time. . rrT1 ,  
The assets of the discount houses mainly consist of Treasury and comm
cial bills, government and local authority securities and negotiable certificates
of deposit denominated in both sterling and US dollars. The market accepts as
an informal responsibility that it should cover the Governments need to
borrow on Treasury bills which are offered on tender each week.
The National Savings Movement started in 1916 to help finance the war by
promoting savings. The present movement encourages the widespread invest¬
ment of savings in Trustee Savings Banks and the National Savings Bank
(see p. 222) and in National Savings securities. The movement is led by the
National Savings Committee for England and Wales and similar committees

for Scotland and Northern Ireland. The committees are comprised of repre¬

have a staff of civil servants. Voluntary local savings committees, often sup¬

The administration of the National Savings Bank and other forms of national
savings is carried out by the Department for National Savings. Five forms
of National Savings securities are currently on sale: National Savings Certifi¬
cates, British Savings Bonds, Premium Savings Bonds, National Savings
Stamps and Gift Tokens. National Savings Certificates, in units of £1, are
encashable at par at any time; interest, which is free of income tax and capital
gains tax is paid only on encashment; the limit on individual holdings is 1,500
units of the current ‘decimal issue’ introduced in 1970. British Savings Bonds,
8-5 per cent, sold in units of £5, are repayable at par on one month’s notice.
If the bonds are held to maturity (five years from the date of purchase) they
are repaid with a bonus of £3 per cent tax free. Maximum holding is £10,000.
Premium Savings Bonds are in units of £1 (minimum purchase is £2) and indi¬
vidual holdings are limited to £2,000. After a qualifying period of three
months the bonds give investors a chance to win tax-free prizes instead of
receiving interest. There is now a weekly draw for a prize of £25,000, and 25
prizes of £1,000 and a monthly draw for prizes ranging from £25 to £50,000.
At the end of April 1973, £990 million was invested in this form of savings. A
selection of British Government securities is held on the National Savings
Stock Register. Trustee Savings Banks also deal in stock on the National
Savings Stock Register.
A contractual savings scheme, known as ‘Save as You Earn’ (SAYE), enables
savings to be made in regular monthly amounts within a minimum of £1 and a
maximum of £20 in deposits with the Department for National Savings or
Trustee Savings Banks by means of deductions from pay or by other regular

payments. At the end of five years, savings will qualify for a bonus equivalent
to one year’s savings free of tax. Completed savings which are not withdrawn
will qualify for a double bonus at the end of seven years, that is, two years
savings. For example, contributions totalling £60 payable over five years at a
rate of /i per month will qualify for a bonus of £12 at the end of that period,
or /24 if left on deposit for a further two years. Savers who wish to stop pay¬

withdrawals). Tax-free compound interest will be paid at the rate of 22
cent per annum on amounts withdrawn after the first but before the end of the
fifth year or at per cent where the contributions cease but the savings are
left invested for the remainder of the five years or where the saver dies before
the contributions are completed.
The National Savings Bank provides a countrywide system for depositing and
withdrawing small savings and has over 22 million active accounts. Ordinary
Accounts bear interest at 4 per cent and the first £40 of interest is tax free (a
new tax exemption limit introduced for the 1974-75 Year of assessment). Lp
to /20 can be withdrawn on demand at any savings bank post office, but a ew
days’ notice is required for larger amounts. The money is lodged with the
National Debt Commissioners and is invested in government securities.
Deposits up to a limit of £10,000 bearing a higher rate of interest (at present 8
per cent) may be made in Investment Accounts where investors have a quah-
fving deposit of £50 in an Ordinary Account. All deposits carry a government
guarantee; at the end of April 1973 the sum of the two accounts totalled
£2,065 million.
The Trustee Savings Banks, most of which were founded in the nineteenth
century, operate under their own trustees but are subject to statutory provi¬
sions and National Debt Office surveillance. There are 73 individual banks with
over 1 540 offices and 13 million active accounts. Deposits can be made either
in the Ordinary Department, the Special Investment Department or the
Current Account Department. Savings in the Ordinary Department earn
interest at 4 per cent and the first £40 of interest is tax free. Withdrawals can
usually be made on demand though notice is required for large sums. Deposits
are invested with the National Debt Commissioners and both capital and
interest are guaranteed by the Government. The Special Investment Depart¬
ments offer a higher rate of return, which is taxable. Deposits are limited t(j
£10 000, but are not government guaranteed. At the end of May 1973 total
sums in the Ordinary Departments of the Trustee Savings Banks were £1,280
million and in the Special Investment Departments £1,890 million. Most
Trustee Savings Banks operate cheque services on deposits in the Current
A Atffie end of July 1973 National Savings totalled £10,469 million. The dia¬
gram on p. 221 shows the distribution of National Savings between the di er-
ent outlets in 1958 and 1972.

has been the policy of the commercial banks to leave the provision of many
ecial financial facilities to other financial institutions. These facilities, whic
e supplementary to the credit facilities of the banking system, are mainly
ovided through the savings banks, finance corporations, hire-purchase
lance companies, the stock exchange, investment trust companies, unit trusts,
hiding societies and the insurance market. The firms engaged in such activi-
*s are in the main highly specialised, for example, discount and other finance
mses, stockbrokers, insurers, insurance underwriters and brokers.

Two corporations, the Finance Corporation for Industry Limited (FCI) and
the Industrial and Commercial Finance Corporation Limited (ICFC), were
set up in 1945 to assist in dealing with the problems of post-war reconstruction
and development. The corporations are ordinary limited companies with no
official representation on their boards and no recourse to public funds.
Another corporation, the Commonwealth Development Finance Company
Limited (CDFC), was established in 1953 to assist development projects in
the Commonwealth.
The FCI was formed to assist in the provision of capital (in amounts of
£200,000 and upwards) for the re-equipment and development of industry.
It has an authorised and issued capital of ^25 million and may borrow up
to four times this amount, making a possible total of resources of £125 million.
The share capital is held by insurance companies, by investment trust com¬
panies and by the Bank of England. At 31st March 1973 the capital called and
paid up was 10 per cent (£2-5 million); the Bank of England paid £5 million in
advance of call in 1958. The liability of the shareholders in respect of the un¬
called capital represents security to the banks providing loans for the corpora¬
tion’s working capital. The value of its loans and investments at 31st March
I973 was £62 million.
The main function of the ICFC is to provide capital, financial advice, and
computer bureau and other services to small- and medium-sized companies in
the British Isles. It has a number of subsidiaries, including Technical Develop¬
ment Capital Ltd. established in 1962 to provide venture capital for the com¬
mercial development of technological innovation. The shareholders of ICFC
are the Bank of England, the English Clearing and the Scottish banks. At 31st
March 1973 the ICFC had more than £185 million invested in 2,250 British
companies.
The Commonwealth Development Finance Company is no longer confined to
the Commonwealth in its activities. It supports business enterprise overseas
by providing finance in the form of share capital and loans on mutually
acceptable terms. Its authorised share capital is £30 million, of which about
14^ million ‘A’ ordinary shares of £1 (j£o-io paid) are held by industrial,
shipping, mining and banking interests in the United Kingdom, and nf
million ‘B’ ordinary shares of £1 (^0*50 paid) are held by the Bank of England
and certain central banks in the Commonwealth. At 31st March 1973 the
CDFC held investments worth £32 million spread over a wide range of
industries placed in more than 35 countries.
The stock exchanges of the United Kingdom and Irish Republic amalgamated
on 25th March 1973. Dealings with the public remain unchanged, but brokers
may open offices nationally and firms wherever situated trade on equal terms.
The main exchange and central administration are in London. Exchanges are
also in Glasgow, Liverpool, Manchester, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff, Dublin
and Belfast.
The number and variety of securities officially listed on the London exchange
is greater than in any other market and its turnover of company securities is
roughly equivalent to that of all the European bourses combined. Some 9,000
securities are quoted on the London exchange; at the end of March 1973 these
had a total market value of £167,290 million. About 7,770 securities of
companies are quoted, including a number of leading overseas companies.

and Unit Trusts

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Company issues represented more than four-fifths of the securities at market
valuation, the remainder being United Kingdom and overseas government
and corporation stocks.
The stock exchange does not fix dealing prices; the terms on which bargains
are made between members reflect the interaction of supply and demand for
the securities concerned. The stock exchange operates under strict rules of
conduct which it formulates itself.
There has been substantial growth in demand in the post-war period for
ordinary (equity) shares, partly in expectation that such shares will maintain
or increase their real value in periods of rising prices. There is a growing level
of institutional investment on the London market by insurance companies,
pension funds, and by investment and unit trusts. The percentage of total
market holdings of United Kingdom quoted ordinary shares held by these
four groups of institutions together rose from 25 per cent to 31 per cent over
the six-year period March 1964-70.
Investment trust companies and unit trusts enable investors to spread their
risks and obtain the benefit of skilled management.
The usual type of investment trust company is constituted as a public com¬
pany registered under the Companies Acts with limited liability; its business
is to invest its capital in a range of stocks and shares. Like other companies, it
may issue several types of stocks or shares and may retain part of its profits to
build up reserves. Investment trust companies grew to importance in the latter
half of the nineteenth century and have been prominent in directing capital
towards overseas investment. At the end of 1972 investment trust companies
held assets worth £7,440 million, of which over one-third were in overseas
securities.
Unit trusts are constituted by trust deed between a management company
and a trustee company which holds the assets. Normally, the managers se 1
units to the public and must invest the proceeds in a fairly wide range of stock
exchange securities. The costs of running the trust are defrayed partly by an
initial charge which forms part of the price of a unit and partly by a semi¬
annual service charge which is usually taken out of the income of the trust.
The level of both charges is controlled by the Department of Trade and
Industry, whose authorisation is required before units can be offered to the
public; this is only granted if the trust deed is satisfactory to them.
The first British unit trust was formed in 1931 and by 1939 there were
98 trusts, with assets estimated at £80 million. This medium of saving has
grown considerably since 1957. At the end of April 1973 there were 2-3
million unit holdings. The value of the funds invested in authorised trusts rose
from £60 million in 1958 to £2,460 million at the end of April 1973 ; it has
nearly trebled since the end of 1967. There is now a wide variety of trusts,
both as to the range of investments covered and the ways in which they cater
for the differing needs of investors.
Although a certain amount of insurance is provided by friendly societies and
trade unions, most insurance services in Britain are in the hands of mutual or
joint stock insurance companies or Lloyd’s underwriters.
There are about 590 insurance companies incorporated in the United Kingdom.
Most British insurers write several classes of business although some specialise
in one class, particularly in life assurance, where about 130 companies write
only that type of business. A few specialise in re-insurance.

International

In addition about 160 overseas companies carry on business (and even more
companies are represented) in the United Kingdom, which illustrates the
international nature of the London market. Some of the large British com¬
panies, however, have their administrative headquarters in the provinces.
At the end of 1972 the total assets of the British insurance companies
amounted to about £19,000 million, the bulk of which is life assurance
companies’ investments.
The Government’s supervisory powers over insurance companies under the
Insurance Companies Acts 1958-67 and the Insurance Companies Amend¬
ments Act 1973 are exercised by the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI).
Lloyd’s is an incorporated society of private insurers in London. The name
‘Lloyd’s’ is derived from Edward Lloyd’s coffee house, established in the late
seventeenth century, where merchants with maritime and other interests
gathered to transact business. By the middle of the eighteenth century,
Lloyd’s coffee house had become the principal centre of underwriting business
and intelligence of shipping movements. Although in its earlier history the
activities of Lloyd’s were confined to the conduct of marine insurance business,
there has also been built up at Lloyd’s a very considerable world-wide market
for the transaction of other classes of insurance business in its non-marine,
aviation and motor markets.
Lloyd’s is regulated by a series of special Acts of Parliament starting in 1871;
the affairs of the Society of Lloyd’s in its corporate capacity are administered
by the Committee of Lloyd’s, which does not itself transact insurance business.
Lloyd’s is not a company but a market for insurance, where business is
transacted by individual underwriters for their own account and risk and in
competition with each other. Insurance may only be placed through Lloyd’s
brokers, who negotiate with Lloyd’s underwriters on behalf of the insured.
Only elected underwriting members of Lloyd’s, who must transact insurance
with unlimited liability and who have met the most stringent financial regula¬
tions laid down by the Committee of Lloyd’s, are permitted to transact
business at Lloyd’s; these financial safeguards give security to the Lloyd’s
policy which is second to none. Since 1969 non-Commonwealth underwriters
have been admitted to membership of Lloyd’s, if they satisfy the requirements.
Today there are about 7,100 underwriting members of Lloyd’s grouped
into some 260 syndicates and represented at Lloyd’s by underwriting agents
who accept risks on behalf of the members of their syndicates.
In conjunction with its marine insurance business Lloyd’s has built up a
world-wide organisation for the collection and diffusion of shipping intelli¬
gence.
The insurance market is completed by the insurance brokers, acting on behalf
of the insured; brokers are an essential part of the Lloyd’s market and a
valuable part of the company market. Many brokers specialise in re-insurance
business, acting as intermediaries in the exchange of contracts between
companies, both British and overseas, and often acting as London representa¬
tives of the latter.
About two-thirds of general insurance business (that is non-life) is carried
on overseas, partly by re-insurance on the London market and partly through
branches and agencies established in over 100 countries. The basic principle
of this international business is that resources capable of meeting any potential
loss are instantly available for use in any part of the world.
Behind this large and international volume of business stand the very
226
Building
Societies
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
substantial assets of the companies, in addition to substantial reserves of
uncalled capital, and the deposits, underwriting trust funds and other re¬
sources of Lloyd’s underwriters.
In accordance with the Treaty of Rome insurance and re-insurance in the
European Community are regulated by directives addressed to the govern¬
ments of member states. The purpose of the directives is to harmonise the
legislation of the various member countries, thus providing a ‘common
market’, which would avoid distortion of competition. Two directives have
been approved by the Council of Ministers. The first deals with the conditions
of access to non-life insurance business and the second requires member
countries not to discriminate in law or practice between their own subjects
and those of other member states. The Commission is also preparing draft
directives on life insurance, insurance contracts, and the taxation of insurance
policies.
The principal function of building societies is to supply long-term loans on
the security of private dwelling-houses purchased for owner-occupation
though loans are occasionally made on the security of commercial and
industrial premises and farms. The funds of building societies are derived
mainly from the general public who invest in shares or deposits. 1 he amount
of share capital is not fixed; shares which have a fixed value are not dealt
in on the stock exchange but may be withdrawn in cash if notice is given.
The Building Societies Act 1962, which consolidated a number of earlier Acts,
prescribes the general way in which societies must conduct their business.
The Chief Registrar of Friendly Societies has discretionary powers to stop
a society either advertising or accepting money from investors if he considers
that the way in which the society’s business is conducted is jeopardising
investors’ money. The rapid expansion of building society activity m the
twentieth century has been accompanied by a concentration of most of the
business in the hands of a few large societies. At the end of 1972, 456 societies
were in operation, with total assets of ^15,25° million; half of this amount
being accounted for by the five largest societies. The amount advanced on
mortgage in 1972 was nearly £3,650 million, over one-third more than in 1971.

OVERSEAS TRADE
Although small in area and accounting for less than 2 per cent of the world’s
population, Britain is the fourth largest trading nation in the world—and, as
a member of the European Community, part of the world’s biggest trading
area which accounts for 40 per cent of all trade.
For well over a century international trade has been of vital importance to
the country’s economy. Britain relies upon imports for about half its total con¬
sumption of foodstuffs and most of the raw materials needed for its industries.
Its exports of goods represent over one-sixth of the gross national product.
It is a major supplier of machinery, vehicles, aircraft, metal manufactures,
electrical apparatus, chemicals and textiles. It is also the world’s largest
importer of foodstuffs, and among the largest for metals and ores, textile raw
materials, petroleum and many other products.
Changes in the value, volume, composition and geographical distribution of
imports and exports are outlined in the following paragraphs.
In 1972 Britain’s exports of goods were valued at about ,£9,135 million f.o.b.,
that is, excluding the cost of freight and insurance outside the United King¬
dom, and imports at about ,£11,155 million (including the cost of freight and
insurance to the United Kingdom). Valued on the same basis as exports,
imports in 1972 were about £9,827 million. Between 1961 and 1972 the value
of exports rose by 135 per cent while that of imports increased by 143 per cent.
Over the same period the volume index of exports rose by 59 per cent, and of
imports by 77 per cent.
Exports had increased steadily from 1961 to 1966, but in 1967 they declined
slightly in value as well as in volume. Following the devaluation of sterling in
1967 they rose rapidly. In 1972 they increased by 4 per cent in value compared
with 11 per cent in 1971; the small rise in 1972 resulted from the decline in
demand in the sterling area (and import restrictions in some African countries).
In the first half of 1973 the volume of exports resumed rapid growth.
There was a particularly rapid expansion of imports in 1964 (15 per cent in
value and 11 per cent in volume) and again in 1968 (22 per cent in value and
10 per cent in volume). In 1972 the value of imports rose by 16 per cent; this
increase, and a further large increase in the first half of 1973, reflected the
rising demand for imports associated with the growth of domestic output, the
effects of the depreciation of the pound sterling, and the rise in commodity
prices (see p. 201). From 1964 to 1967 there was a steady improvement in
Britain’s terms of trade, that is, export prices rose faster than import prices.
In 1970 the index (1961 = 100) rose to 104 and in 1971 to no, a level which
was maintained in 1972; but by the end of the first quarter of 1973, with the
sharp rise in commodity prices and the lower exchange value of sterling, the
index had fallen to 99.

to 1972 are shown in Table 14.
