The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom was the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today about 16 people work in manufacturing, mining and
building for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world’s fourth largest
exporter of manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures
reflects its position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary from
the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National Coal
Board, a public corporation with about 335,000 employees, Imperial Chemical
Industries Ltd. and the General Electric Company Ltd., which, with labour
forces in the United Kingdom of 135,000 and 171,000 respectively, are among
the largest limited liability companies; and the Co-operative Wholesale Society
Ltd., with about 23,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes, made by two statutory companies;
iron, steel and a small range of chemicals from the plants of the British Steel
Corporation; aero-engines made by Rolls-Royce (1971) Ltd.; locomotives and
rolling-stock built in the workshops of British Railways; and military equip¬
ment and supplies made in establishments of the defence services. Staff of the
Stationery Office do some printing and bookbinding. Certain factories giving
employment to the severely disabled are operated by Remploy Ltd., a non-
profit-making public company financed on the Vote of the Department of
Employment, which appoints the directors (see p. 375). The Government
holds about 49 per cent of the equity of a major oil company, British Petroleum
Limited, and has a controlling interest in a few other companies.
The most recent complete analysis of the size distribution of establishments
and enterprises in manufacturing industry, and of the degree of concentration,
is contained in the Report on the Census of Production 1968. This shows that
some 64 per cent (59,000) of the 92,000 or so establishments which submitted
returns had fewer than 25 employees each, and accounted for 7 per cent of
total employment; some 28,000 establishments, nearly one-third of the total,
had between 25-500 employees, and accounted for over two-fifths of the total
labour force; 2,400 establishments, each with between 500 and 2,000 em¬
ployees, were responsible for 28 per cent of employment; while 21 per cent
was in the hands of the 409 leading groups each with over 2,000 employees. A
high proportion of the biggest establishments were in the heavy industries;
the average size of establishments in industries making consumer goods was
smaller than in manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with results
obtained in earlier years suggested a slow but significant trend towards in¬
creased average size of establishments.
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of manu¬
facturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establishments,
254
Building and
Civil Engineering
Mining and
Quarrying
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities. An enter¬
prise, as defined in the 1968 census, normally consists of either a single firm
or a parent company together with its subsidiaries. Just over 34 per cent of all
employment in British manufacturing industries in 1968 was accounted for
by more than 1,000 large private enterprises employing 1,000 or more people,
the largest 100 or so accounting roughly for a third. A further indication of
company size is the value of capital employed (net assets). In the case of three
companies, the Imperial Chemical Industries group, British Petroleum and
Shell Transport and Trading, the figure exceeds ^2,000 million; about 81
companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net assets.
With intensified competition in the economy and, in many branches of
industry, the growing dependence of profitable operation on concentration and
an increasing scale of production, the trend towards mergers and regrouping
gathered momentum throughout the last decade. Larger units of control have
been established in almost all the leading industries and in some a small
number of big companies and their subsidiaries are responsible for most of
total production. Examples are oil refining, non-ferrous metal smelting, motor
vehicles and aircraft, heavy electrical engineering, electronics, machine tools,
brewing, textiles, basic chemicals, tobacco and magazine publishing. Shares
in these companies are usually distributed among a great number of holders
and it is rare for a few large holders to have a controlling interest. For example,
43 of the largest public companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 290-313.
Large-scale building and civil engineering work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Department of the Environment (see p. 52)
is the largest single employer of building labour while 37 per cent of the in¬
dustry’s output is for the public sector. Building firms may be divided into
those undertaking general building and civil engineering work and those con¬
cerned with highly specialised work, many of which operate outside as well as
inside the building industry. Building is an industry of small firms; some
90 per cent of the firms employ fewer than 25 employees. For a fuller account
of the building and civil engineering industries, see p. 288.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
Britain’s coalmining industry is operated as a single co-ordinated enterprise
under National Coal Board direction. Nearly all other mining and quarrying
(sand, gravel, chalk, limestone, salt, tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is under¬
taken by private enterprises, usually owned and operated by limited liability
companies; about 44,000 workers are employed, excluding coalmining.
Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
Legislation provides for the registration and judicial examination of restrictive
trading agreements and the investigation by an independent administrative
body of monopoly situations. Under the Fair Trading Act 1973, the Director-
General of Fair Trading carries out functions in relation to restrictive trading
agreements, monopoly situations and mergers, and protection of consumers.
The Restrictive Trade Practices Acts 1956 and 1968 as amended by the h air
Trading Act 1973 govern the registration and judicial examination of restrictive
agreements. They require the entry in a public register of the particulars of a
wide range of restrictive agreements (including those relating to common
prices, approved lists of dealers and the limitation of production) which affect
the supply of goods or commercial services for the United Kingdom market.
Proposed agreements of national importance which promote efficiency or
INDUSTRY
Role of Public
Enterprise
255
provide for new productive capacity can be exempted from this requirement
for a specified period by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry (see
p. 262). The Director General of Fair Trading is responsible for keeping the
register and for bringing the agreements before the Restrictive Practices
Court set up under the 1956 Act. If the parties to an agreement fail to satisfy
the court that special circumstances set out in the legislation exist, and that
the restriction is not unreasonable, having regard to the balance between the
benefit it confers and any public detriment likely to result from its operation,
that restriction must be found contrary to the public interest. Agreements are
void in respect of restrictions so found. The court can make orders preventing
the parties from operating their agreement, or from making new arrangements
having the same effect. Agreements relating exclusively to exports are not
subject to this procedure but have to be notified to the Secretary of State for
Trade and Industry.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance was
prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce minimum resale
prices in the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 made minimum resale price
maintenance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for
which temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
The Director General of Fair Trading has a duty to specify the goods and
services in respect of which the court has refused to make an order of exemp¬
tion from the terms of the Act. Only two classes of goods (books and maps and
medicaments) have so far gained exemption under an order from the court;
nearly 500 classes have been refused exemption.
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (other than those within the scope
of the Restrictive Practices Court) may be referred for investigation and
report to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission by the Director General
of Fair Trading or by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, or in the
case of statutory bodies only by the Secretary of State together with other
ministers where appropriate. If the commission finds that monopoly condi¬
tions operate against the public interest, the Department of Trade and Industry
has powers to remedy or prevent harm which in its opinion may result. The
Fair Trading Act replaces, with revised provision, the Monopolies and Mergers
Acts 1948 and 1965 and makes several changes to widen the scope within
which monopoly and merger situations can be referred for investigation by the
commission. The market share by reference to which monopoly is defined is
reduced from one-third to one-quarter, and there are new powers to refer
local monopolies and public sector industries to the commission. The special
provisions relating to newspaper mergers, and the provisions relating to other
merger cases, remain substantially unaltered. A merger may be referred to the
commission by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry if it results in,
or strengthens, a monopoly situation, or if the value of assets taken over exceeds
IS million.
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether about 12 per
cent of the labour force works for these bodies. Their managing boards and
staffs are chosen for their experience and competence in a particular field; they
are not civil servants, and, although accountable to Parliament for their actions
256
Industrial
Association
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring depart¬
ments who are responsible for the management of the corporations. Certain of
the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer grants to help
them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
These corporations are described in their relevant sections.
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members of
each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to how
the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day management.
It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister any in¬
formation, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In practice,
as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy decisions
are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion for him to
issue a formal directive.
The minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings. However, financial targets have been
agreed by the Government with the different industries (or are under dis¬
cussion) ranging from 12-4 per cent gross return on capital employed to
‘breaking even’ after interest and depreciation have been allowed for. In
addition the industries are expected to apply a test discount rate for new
investment of 10 per cent. The responsible minister is usually empowered
(subject to Treasury approval) to say what shall be done with any surplus
revenues which may accrue. As regards finance for capital expenditure, the
present system is that finance which cannot be met from internal sources is
provided mainly by interest bearing loans from the Exchequer and in certain
cases by borrowing from abroad (see p. 212).
It is usual for the minister responsible for each nationalised industry to be
required by statute to take steps to see that the interests of the industry’s
customers are protected. This is generally done by the establishment of
representative consumers’ councils to consider complaints and suggestions
made to them, and to advise the board or the minister on the changes they
think desirable. ... . • 1 •
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are admissible
only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration. A House of
Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries, which examines
the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and reports to Parlia¬
ment, has been in operation since 1957.
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as: (1) the pro¬
vision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison with the
Government, and representation of their members’ point of view; (2) the
regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of prices
(see p. 255); (3) negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of
work. Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with varying
completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of industry
INDUSTRY
257
Location
Greater London
and the South-east
Region
where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices. Em¬
ployers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of firms
engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations, concerned mainly with representation to the Government, the
provision of common services and the regulation of trading practices are
normally composed of firms manufacturing a particular product or group of
products. In an industrial sector concerned wholly with an allied group of
products, a single association may undertake all the required functions.
There are about 70 national federations and some 1,400 employers’
organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or branches of the
national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages and conditions of
work (see also p. 384). The number of manufacturers’ associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely but is thought to total
some 1,200, varying greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representa¬
tives of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory and
consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascertaining
their collective views and representing them nationally to the Government
and the public and also internationally, for example in the Council of Euro¬
pean Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a number of govern¬
ment advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies
concerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 11,800 companies, 195 trade
associations and employers’ federations and 37 commercial associations.
Nationalised industries have joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a
regional organisation in the United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These are open to all kinds of producers and traders and exist
to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The Association of
British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central organisation
to which approximately 100 local chambers of commerce (together with 20
British Chambers of Commerce operating abroad) are affiliated. In Scotland
there is an additional central organisation, the Scottish Chamber of Commerce,
and in Northern Ireland, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and
Industry to which local chambers are affiliated.
The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British in¬
dustry today, grouped according to the eight standard regions of England,
plus Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
London is Britain’s capital and main communication centre, and is probably
still the world’s most important financial centre. Lying at the head of ocean
navigation on the Thames estuary it is one of the world’s largest cities and
largest ports, though much deep-sea-going traffic has moved down-river to
Tilbury docks. It is the main centre in Britain of printing and the manufac¬
ture of clothing, food and drink, furniture, materials for the arts, precision
instruments and many other specialised products. Small firms predominate in
many of these industries and the average size of manufacturing firms (parti¬
cularly in the central area) is well below the national average. London is also
important, especially in its outer ring, for light engineering, chemicals and
consumer goods and has some heavy engineering plants and a number of
leading research establishments.
258
South-west
Englatid
East Anglia
West Midlands
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Towards the periphery of Greater London (population 7,353,810) and in
the new urban development outside it, industry, particularly the electronics
and a variety of consumer goods industries, has expanded greatly; some of the
largest aircraft plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge and Hatfield,
as well as factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two of the four
main motor vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor vehicle
manufacturing plants at Cowley, Oxford (112,000), some 50 miles north-west
of London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there are large oil
refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works and major
concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
A great part of the Channel coast eastwards from Poole (population 109,000)
and Bournemouth (149,000) consists of built-up areas, which from Brighton
(164,000) eastwards are partly dormitories for people working in London.
Holiday resorts fringe the coast. Portsmouth (207,000) is a naval port with
some shipbuilding and general manufactures. Southampton (214,000) is
Britain’s largest port for ocean-going liners; its industries include ship repair¬
ing, oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover,
Folkestone and Newhaven are packet ports.
Though famous for its tourism, leisure industries and agriculture, the south¬
west of England has a busy manufacturing sector. In the Camborne, Redruth,
Falmouth and St. Austell areas (93,000), Cornwall has china clay and tin
mining, and machinery manufacture, ship repairing and other forms of
engineering. Plymouth (250,000) with the naval dockyard and electrical and
other industries, is an important manufacturing centre. The towns of Glou¬
cester (91,000), Cheltenham (76,000) and Bath (85,000) are major producers
of machinery, instrumentation and other engineering products. Swindon
(90,000) has vehicle, electrical and electronic engineering. Clothing, footwear,
and other textile products are made at several centres. Bristol (422,000), the
region’s administrative and commercial centre, is a leading port and the
largest industrial city, having food processing, tobacco, packaging materials,
printing, aerospace, machinery and a wide range of other industries ; there are
extensive modern docks at Avonmouth, an industrialised suburb with impor
tant basic chemicals and non-ferrous metal plants.
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (100,000) is a leading centre
of research-based industry; Ipswich (123,000) and Peterborough (71,000) are
noted for diesel engines, agricultural machinery and engineering generally;
and Norwich (120,000) for footwear and food manufacture. Food canning and
freezing, based mainly on locally grown produce, have developed rapidly.
The fishing ports of Great Yarmouth (50,000) and Lowestoft (53,000) have
fish processing plants, and have also become important bases for companies
engaged in petroleum and natural gas exploitation in the North Sea.
The main concentration of industry in the West Midlands is in the conurba¬
tion which includes Birmingham (1,007,000), Wolverhampton (269,000),
Dudley (186,000), Walsall (184,000), West Bromwich (165,000), Warley
(162,000) and Solihull (108,000) and in Coventry (336,000). The economy of
the conurbation and Coventry is dominated by the metal-using industries, in
particular by motor vehicle manufacture which itself draws substantially from
the mechanical and electrical engineering industries. Other notable industries
include jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware.
The manufacture of pottery and china is the most important industry in the
INDUSTRY
259
East Midlands
North-west
England
smaller conurbation of north Staffordshire centred upon Stoke on Trent
(262,000). Other manufactures such as rubber and electrical products have
developed in the area in recent years, but coalmining has contracted.
Other industrial centres include Stafford (55,000), heavy electrical and other
engineering; Worcester (74,000), engineering; Burton on Trent (50,000),
brewing and rubber; Kidderminster (49,000), carpets; and Rugby (60,000),
electrical engineering. An important tourist centre is Stratford-upon-Avon
(20,000), the birthplace of William Shakespeare.
The industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(281,000), noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (219,000) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (300,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products and tobacco;
Northampton (127,000), footwear and engineering; and Chesterfield (70,000),
engineering. Corby (48,000), a new town in Northamptonshire, has a large
integrated steel works. Part of Britain’s richest and most highly mechanised
coalfield lies under the north-east of the area. Some of the towns on the coal¬
field, such as Mansfield (58,000), have important manufacturing industries,
particularly textiles.
Manchester (541,000) is Britain’s second most important commercial and
financial centre and a major port. It is the commercial hub of the cotton and
man-made fibre textiles industries and one of the chief centres for electrical
and heavy engineering and an industrial centre for the production of a wide
range of goods including machine tools, petrochemicals, dyestuffs, and
pharmaceuticals. The traditional cotton-manufacturing towns circling Man¬
chester, while adapting to the increasing use of man-made fibres, have seen
engineering outgrow the textile industry. The largest towns are Bolton
(154,000), Stockport (140,000), Oldham (106,000), Blackburn (102,000),
Preston (97,000), Rochdale (91,000) and Bury (68,000), and these have
diversified into printing, paper making, textile and electrical machinery and
heavy commercial vehicles (especially in the Chorley-Leyland area). The few
remaining Lancashire coal mines still being worked lie in the Manchester-
Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of export
traffic, links Manchester and Merseyside. It passes through Warrington
(68,000), with its metal industries (such as wire-drawing), Widnes (57,000)
and Runcorn (36,000) with the chemical industry, and Ellesmere Port
(62,000) with its oil refinery installations, before reaching the Mersey estuary.
St. Helens (104,000), to the north of the canal, is famous for glass manufac¬
ture. Liverpool (607,000) is an important commercial and insurance centre as
well as being the third largest port in Britain and, after London, the largest
centre for processing imported foodstuffs and raw materials (especially flour
milling, soap, sugar refining and rubber products). Its industrial strengths have
changed from the older industries such as shipbuilding and repair across the
river at Birkenhead (138,000) to newer industries, including electrical engin¬
eering, manufacture of heavy industrial plant and, more recently, of motor
vehicles. Its chemical plants are also important users of salt, extracted in
Cheshire.
The north-west has a major international airport at Ringway and a com¬
prehensive rail and motorway system, which not only link the conurbations
to the more northerly industrial towns such as Barrow (60,000) (shipbuilding
and marine engineering), and the tourist resorts such as Blackpool (151,000),
260
Yorkshire and
Humberside
Northern England
Wales
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
but also provide access to the other major ports and conurbations of the
country.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen industries
are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (294,000) is the com¬
mercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (45,000), Dewsbury
(51,000) and Spenborough (41,000) have specialised in heavy cloth, but their
production is becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (130,000) has a repu¬
tation for fine woollens and worsteds and Halifax (90,000) for carpets. In most
of the larger centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are
manufactured. Leeds (499,000), the commercial capital of the area, has a large
ready-made clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south
is the heavy engineering centre of Sheffield (513,000), famous for its high
quality steels, cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide over
one-quarter of Britain’s coal; Doncaster (82,000), also with tractor and nylon
manufacturing, and Barnsley (75,000) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (105,000) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (283,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, chemicals and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (70,000),
an important and expanding steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of
Grimsby (95,000) which has a food processing industry and also growing
chemicals and textiles industries close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population is concen¬
trated in the coastal strip from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees.
Within this area the main centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon
Tyne (222,000), Gateshead (94,000), Tynemouth (69,000), South Shields
(100,000), Wallsend (46,000) and Jarrow (29,000); and Teesside (395,000) and
Hartlepool (97,000). Other large towns are Sunderland (217,000), Darlington
(86,000) and in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants on
both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ over one-quarter of the male workers. This proportion has
been falling steadily as the result of the region’s efforts, with government help,
to attract new types of enterprise. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. An aluminium smelter is
operating on the Northumberland coast. Atomic energy is important in
Cumberland, with two nuclear power stations and other installations.
Over two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire live in the
two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this area are the coal
mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing depths, still
produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and other special¬
ised coals, and employ more workers than any branch of manufacturing
INDUSTRY
26l
Scotland
Northern Ireland
industry. Rhondda (83,000) and Merthyr Tydfil (55,000) are the largest centres
in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the most modern
plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate and much of
its sheet steel. In the past 35 years many new industries have been established,
often on government industrial estates; they include plastics, synthetic fibres,
clothing, electronics, motor vehicle components and light engineering.
The main urban centres are also the three major ports—Cardiff (275,000),
Newport (112,000) and Swansea (172,000). Milford Haven (14,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres, are
located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly Wrexham
(39,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population of 5-2 million is concentrated in
the central Lowlands between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The
principal cities in this area are Glasgow (862,000), a major commercial centre
and Edinburgh (450,000), Scotland’s capital, an administrative and cultural
centre. Clydeside, which includes Glasgow, is a major shipbuilding and marine
engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering enter¬
prises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north Lanark¬
shire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed electronics
equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms in such
centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as well as in
Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding alongside
the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries. Motor car
manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West Lothian there
has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
With the major oil discoveries which have been made in the North Sea (see
p. 275), the area around Aberdeen is becoming a major oil centre and sub¬
stantial development by oil-based industries is taking place.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concen¬
tration in and around Dundee (182,000) and Aberdeen (182,000) and a number
of towns outside these areas have attracted light industries in recent years.
Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented by office
machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators and electronic products. In
north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of whisky distilleries, while
the paper and metal industries are also important.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 280).
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley towns
of the Borders and in the Highlands and Islands. Small engineering and
electronics industries have recently been established in towns in the Borders
and the south-west. Small-scale manufacturing has also been introduced in the
Highlands, and larger enterprises include the experimental atomic reactor
establishment at Dounreay and the aluminium smelter recently commissioned
at Invergordon (see p. 293). There is also large-scale development in oil-
related industries in the Moray Firth and Cromarty Firth areas.
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and lacking in
minerals, there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and
around Belfast, the capital city (362,000). Britain’s largest single shipyard
incorporating the world’s biggest shipbuilding berth is in Belfast; other long-
established activities include the manufacture of textile machinery and other
262 BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
engineering products, ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing. Northern Ireland
has also long been an important centre for textiles—it is particularly well
known for linen. The textile industry is now diversified; Northern Ireland is
one of the most important areas in Europe for man-made fibre production and
provides over one-fifth of Britain’s output. There has also been extensive
development in vehicle components, oil-well equipment, electronic instru¬
ments, telephone switchgear, shoes and synthetic rubber.
Relations
between the
Government
and Industry
Statistical
Services
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways—
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the placing of government contracts, through the policies of publicly
owned enterprises, by physical controls, by inducements, by exhortation and by
the provision of services, information and advice. Apart from labour legislation
(see Chapter 17) and certain export and import controls over a small range of
products (see Chapter 13), there are few physical controls over industry—the
main ones are the use of the legislation concerning monopolies and restrictive
practices already described (see p. 254) and the operation of powers to control
new industrial and office building and changes in land use.
There is close association between industry and the Government through
such channels as the National Economic Development Council, the main
forum for consultation between the Government, management and the trade
unions, and Economic Development Committees (EDCs) which cover parti¬
cular industrial sectors.
The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), set up in October 1970 to
combine the functions of the Board of Trade and the Ministry of Technology,
is the first single body with responsibility for all policies affecting production
and trade (both internal and export), and for the Government’s relations with
individual industries. Following a review of the machinery for aerospace policy
and defence procurement, the former, together with civil aerospace research,
has become the responsibility of the DTI, while the latter is handled by a
procurement executive at the Ministry of Defence.
Policies on labour matters, including industrial relations, industrial training
and manpower in general are the concern of the Department of Employment.
Other departments involved with industrial issues are the Treasury (fiscal and
monetary policy and medium- and long-term economic questions); the
Department of Education and Science, which is responsible for the promotion
of education and for civil science, operating primarily through the research
councils; and the Department of the Environment (relations with the con¬
struction industry and some regional matters).
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Commerce deals with industry and
industrial development.
The Government Statistical Service which includes the Central Statistical
Office (CSO), the Business Statistics Office (BSO), the Office of Population
Censuses and Surveys and the statistics divisions of the major departments,
provides a service of statistical information and advice. Each department is
responsible for compiling statistics relating to its own policy area and publish¬
ing them, usually through its own publications. Data about individual in¬
dustries are published by the BSO in Business Monitors. Comprehensive
statistical publications are produced by the CSO.

Productivity
Industrial production (mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction,
and gas, electricity and water) was in 1972 some 2-6 per cent higher than a

The size of the labour force has fallen slightly in the last five years and the
increases in production have been due mainly to a variety of factors influencing
productivity, including advances in products, machinery, processes and
methods of work; the rate of fixed capital formation; more intensive competi¬
tion and sales promotion; and improved management.
Although gross fixed capital formation at home has, as a whole, been well
maintained since 1966, the proportion devoted to manufacturing has tended
to fall. The total in 1972 amounted to 21 per cent of the gross domestic product
and was estimated (at current prices) to be more than double the 1963 level.
Part of this rising investment is associated with the introduction of new
techniques and equipment and in particular of machines and instruments
which lessen the demand for human skill and supervision though they may
require more skill from fewer people. This process of automation is giving rise
to far-reaching changes in the pattern of industry and in the internal organisa¬
tion and labour requirements of business enterprises and has already been
responsible for consequential increases in production and efficiency which, in
the long run, are likely to be very large. Much investment, however, still con¬
sists of replacements, additions and improvements of a more traditional kind.
Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. But though the
promotion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter for industry,
government departments and educational and research establishments also
have an important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial
policies also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand,
and government purchasing policies take account of national industrial
objectives.
Within industry, employers’ organisations often provide technical assistance,
conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational education and
training, and many trade unions organise special training schemes and courses
264
Standards
Design
Co-ordination
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
to promote understanding of modern management techniques. Changes in
working methods to facilitate higher output feature in a number of produc¬
tivity agreements negotiated between management and workers. Private con¬
sultants specialising in management and work study are available to advise
firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency; there are also many
specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned with various aspects
of productivity. The local organisations arrange meetings, inter-factory visits,
courses, conferences, film shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
in respect of, among other things, quality, performance, dimensions, testing
methods and codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by
manufacturers, buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies
the specification of requirements. The BSI is governed by a council consisting
of representatives of the main organisations of employers and workers, pro¬
fessional institutions and the larger government departments.
The Design Council, set up by the Government in 1944 as the Council of
Industrial Design to promote higher standards of design in British industry,
is concerned with all aspects of industrial design from durable consumer goods
to engineering products. The Council, with its Scottish Committee, is a grant-
aided body sponsored by the Department of Trade and Industry; its members
include industrialists, engineers, retailers, architects, designers and educa¬
tionists and trade unionists. At The Design Centre in the Haymarket, London,
a selective but changing display of modern British consumer goods is main¬
tained; exhibits are chosen from Design Index, the Council’s illustrated record
of more than 11,000 well-designed products. Special exhibitions on particular
themes are also arranged regularly. An annual awards scheme, Design Council
Awards, covering capital goods and engineering equipment as well as con¬
sumer products, was introduced in 1967. The Duke of Edinburgh also
presents his annual Design Prize. The Scottish Committee runs the Scottish
Design Centre in Glasgow, and there is an independent regional design centre,
maintaining a duplicate of the Index, at Manchester. The Council organises
temporary exhibitions in regional centres and overseas; arranges regular
conferences and training courses; undertakes industrial study tours in Britain,
and operates a designer selection service which can make recommendations to
any individual or organisation from a list of over 2,800 British industrial,
interior and graphic designers. It publishes a monthly magazine, Design, and
maintains reference and photographic libraries.
Other bodies concerned with industrial design include the Royal Society of
Arts (see p. 399), the Society of Industrial Artists and Designers, which is the
representative professional body in Great Britain of designers engaged in
industry and commerce, and the Design and Industries Association (DIA), a
voluntary association of industrial companies, designers, and others interested
in the promotion of good design in industry. The Crafts Council of Great
Britain, the Crafts Centre of Great Britain and the Scottish Craft Centre are
all grant-aided by the Department of Trade and Industry. Their aims are to
improve craft design and to promote closer relations between craftsmen and
industry.
The Department of Trade and Industry is responsible for the co-ordination of
activities related to the improvement of industrial productivity. It is represented
on the EDCs (see p. 262)—which are concerned primarily with the removal of
INDUSTRY
Management
Encouragement
of Investment
in Industry
265
obstacles to efficiency—by seconded industrial advisers. The DTI is also
charged with extending the introduction of automatic control systems and
advanced techniques into industry, sponsors the BSI, the British Calibration
Service and the National Computing Centre, supports the National Data
Processing Service, and provides technical advisory services. It is concerned
directly with research into such factors as productivity measurement tech¬
niques, group technology, production engineering and fatigue among
operators. The Conciliation and Advisory Service of the Department of
Employment advises firms on aspects of productivity connected with man¬
power utilisation and industrial relations. A number of other departments
have responsibilities which bear on productivity.
In Britain, as elsewhere, management is recognised as a subject requiring
special skills and knowledge. This is reflected both in a change in the general
educational qualifications of recruits and in the spread of systematic education
and training for management.
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national manage¬
ment body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its purpose is
to study and promote scientific management, including management education
and training, throughout industry, commerce and public administration. The
BIM receives an annual government grant of about £ 100,000 to help it expand
services to industry. The Industrial Society works to promote better use of
human resources; it advises members and conducts conferences and courses.
Management studies and education for management are expanding rapidly
in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher education (see
p. 167). There are graduate business schools in London and Manchester.
Training courses for higher management are held at several universities and
colleges, including the Administrative Staff College, Henley-on-Thames, and
Ashridge College of Management, Berkhamsted. The larger firms, especially
those with wide responsibilities, often provide general management courses
for senior executives, and systems of informal training within an organisation
are numerous. There are also bodies concerned with specialised branches of
management, for example, the Institute of Personnel Management, the
Institution of Works Managers, the Institute of Office Management and the
Institute of Marketing.
The growing number of professional personnel working as management
consultants—now about 6,500—and the use of the services of independent
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are further
indications of interest in the science of management in Britain.
Under the Finance Act 1972 incentives to encourage capital expenditure in
plant and machinery take the form of a system of free depreciation enabling the
whole of such expenditure to be written off against profits for tax purposes in
the year in which it is incurred; there is in addition a 40 per cent initial allow¬
ance on new industrial buildings and structures and an annual writing down
allowance of 4 per cent. To maintain a greater incentive in the development
and special development areas (see below) the tax allowances available nation¬
ally and free depreciation are reinforced by regional development grants of 20
per cent and 22 per cent respectively towards capital expenditure on certain
new plant and machinery and on new or existing industrial buildings. These
grants are not treated for tax purposes as income receipts and so do not give
rise to corporation tax; nor do they affect the entitlement to the first year
allowance on plant and machinery, and building. The building grants are also

Government

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
available in the intermediate areas and—until March 1974—in derelict land
clearance areas.
The aim of industrial and regional policy is to secure a full and balanced
development of the country’s resources and to stimulate a faster and steadier
expansion in national output.
Major changes in the administration of policy were given effect by the
Industry Act 1972. A Minister for Industrial Development—under the broad
direction of the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry—is in charge of the
Industrial Development Executive which includes divisions of the Department
of Trade and Industry concerned with regional development. A Development
Unit within the executive is responsible for the appraisal and implementation
of regional policies. The Minister is advised on major specific cases for
assistance by an Industrial Development Advisory Board composed of repre¬
sentatives from industry, banking and finance while locally based Regional
Industrial Development Boards advise on general industrial opportunities and
on applications for selective financial assistance. Advice on wider planning
matters is given by regional economic planning councils assisted by economic
planning boards which were set up in 1965 (see p. 199).
A new European Community Regional Development Fund, financed from
the Community’s own resources, is planned to be set up before 31st December
1973-
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate of
economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemployment
above average as a result of the decline of some traditional industries or the
lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the north-east
and some other parts of England. This regional imbalance has been aggra¬
vated by the tendency for new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and
the south-east where, as a result, the demand for labour has been high and
there have been increasing problems of congestion. An important aim of the
Government’s regional policy is to achieve a better distribution of industrial
development between the different parts of the country. The Government has
in recent years taken important measures aimed at securing balanced economic
development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and has
been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war.
In 1966 most of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, Merseyside and part
of the south-west were designated ‘development areas’ qualifying for financial
assistance. In 1967 additional aid was made available in localities within them
where high and persistent unemployment was expected, and in 1971 these
‘special development areas’ were extended to cover industrial centres in west
central Scotland, north-east England and south Wales. Following investiga¬
tion of the needs of areas with economic problems outside the development
areas, in 1970 a number of localities were designated intermediate areas or
‘derelict land clearance areas’ with eligibility for assistance on a lesser scale
than development areas. The coverage of intermediate areas was extended in
1971 and 1972. The boundaries of the assisted areas are shown in the map on
the opposite page.
Besides the free depreciation allowances and grants on capital investment
there is a wide range of financial and other inducements available under the
Industry Act 1972 and the Local Employment Act 1970 to encourage industry

to expand in the assisted areas. In the development and intermediate areas the
Department of Trade and Industry may build factories for leasing, in some
cases with an initial rent-free period, or for sale on deferred terms, and provide
selective assistance including loans, and in certain circumstances grants
towards removal expenses.
Factory building and estate management are undertaken on the Department
of Trade and Industry’s behalf by the English, Scottish and Welsh Industrial
Estates Corporations; premises administered by the three Corporations total
over 67 million square feet and give employment to over 220,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes 85 per cent capital
grants to local authorities in development and special development areas for
clearing derelict or neglected sites; grants are also available for improving basic
services. The Department of Employment may help with the cost of training
additional labour in development areas and of transferring workers in con¬
nection with establishing new enterprises.
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised through
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. Any application
under the normal town and country planning machinery for planning per¬
mission for industrial development outside the development areas involving
more than 15,000 square feet of industrial floor space (or 10,000 square feet in
the south-east) must be accompanied by a certificate from the Department of
Trade and Industry certifying that the development in question can be carried
out consistently with the proper distribution of industry. In considering
applications the Secretary of State pays particular regard to the need for
providing appropriate employment in the assisted areas. In practice this
obligation has led to the refusal of certificates for most projects outside the
assisted areas unless it can be shown that the project could not reasonably be
undertaken in such an area or in Northern Ireland. Subject to this priority,
the control is also used to encourage dispersal of industry to new or expanding
towns taking population from the more congested areas. Under the Town and
Country Planning Act 1971 the Department of the Environment has power to
control office development in certain areas. Office development permits are
needed only for developments of over 10,000 square feet in the south-east of
England.
Under separate legislation capital grants are available at 30 per cent of the cost
of new buildings, machinery and equipment for the manufacturing, construc¬
tion and extractive industries in Northern Ireland. Total expenditure inclu¬
sive of grants qualifies for tax allowances. There is also provision for assisting
firms by means of loans to carry out major schemes of re-equipment, to move
to another area in particular need of industrial development or to undertake a
rehousing of their business in association with a major scheme of modernisa¬
tion and reorganisation. Help under the investment grants legislation is made
without regard to how much employment is created as a result.
As an alternative means of assistance in Northern Ireland there are compre¬
hensive and flexible powers authorised under the Industries Development Acts
for projects which offer a reasonable amount of employment. In such cases
individual development grants of up to 4° Per cent of expenditure on new
buildings, machinery and equipment are available, with tax allowances as
above. For those projects which offer exceptionally attractive returns in em¬
ployment or location within Northern Ireland, the assistance offered can
include tenancy of a government-built factory at low rent (including possibly
a rent-free period), grants towards operating costs in the initial stages, and
Councils to

Industry
Rural Industries
INDUSTRY 269
grants towards costs of removing existing machinery and installing it in a
factory in Northern Ireland.
Since 1945 over 280 new firms have been established in Northern Ireland
with government assistance, and the number of people now employed in
grant-aided industry totals over 77,000. A Finance Corporation with an initial
capital of £50 million has been formed to aid industrial and commercial
concerns which have short-term liquidity problems but long-term prospects of
viability.
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associations
concerned with promoting local industry. These are sponsored mainly by local
authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
the seven ‘crofting’ counties (see p. 327). It provides grants and loans to
industrial, commercial and other enterprises; it may also acquire land, provide
management and other advisory services and set up and carry on businesses.
The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary association,
promotes the general economic development of Scotland.
Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably advice and guidance to small businesses
in rural areas and country towns and loans for assistance to tourism in the
rural parts of development areas. In England and Wales this service is pro¬
vided by the Council for Small Industries in Rural Areas acting in consulta¬
tion with the Rural Community Councils through their Small Industries
Committees in the counties; by the Small Industries Council for Rural Areas
of Scotland; and in Northern Ireland by the Local Enterprise Development
Unit of the Ministry of Commerce. Another service provided by the Com¬
mission is the financing of small factories to stimulate rural industries and to
combat rural depopulation.
FUEL AND POWER
The main primary sources of energy used in Britain are coal, petroleum and,
to a lesser extent, nuclear energy, natural gas and water power; secondary
sources produced from these are electricity, town gas and coke.
Coal, most of it mined within the country, represents about 37 per cent of
primary energy consumption, although the amount of coal used and its share
of the total energy market has been falling. Oil has expanded its share of total
energy consumption rapidly from under 20 per cent in 1958 to nearly 48 per
cent in 1972. Although at present almost all oil is imported, the first supplies
are to be produced from the British sector of the North Sea during 1974. With
the advent of nuclear power and North Sea natural gas Britain has moved over
from two fuels to four. A programme for nuclear power stations has been in
progress since 1955 and nuclear power now provides a significant share of
1 The Development Commission recommends, and the Treasury approves and

time the Fund may be used to help and expand the rural economy (including accom¬
modation of tourists) and also to promote the development and improvement of
fisheries.

electricity supplies although only 3 per cent of total energy requirements. The
share of natural gas is expanding rapidly from supplies from the North Sea
discoveries and in 1972 accounted for 11 per cent of the energy market. Water¬
power resources are very small and cannot be developed much further. Trends
in primary energy consumption are shown in Table 25 and in the diagram
on p. 272.
The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for the effective and co-ordinated
development of fuel and power resources lies with the Secretary of State for
Trade and Industry and in the case of electricity in Scotland with the Secre¬
tary of State for Scotland. Research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using
industries. The Secretary of State also has an Advisory Council on Research
and Development.

The nationalised fuel and power industries in Britain employ in total some
650,000 people, or 2-5 per cent of the working population; their capital invest¬
ment in 1973-74 will be in the region of £800 million; their annual turnover
is almost ,£3,500 million; and the value of their net output is nearly 5 per cent
of the national product. The nationalised industry boards’ investment is
financed through internal resources and borrowing from the Government
(long term), the clearing banks (short term), and from overseas (long term)
sources. In each of the nationalised fuel industries there are statutory bodies
set up to protect the interests of consumers.
Following Britain’s entry into the European Community in January 1973
its fuel industries are co-operating to an increasing extent with those of the
other member countries. The coal industry now conforms to the rules of the
European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC, see p. 80); under the arrange¬
ments for British accession to the ECSC tariff barriers between the coal
markets of Britain and the other members were removed on 1st January 1973.
Britain’s entry means a doubling of the Community’s coal industry to a
combined annual production of some 300 million tons.
A Community energy policy is in the early stages of development with the
basic aim of guaranteeing certain and lasting energy supplies under satis¬
factory economic conditions. One possibility is that in order to lessen depen¬
dence on imported oil, the European Community will place more emphasis
on the contribution of coal to electricity production. Other possibilities are
more investment in nuclear power plant, and increased exploitation of natural
gas.
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years

ENERGY TRENDS 1962-1972
The National
Coal Board
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. In 1913—the peak production year—the industry
produced 287 million tons of coal, exported 94 million tons and employed over
a million workers.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and fourteen members appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry. The NCB has, with minor exceptions, exclusive rights over the
extraction of coal in Great Britain, but is empowered to license private opera-
INDUSTRY
273
Supply and
Demand
Production and
Manpower
tors to work small pits and open-cast sites. It has no monopoly in distribution,
and retail sales remain largely in private hands, but it has some retail depots
and makes bulk sales to large industrial consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the Secretary of State (and
through him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The Secretary of State has power
to issue general directives on matters affecting the national interest, and to
authorise borrowings to finance capital investment.
At the end of March 1973 there were 281 NCB collieries in operation, each
on average producing some 462,000 tons of coal, compared with 192,000 in
1947. Of these, 278 were grouped into 16 areas, each controlled by a director
responsible to the NCB. The remaining three collieries (in Kent) are controlled
by a general manager who is also responsible to the NCB.
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; sales fell sharply, however, between
1956 and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing
competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel, railway transport and other industries con¬
tributed to the fall in demand which is still continuing (see Table 26). Un¬
distributed stocks have recently been run down considerably and at the end
of March 1973 were 12 million tons.
Over half of total consumption is by the electricity authorities and under
one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens are other
large users while consumption by the gas industry is falling rapidly with the
switch to natural gas. Consumption by the electricity industry has increased
by 33 per cent since i960 to 71 million tons in 1972-73 whereas the require¬
ments of most other classes of consumer have declined. For domestic users
this fall has been slightly offset by increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have declined for somewhat similar reasons; in 1972-73 they
amounted to some 2-3 million tons. The biggest customer is the Federal
Republic of Germany; over 90 per cent of exports go to West European
countries. In 1972-73 imports amounted to over 3-4 million tons.
The fact that the British industry was developed so early has meant that many
of the best seams of coal are now worked out, but there are abundant reserves
of coal with which production can be maintained well into the next century;
there is also scope for opening new collieries should these be required. The
main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and Nottingham¬
shire field, which produces about half of the total output, (2) the Durham and
Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and (4) the Scottish field.
Other important coal-bearing areas are those of Lancashire and the west Mid¬
lands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).
Table 26 shows the main trends in the industry since 1950.
Coal consumption has fallen steadily over the past 20 years as shown in
Table 26 to 133 million tons in 1972-73. The fall in demand has been accom¬
panied by increases in productivity and has resulted in a rundown of the
labour force from some 700,000 to about 263,000. There were 10,400 fewer
workers in March 1973 than in March 1972. Productivity as a whole has risen
by over a half since 1961 to 2-3 tons per manshift in 1972-73; at the coal face
it has more than doubled over the last 20 years to 7-4 tons per manshift in
1972-73. The increases have been obtained largely by concentration on the
more productive mines and faces, by increasing mechanisation at the face,

and by the use of multi-shift working. At mechanised faces, output now
averages 8-6 tons per manshift compared with 2-7 tons at non-mechanised
faces. Other important measures which have contributed to increased produc¬
tivity include new techniques for obtaining information about the reserves
before they are worked, intensive training of management and men to obtain
the maximum utilisation of equipment on highly mechanised faces, the in¬
creasing use of powered supports, the use of higher horse-power machines
and improvements in the mechanised handling of coal below ground and on
the surface.
The NCB raises capital, including working capital, by borrowing from the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry. Within certain limits the board
may also, with the permission of the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry,
borrow temporarily (by way of overdraft or otherwise). The greater proportion
of investment is financed from internal resources.
A reorganisation of the board’s capital structure became necessary after a
prolonged labour dispute and resulting pay settlement; this had followed years
of contraction in the industry due mainly to competition from oil. Under the
Coal Industry Act 1973 some £450 million, being the NCB’s accumulated
deficit at the end of March 1973 together with the amount by which the
board’s capital assets were overvalued, was written off; the statutory limit on
the NCB’s borrowing is set at £550 million in the first instance, with provi¬
sion for extension to £700 million if necessary. The Act contains a number of
other provisions designed to improve the industry s position. These will allow
the industry’s rate of contraction to be moderated and include a regional grant
to support employment and improved redundancy terms for miners losing
their jobs. In addition certain payments are being made to promote sales of
coal to the electricity industry, towards the NCB’s coal and coke stocking
costs, and to producers of coking coal. Although the board is expected in
future to break even financially (after taking account of grants) provision is
made for an accumulated deficit up to £50 million, to be increased up to £100
million if necessary.
In the year ending March 1973 the NCB made an operating loss of 129
million.

The NCB has two research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; and a Mining Research and Development Establish¬
ment, near Bretby, Derbyshire, for the investigation of underground problems,
developing new machines and testing equipment.
Research associations receiving grants from the NCB and the Department
of Trade and Industry include the British Coke Research Association and the
Coal Tar Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as
the Safety in Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the
board’s problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires,
pneumoconiosis, engineering and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962. At present nearly all of Britain’s oil supplies are imported.
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea for natural gas and oil has been going on
since 1962 and full-scale exploration activities since 1964, following the enact¬
ment of the Continental Shelf Act 1964, and the subsequent award of a first
round of licences. Further licences were awarded in 1965, 1969-70 and 1971-
72. The total area now under licence is 43,415 square miles (112,444 square
kilometres) out of a total area, over which Britain has exercised its rights to
explore and exploit the seabed and subsoil, of 166,000 square miles (430,000
square kilometres).
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of five major fields
of natural gas in the British sector all of which are now in production (see
p. 283). Oil in significant quantities was first found in the British sector in
1970; development plans were announced for the Forties field in 1971, to
provide for output of 12-5 million tons a year by late 1975. First deliveries
through a 110-mile (177-kilometre) submarine pipeline are expected in late
1974. Several other major discoveries have been made including that of the
Auk and Argyll fields, planned to come into operation during 1974, and the
Brent and Piper fields to come into operation a year or two later.
A production rate of from 70 million to 100 million tons a year by 1980 has
been estimated. By the end of 1972 443 wells had been drilled, including 180
production wells.
Annual production of crude oil from land-based oilfields in Britain now totals
about 82,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the
establishment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Egmanton
and Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire (Gainsborough)
and in Dorset (Kimmeridge).
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today production by these companies amounts to about 17 per cent of total
world production and they operate a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and
partly on charter) amounting to over one-fifth of the world s tanker tonnage.
(British registered tanker tonnage is about 13 per cent of the worlds total.)
In 1972 Britain imported 102-9 million tons of crude oil valued at X9I4'9

million, the largest single item among imported products. Kuwait and Saudi
Arabia supplied approximately 20 per cent each, and Libya 14 per cent. Other
major suppliers were Iran, Nigeria and Venezuela.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption (excluding refinery
consumption) in 1972 totalled about 96 million tons, having more than doubled
since i960. Fuel oil consumption in 1972 constituted 42 per cent of the total.
Demand for gas and diesel oils (including derv fuel used in road vehicles) rose
by 2-6 million tons to over 20 million tons in 1972. Sales of motor spirit
expanded by nearly one million tons to 15-6 million tons in 1972.
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1972 were for non¬
industrial central heating, electricity generation, building and the railways.
Electricity generation accounted for 42 per cent of fuel oil consumption,
followed by the steel industry with 11 per cent; and non-industrial central
heating with a further 8 per cent. Of the remainder, the largest users were the
chemical, paper-making, glass, engineering and textile industries.
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economic to refine
at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry has
favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1972 rated refinery capacity in Britain amounted to 123 million
tons a year; capacity is expected to reach an estimated 145 million tons by the
end of 1975. Of the 21 refineries in operation, four have a capacity of under
0-5 million tons. The eleven largest are situated at Fawley, near Southampton
(10-5 million tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (10-5 million tons); Isle of Grain
(10-9 million tons), Shell Haven (10 million tons), and Coryton (7 million
tons), all three on the Thames Estuary; Teesport, Yorkshire (6 million tons);
Grangemouth, east Scotland (8-9 million tons); Milford Haven and Pembroke
in Pembrokeshire (6*3 million tons and 7 million tons); Llandarcy near
Swansea (8-2 million tons); and Killingholme near Grimsby (8-3 million tons).
Other important refineries are located at Belfast, Billingham, Heysham (Lancs.)
and second refineries at Killingholme and at Milford Haven. Stanlow is to be
expanded by 8 million tons. A new refinery has been completed at Milford
Haven; another is to be built at Canvey Island, Essex, and others are planned.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily to 98 million tons in 1972. There is a substantial external trade
in refined products which tends to follow trading and seasonal requirements
and the commercial arrangements of the major oil companies. Exports from
Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products to European countries, were
valued at £195 million in 1972. Imports of refined products (including liquefied
gases) amounted to ^220 million.
Three main crude oil pipelines are in operation in Britain between harbours
capable of berthing very large tankers and refineries: in west Scotland, from
Finnart to Grangemouth; in South Wales, from Angle Bay, Milford Haven,
to Llandarcy; and in north-west England, from Tranmere to Stanlow and
Heysham. A 131-mile (211-kilometre) pipeline is to be built from Cruden
Bay, Scotland, to Grangemouth, for oil from the Forties oil field in the North
Sea (see p. 245). Pipelines also carry refined products to major marketing
areas; for example, from the Humber to the Manchester area, from Fawley to
Staines and Heathrow Airport, and from the Isle of Grain to Walton-on-
Thames and Heathrow Airport. A 245-mile (394-kilometre) pipeline feeds
