refined products to north London and the Midlands from refineries and
installations on the Thames and Mersey; a similar line 265 miles (426 kilo¬
metres) long from Milford Haven to the Midlands and Manchester is under
construction. Pipelines carrying petrochemical feedstocks run from Stanlow to
Carrington, near Manchester, from Fawley to Severnside, near Bristol, and
from Teesside to Fleetwood and Runcorn. The Pipelines Act 1962 is designed
to secure the orderly development of privately owned industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at Godai¬
ming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has been a
feature of the industry. In 1919 the Electricity Commissioners were created as
a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a national scale through
voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity Board was set up to
construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting individual power
stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission. In 1943 the North of
Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was established as a public corpor¬
ation to develop the water-power resources of the Highlands. In 1948 all
municipal and private undertakings (other than those in Northern Ireland)
were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 and vested in the British Elec¬
tricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north of Scotland where
they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two subsequent Acts (1954
and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and gave the industry its
present structure. Electricity supply employs about 197,000 people, including
6,000 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate area
electricity boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland
these functions are carried out by the Northern Ireland Electricity Service.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with a
general responsibility for promoting electricity supply and for advising the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry; it is also responsible for a number of
common services, principally capital financing, research and industrial rela¬
tions. The council consists of a chairman and two deputy chairmen, the chair¬
man and two designated members of the CEGB, the chairmen of the 12 area
electricity boards and not more than three other members. The CEGB
controls the operation and maintenance of power stations and the main trans¬
mission system (the national grid) and supplies electricity in bulk to the 12
area boards. The CEGB consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and
278
Scotland
Northern Ireland
Generation
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
between six and eight members. Each of the 12 area electricity boards acquires
bulk supplies of electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for distribution
networks and sales of electricity to its area consumers.
Area consultative councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective area boards. The Secretary of State
for Trade and Industry appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members
of the Electricity Council, the CEGB, the area boards and the consultative
councils; approves each board’s capital development programmes and the
industry’s research programme; and approves, in consultation with the
Treasury, the industry’s borrowing requirements.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members, one of whom is
the chairman of the other board. The Secretary of State’s responsibilities in
relation to the boards are similar to those of the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry in England and Wales.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. The Northern Ireland Electricity Service
came into operation on 2nd April 1973. The new body is the result of the
amalgamation of four former electricity undertakings—the Northern Ireland
Joint Electricity Authority, the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland, and the
Electricity Departments of Belfast Corporation and Londonderry Develop¬
ment Commission. It has fixed assets valued at £ 165 million, a capital expen¬
diture programme for 1973-74 of £30 million and estimated sales for 1973-74
of £41 million; it serves 500,000 consumers. A Consumers’ Council has also
been set up.
As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. Hydro-electric development on any scale is comparatively
recent, water-power resources being relatively small and in remote areas.
Since 1965, nuclear energy has become increasingly important. Oil and natural
gas are also used.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1972 totalled 63,791 megawatts (MW) (see Table
27), an increase of 5 per cent on the previous year.
In the years 1965 to 1972 some 26,800 MW of generating capacity was com¬
missioned in England and Wales, including 3>00° MW in i972. The SSEB s
total capacity is to be increased to some 7,000 MW in 1974, and the NSHEB’s
to 2,140 MW by 1974.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 1,204 MW, 720 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 4,326-3 million kilowatt-hours
(kWh) in 1972.
Generation for the public supply in Great Britain reached nearly 238,000
million kilowatt-hours in 1972; conventional steam power stations provided
87 per cent of the total and nuclear and hydro-electric stations about 11 per
cent and 2 per cent respectively. A high rate of expansion of output has been
a feature of the industry since its earliest years; though the rate has slackened

Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively small
—19,719 million kWh in I972- The major sources outside the fuel industries
themselves are the chemical, iron and steel and paper industries and the
nuclear power plants of the Atomic Energy Authority.

The electricity authorities take over half the British consumption of coal and
about 18 per cent of the consumption of oil.
Oil-fired stations of 2,000 MW have been commissioned at Fawley, on
Southampton Water (one of the most fully automated stations in Europe), and
at Pembroke, South Wales, and others are under construction at Inverkip,
Renfrewshire (1,980 MW), Isle of Grain, Kent (3,300 MW) and Ince,
Cheshire (1,000 MW). Preparatory work on the site of another oil-fired station
at Peterhead, Aberdeenshire (1,320 MW) started in 1973.
A dual-fired station to burn either coal or oil has been commissioned at
Kingsnorth, Kent, and other stations involving some 4,000 MW of plant have
been or are being converted to dual-firing; two can burn natural gas. Average
thermal efficiency (that is, the ratio of the electrical energy output to the heat
energy input of the fuel consumed) of conventional steam stations in England
and Wales rose from 2075 per cent in 1947 to 29-32 per cent in 1972 as new
plant was brought into use. The 20 most efficient stations, containing much
of the newest plant, had an average thermal efficiency of 33-22 per cent in

Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
Forty-nine single-shaft units of 500 MW are being installed in 14 stations.
Station capacities are also increasing. Ten stations, each with capacities of
2,000 MW, with four 500 MW single-shaft generating units, are now in
service. Twenty-three 660 MW single-shaft generating units are on order for
installation: three for Drax, Yorkshire; five for Isle of Grain; three for Inver¬
kip: two for Peterhead; and two each for five nuclear power stations under
construction (for locations see map, p. 271). Units of 1,300 MW are under
consideration. A 2,400 MW station at Longannet, Fife, with four 600 MW
cross-compound units, was commissioned in 1970.

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 7° MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
SSEB have installed 916 MW of such units and a further 2,850 MW are
planned. Many others of 17 to 35 MW capacity are being used in new stations
to safeguard the auxiliary supplies to the large new steam units, and also to
provide capacity for peak operation. Auxiliary units of this kind in service at
the end of 1972 totalled 1,140 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is at present confined to Scotland and Wales. Most
of the water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their
own natural catchment areas. The setting up of the NSHEB in 1943 marked
the beginning of an era of intensive water-power development in the
Highlands.
In 1972-73> 2,908 million units were sent out by the NSHEB from water¬
power, compared with 322 million in 1949- At the end of March 1973 there
were 54 main hydro-electric conventional stations in operation in the north
of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,049 MW and the largest the
Loch Sloy station—has a capacity of 130 MW. The Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW from
four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the end of 1967.
(In pumped-storage schemes electricity generated in off-peak periods is used
to pump water to higher levels from which it descends at peak periods to
operate turbo-generators.)
Construction of a 300 MW pumped-storage project at Foyers, Loch Ness,
began in November 1969. It will have two 150 MW reversible-pump-turbines
and is planned for completion in 1974' addition, there are stations generat¬
ing electricity by water-power in the south of Scotland (123 MW) and in
Wales (469 MW). The latter includes the 360 MW pumped-storage station
at Ffestiniog. It is planned to build a 1,500 MW pumped-storage station at
Dinorwic, North Wales.
In 1972 nuclear power stations provided some 10 per cent of Britain’s elec¬
tricity generation for public supply and the proportion is likely to rise to about
one-seventh by the mid-1970s. Britain accounts for about 12 per cent of world
nuclear generation (excluding the Soviet Union). Since 1962 Britain has pro¬
duced over 240,000 gigawatt-hours of nuclear-generated electricity—much
more than any other country—and about 40 per cent of total world generation
from nuclear sources. _
Various stations make up the output. The original prototypes built by the
Atomic Energy Authority (AEA) at Calder Hall, Cumberland (198 MW) the
first in the world to operate on a commercial scale—and at Chapelcross,
Dumfriesshire (198 MW), are now owned and operated by British Nuclear
Fuels Ltd. (see p. 405). This company, one of two set up in 1970 to take over
the AEA’s trading function including the manufacture and reprocessing of
nuclear fuels in Britain and overseas, will be closely associated with the new
single company to be set up by the Government to design and construct steam
supply systems for nuclear power stations (see p. 405).
The AEA has at present three main stations which produce electricity for
the national grid: the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor (AGR) at Windscale,
Cumberland (14 MW electrical output); the experimental fast breeder station
at Dounreay, Caithness (14 MW); and the Steam Generating Heavy Water
Moderated Reactor (SGHWR) at Winfrith, Dorset (100 MW).
Most of Britain’s nuclear-generated electricity is, however, supplied by

and

281
stations owned and operated by the electricity authorities. These, like Calder
Hall and Chapelcross, are all magnox stations—graphite-moderated, carbon-
dioxide cooled, using natural uranium metal fuel elements canned in magne¬
sium alloy. Under the first commercial programme, originally announced in
1955 but since twice modified, nine magnox stations with a total design capacity
of 4,500 MW were in operation in 1972: Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276
MW design capacity), and Bradwell, in Essex (300 MW), were both com¬
missioned in 1962; Hunterston ‘A’, in Scotland (300 MW), in 1964; and in the
following year Hinkley Point ‘A’, in Somerset, Trawsfynydd, in Wales (both
500 MW), and Dungeness ‘A’, in Kent (550 MW); Sizewell, in Suffolk (580
MW), was commissioned in 1966; and Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW),
in 1968. A ninth station, Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180 MW), was commissioned
in 1971.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a
further 8,000 MW of nuclear capacity is planned of which about 6,500 MW
will be commissioned by 1976. The reactor design chosen for the programme
is based on the AGR at Windscale, a logical development of the magnox
system, which uses slightly enriched uranium dioxide fuel canned in stainless
steel. The first five AGR stations under construction are Dungeness ‘B’
(1,200 MW); and Hinkley Point ‘B’, Hunterston ‘B’, Hartlepool, County
Durham, and Heysham, Lancashire (each of 1,320 MW capacity). Further
stations are planned at Sizewell (1,320 MW) and at Portskewett (1,300 MW)
in Monmouthshire.
A large prototype fast reactor (PER) of 250 MW capacity is to be com¬
missioned by the AEA in 1973 at Dounreay (where in 1962 the experimental
fast reactor became the first of such type to produce electricity for public use
and to operate at a high power level). It is expected that the first full-scale order
for a Sodium Cooled Fast Reactor will be placed in the late 1970s, and that
from the mid-1980s a major part of nuclear orders will be for this type of
station.
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1972 those of the CEGB totalled over 8,000 circuit
miles (13,000 kilometres), of which 4,670 miles (7,515 kilometres) were at
400,000 volts, and 2,990 miles (4,811 kilometres) at 275,000 volts. Primary dis¬
tribution in England and Wales is at 132,000 volts, comprising 11,200 circuit
miles (18,000 kilometres) of lines, with secondary distribution at 33,000 volts,
tertiary at 11,000 volts and general low voltage distribution at 415/240 volts
(standardisation of supply to consumers at 240 volts is almost completed). In
Scotland there were some 4,903 circuit miles (7,890 kilometres) of main trans¬
mission lines at the end of March 1972, of which 1,752 circuit miles (2,823 kilo¬
metres) operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder at 132,000 volts. Primary
distribution in Scotland is at 33,000 volts. Energy movements on the grid in
England and Wales are controlled through the seven operational areas, set up
for that purpose and distinct from the regions in which the generating side of
the industry is organised; each area has a separate control, and the operations
are co-ordinated by a National Control in London. The grid in Scotland is
operated from the control centres at Pitlochry (NSHEB) and at Kirkintilloch
(SSEB).
The development of the grid system has made the British system the largest
fully interconnected power network under unified control in the world. Twin
cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable of
transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been in

operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the CEGB, supplemented from other sources,
such as industrial plants, and the nuclear power stations of the AEA. There
are 19 million consumers. Industrial concerns are the biggest users of elec¬
tricity. The principal domestic uses of electricity are for lighting, cooking and
for space and water heating, but the demand for numerous other domestic
purposes is rising steadily.
The NSHEB has about 488,000 consumers, many in remote areas. The
SSEB supplies more than 1*5 million consumers.
Some 5 per cent of Britain’s annual gross fixed capital formation in 1972 was
attributable to the electricity supply industry. The industry’s plans for new
capital investment are based on a growth in demand estimated at an annual
average rate of 5*4 per cent up to 1978-79.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from £249 million in 1956 it rose to £720 million in 1966 but has
since fallen to £400 million in 1972-73. About one-half of the industry’s
capital requirements has been financed from internal resources. The statutory
limit to borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is ^6,150 million, with
provision for extension to £7,700 million. The Gas and Electricity Act 1968
empowered the industry to borrow (long term) from overseas sources.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry, is responsible for drawing up a general programme of research,
comprising direct research carried out by the electricity boards themselves,
supported by co-operative research with selected industrial research associa¬
tions and by research contracts placed with universities and other organisations.
The council itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the
Electricity Supply Research Council. Collaboration on research between the
supply industry and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power
Engineering Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the CEGB and
comprise the Central Electricity Research Laboratories at Leatherhead,
Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Gloucestershire, concerned with nuclear
problems, and the Engineering Laboratories at Marchwood, on Southampton
Water. Research on distribution technology and electricity utilisation is under¬
taken at the Electricity Council Research Centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire, and
by the area boards.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
SSEB undertakes a wide range of research and development work, both in¬
dependently and in conjunction with the universities and manufacturers and,
with the NSHEB, is associated with the activities of the Electricity Council
and CEGB.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London, was
first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light and
Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London. In
the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting,
provided by a growing number of company and municipal undertakings.
The gas industry developed from a supplier mainly of lighting to a supplier

Structure
Production
Distribution
Consumption
283
mainly of heating during the period between the two world wars when in¬
creasing competition from electricity had to be met. It now supplies over 13^
million customers.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
115,000 people are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1 st May 1949. The industry’s structure was adapted under the Gas Act
1972 to take account of the change from manufactured to natural gas neces¬
sitating more centralised control of production and transmission. The British
Gas Corporation came into operation on 1st January 1973 taking the place of
the Gas Council, the former central co-ordinating body in the industry, and
assuming the responsibilities of the 12 area gas boards formerly carrying out
the local manufacture and the distribution of gas to consumers. Members of
the Corporation are appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry. In connection with its main duty of developing and maintaining an
efficient, co-ordinated and economical system of gas supply and of satisfying
reasonable demands for gas, it has powers: to search for and extract natural
gas and to extract any associated petroleum; to manufacture or acquire,
transmit and distribute gas; to manufacture, supply, or sell byproducts; and
to manufacture, install, maintain or remove gas plant and fittings.
A National Gas Consumers’ Council, and 12 Regional Gas Consumers’
Councils, have been set up to protect consumer interests.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The main single source of gas in Britain is now natural gas, supplied either
directly (over 70 per cent) or as feedstock for town gas manufacture, and
accounting for about 95 per cent of total demand.
The first productive well in the North Sea was discovered in 1965. Five
major gasfields have been located: Leman Bank, West Sole, Hewett, Inde¬
fatigable and Viking, all now in production. A number of smaller structures
have also been found and exploration continues.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in York¬
shire, was put on flow early in 1967. Since then further pipelines have been laid
to bring gas to the terminals at Bacton, Norfolk, and Theddlethorpe, Lincoln¬
shire. Natural gas accounts for about 11 per cent of total energy consumption.
During 1972 the aggregate quantity of gas available amounted to 11,171
million therms,1 an increase of 2,422 million therms (28 per cent) over the
previous year.
In 1972 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about 31-3
million therms, most of it for household use.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. The pipeline system then begun has been expanded to form a
national high-pressure pipeline system for distribution of natural gas derived
mainly from British fields in the North Sea. By March 1973 some 2,000 miles
(3,220 kilometres) of the required 2,500 miles (4,000 kilometres) had been
constructed. The central distribution system is fed from the two shore termi¬
nals by five feeder mains.
Just over half of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the re¬
mainder for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been

rising steadily since 1961, after a period when growth was almost negligible,
and is now doing so with increasing rapidity. It rose by 30-3 per cent in

About 45 per cent of the domestic load is used for central heating, with gas
fires and cookers accounting for a further 45 per cent. There are some 11
million gas cookers, 9^ million space heaters, million central heating instal¬
lations, over 3^ million water heaters, and over 1 million refrigerators.
Gas has traditionally been used extensively in industries which require the
control of temperatures to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery
industry and in certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products.
Natural gas is being used as a chemical feedstock and in bulk fuel markets. In
1972 sales of gas to industry totalled 4,278 million therms; they have risen
sharply since the arrival of natural gas.
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the area gas
boards was limited to £250 million. Since then the limit has been raised as
necessary. For the British Gas Corporation the borrowing limit has been fixed
by the Gas Act 1972 at £2,500 million, to be raised by order if necessary up
to £2,700 million. The Act also empowers the industry to borrow (long term)
from overseas sources.
The industry had been spending about £50 million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 to 1961 but since 1961-62 expenditure has
increased sharply. Capital needs over the four years to March 1975 afe estima¬
ted at over £1,200 million, of which the largest items are £531 million on bulk
transmission and distribution and £371 million on conversion to natural gas.
About half of the total is to be met from internal resources.
Much of the gas industry’s current research and development effort is con¬
centrated on transforming the industry from one based on manufactured
gas to one based on indigenous natural gas. In 1970 it was estimated that the
switch over to natural gas in Great Britain would be completed in seven to
eight years. . .
A phased programme of converting the 30 million gas appliances is in
progress. Some 60 per cent of consumers had had their appliances converted
at the end of March 1973. Investigations are being made into projects in¬
volving various methods of storage of natural gas to meet peak load conditions.
Liquefaction and storage facilities for natural gas have been constructed near
Coatbridge, Scotland, and other facilities are under construction or planned.
The British Gas Corporation has a research committee which advises on
research policy at four research centres. The engineering research station at
Killingworth, Northumberland, has concentrated on large-scale distribution
problems. Research is also done on behalf of the Corporation at a number of
universities and colleges. Work is being carried out on Corporation processes
for manufacture of substitute natural gas, in which there is wide interest
overseas, especially in areas where natural gas is running short. The Corpor¬
ation’s total expenditure on research, development and testing amounts to
£8-3 million a year.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.

285
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users on the
best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the operation of
solid fuel appliances.
The National Industrial Fuel Efficiency Service, originally formed in 1954
and sponsored by the fuel and power industries to promote fuel saving in
industry is now run by private enterprise. In addition to consultancy work, it
provides advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of
forms, from ‘spot’ inspection to full-scale surveys and regular visits on a
contract basis.
WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and dis¬
tribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as mountain
lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river intakes, and
partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and boreholes. A
major reorganisation of water services in England and Wales is due to come
into effect on 1st April 1974.
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
(a well-known social reformer) and his colleagues who demonstrated the
dangers arising from inadequate water supply and sanitation. The Public
Health Act 1848 laid the basis for a long series of statutes dealing with public
health. From the middle of the nineteenth century onwards a number of water
undertakings were set up to provide water to the expanding urban population,
and the water supply system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion
and with some overlapping and waste.
The householder receives his domestic water supply at a comparatively
small charge, varying in different areas, which he usually pays by way of a
water rate levied, like other rates, on the value of his house. Industrial users
are charged in most cases according to actual metered consumption.
The Water Resources Act 1963 (which came into full operation in April
1965) created an administrative structure for England and Wales consisting
of a number of river authorities and a central Water Resources Board to meet
growing domestic, industrial and farm irrigation needs.
Until April 1974 water supply is in the hands of over 1,400 separate bodies,
including: 22 river authorities in England, three lying across the Anglo-
Welsh border, and four in Wales; 180 water undertakers providing supplies of
piped water for domestic and other uses; and over 1,200 sewerage authorities,
which are mainly local authorities or in some cases joint boards of local
authorities. There are also nearly 2,000 miles (3,220 kilometres) of canals and
river navigation administered by the British Waterways Board (see p. 357).
Under the Water Act 1973, a radical reconstruction of the water services in
England and Wales will come into effect in April 1974 alongside the re¬
organisation of local government (see p. 67). Responsibility for promoting
jointly a national policy for water in England and Wales will rest with the
Secretaries of State for the Environment and for Wales and the Minister of
286
Water Authorities
National Water
Council
Supplies
Scotland
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. A Central Water Planning Unit of the
Department of the Environment will take over responsibility for national
planning studies from the Water Resources Board. A Water Space Amenity
Commission has been set up to advise on recreation and amenity in England.
The Act provides for the setting up of nine regional water authorities in
England and a Welsh National Water Development Authority in Wales. Each
water authority consists of a chairman appointed by the Secretary of State,
members appointed by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and a
majority of members appointed by local authorities. The functions of the
water authorities will include water conservation; water supply; sewerage and
sewage disposal; control of river pollution; maintenance, development and
improvement of fisheries; land drainage; and recreational amenities relating to
water.
Also under the Act a National Water Council has been set up consisting of a
chairman appointed by the Secretaries of State, the chairmen of the water
authorities and ten other members with special relevant knowledge, of whom
eight have been appointed by the Secretaries of State and two by the Minister
of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. The main function of the council is to
advise and assist ministers and water authorities.
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 99 per cent of
the total population—now total some 3,050 million gallons (13-9 million
cubic metres) a day, out of a total estimated abstraction of nearly 5,850 million
gallons (26-55 million cubic metres) a day (excluding water used for cooling
in connection with electricity generation). Capital expenditure on water
supply, sewerage and sewage disposal is estimated at £300 million in 1972-73;
an annual increase of 7 per cent in real terms is envisaged.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1971. By
March 1973 schemes costing over £132 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The administrative arrangements for water supply and distribution in Scotland
were reorganised by the Water (Scotland) Act 1967 under which the functions
of 200 local water authorities were transferred to 13 regional water boards in
May 1968. The Act also established the Central Scotland Water Development
Board which supplies water in bulk to its seven constituent regional water
boards; it does not supply direct to individual consumers. All the members of
these boards are members of town or county councils.
The water problem in Scotland is broadly similar to that in England and
Wales except that there is not the same need to allocate water between
competing interests and requirements are met almost entirely from surface
sources. The Secretary of State for Scotland is responsible for general over¬
sight and co-ordination and has a general duty to promote the conservation of
water resources in Scotland; and to require regional water boards to provide
supplies of wholesome water everywhere in their regions, where this can be
done at reasonable cost; at present, they supply over 98 per cent of the total
population. The Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the Secretary of
State on general questions relating to resources and supplies and the organisa¬
tion of the water service. The Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Act i944>
as amended, makes available to Scottish regional water boards and to local
authorities grant assistance up to a maximum of £60 million towards the cost
of water supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.

287
The 12 new regional and island councils to be set up in Scotland in 1975 to
carry out local government functions (see p. 69) are to be responsible for
water supply and sewerage; separate river purification authorities will con¬
tinue to be responsible for the regulation of the discharges of effluent to rivers
and certain tidal waters. The Central Scotland Water Development Board will
be reconstituted to carry out co-ordinating functions and administer water
schemes supplying more than one regional council in central Scotland.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. Over 90 per cent of the population has a piped supply.
Under the Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern Ireland) 1945 the
Ministry of Development may pay grants towards the cost of water schemes.
Since 1945 over £80 million has been invested—over ^40 million by way of
government grants. The Ministry of Development, already responsible for
water conservation and pollution control, took over from local authorities, in
April 1973, responsibility for water supply and sewerage services.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation’s water
resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain, and in
the Ground Water Year Book for England and Wales published annually by
Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. Detailed studies of the resources and use of
water in specified areas have been published in the series of hydrological
surveys which cover approximately half of England and Wales. General
information on rainfall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the res¬
ponsibility of the Meteorological Office. The Hydraulics Research Station
of the Department of the Environment at Wallingford and the Water Research
Association’s station at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the
design and calibration of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of
surface water, and into other hydraulic problems.
A Water Research Centre is to be set up to co-ordinate research in the
whole of Britain.
Barrage projects involve dams across or within tidal estuaries to form a lake
of fresh water, and studies have been carried out for several estuaries in
Britain. A report on a study for Morecambe Bay, Lancashire, published early
in 1972, put forward several suggested schemes, including a barrage and storage
reservoirs. A three-year survey is being carried out into plans for the Wash,
and a report has been published on the estuary of the Dee.
At present each river authority is responsible for the control of pollution of
rivers and certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before
polluting effluents are discharged. These responsibilities will pass to the
regional water authorities in April 1974, and new legislation on control of
pollution is projected.
The Government’s aim is to improve the quality of water in all the main
rivers by the early 1980s. According to the River Pollution Survey (see
Bibliography p. 478) much progress has already been made in diminishing
river pollution in recent years.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment and
disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and prevention
of pollution of surface water and underground water.

CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction, altera¬
tion, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage and
sewerage systems, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence works, electrical
wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal prospecting and
mining, and structural work connected with thermal and hydroelectric power
stations and telecommunications. About i-8 million people are engaged on
construction, including the self-employed. They represent some 7 Per cent of
the total civilian labour force. Nearly a quarter are employed in the public
sector. The construction industry accounts for about 12 per cent of the total
industrial product. A quarter of output consists of maintainance work, and
about half of all work is commissioned by public authorities.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities which employ their own labour. About five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are over 66,000 firms employing two or
more people over 90 per cent of them employ fewer than 25 people.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 240,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance, valued
at over £1,500 million annually. The total labour force includes about 700,000
skilled craftsmen, most of whom have been trained for four or five years under
the industry’s apprenticeship schemes. A further 72,000 are employed as
apprentices.
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.
The Department of the Environment (see p. 52) is responsible for the
construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government (except for
health and education projects), including work for the armed services, both at
home and overseas. It is also responsible for co-ordinating research and
development throughout the government service and seeks to influence
methods and techniques in the building industry as a whole. A Property
Services Agency was set up within the department in 1972 to deal with the
Government’s property and building functions.
The value of work done in 1972 amounted to £6,088 million, of which £699
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £5,389
million (£4,284 million on new work and £1,105 million on repair work).
Some 350,432 houses were started in 1972 and 319,097 were completed,
of which 196,270 were for private owners. Of the £1,423 million of new
housing carried out by private contractors, £851 million, or over half, was
for private owners and the remainder for public authorities. Industrialised
building methods employing prefabricated components are used in much of
the work.

289
The National Building Agency is an independent advisory body, managed
by a board of directors appointed by the Department of the Environment and
the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and at present financed by a
government grant and the fees which it earns. Fee income has increased
rapidly, and the grant is to end by April 1974. Its main function is to encourage
the adoption of advanced methods of house building, and to provide technical
advice and services to government departments, local authorities and other
clients.
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in Britain in 1973 were
several major conventional power stations and nuclear power stations (see p.
280), dams and reservoirs, hospitals, large-scale housing developments, a
3^10 million office and shop development in Victoria Street, London, a £22
million scheme to extend the London underground railway system to London
Airport (Heathrow) and the first stage of the new Fleet underground line
across London. Projects for road construction, bridges and tunnels included
about 235 miles (378 kilometres) of motorways under construction in England
alone (see p. 351), and the ^28 million second Mersey Tunnel scheme of which
the first of two tunnels was opened in 1971.
Among important construction projects being undertaken by British con¬
tractors in overseas countries during 1973 were: a ^50 million dry dock and
ship-repairing scheme in Dubai; road schemes in many areas; a j£io million
governmental buildings scheme in Nigeria; work at the Chambishi copper
mine in Zambia; a ^13*5 million contract to extend and modernise an oil
refinery in Belgium; and an ^8 million pipeline scheme in the Soviet Union.
Recently the value of new overseas contracts obtained by British construction
firms, in a large number of different countries, has been running at about £300
million a year. A substantial and growing amount of overseas business is also
being done by British architects and surveyors, as well as by other types of
consultant. British members of the Association of Consulting Engineers had
projects worth about £3,784 million in hand on 1st January 1973, bringing in
some £50 million net in invisible export earnings.
The Directorate-General of Research in the Department of the Environment
works closely with the building industry on many aspects of construction
research. The Building Research Establishment which forms part of the
department includes the Building Research Station originally set up in 1921,
when Britain was the pioneer of organised building research; it is concerned
with all aspects of building and provides a technical advisory service for
construction firms. An Agrement Board, set up by the Government, tests and
certifies new products and methods.
The construction industry is served by several of the industrial research
associations. The Construction Industry Research and Information Associa¬
tion is concerned with structural design, civil engineering construction, build¬
ing design and construction, earthworks and foundations, hydraulic and public
290

MANUFACTURE
Iron and Steel
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
health engineering, and underwater engineering. The Heating and Ventilating
Research Association deals with heating and air-conditioning in dwellings and
commercial buildings. The application of materials is the main concern of the
Timber Research and Development Association and the Cement and Concrete
Association. Other research associations deal with bricks, paint, plastics in
building, welding and civil engineering hydraulics. The major construction
firms have research departments working on plant, materials and methods.
Other bodies concerned with research include the universities and colleges of
technology. Most of the producers of primary building materials have trade
associations which maintain research institutions chiefly devoted to seeking
new and more efficient use for their materials.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many of
which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by nearly
one-third since 1963; output per head advanced by 7-6 per cent in 1972
bringing the rise since 1963 to 41 per cent. In 1972 the manufacturing sector’s
fixed capital expenditure totalled £1,775 million (at 1970 prices), 75 per cent of
which was spent on plant and machinery. The number of employees in manu¬
facturing industry (including the unemployed and those absent from work
through sickness and other causes, but excluding employers and the self-
employed) was 7-6 million in June 1972, 35 per cent of the total number of
employees. . m . • j-
The employment and production figures listed in Table 28 give an indica¬
tion of the relative importance of broad sectors of manufacturing industry.
Expansion has been particularly marked in those industries utilising advanced
technologies such as electronics, the newer branches of mechanical engineer¬
ing, instrument engineering, most sectors of the chemical industry and man¬
made fibres. In the subsequent sections, employment statistics refer to numbers
in Great Britain at June 1972, output figures are taken from the latest avadable
Business Monitor (see p. 262) and export figures from the Overseas Trade
Statistics of the United Kingdom. Some production figures are given in metric
terms, where statistics for an industry are published in this form. Conversion
tables are on p. 463.
The metal manufacturing industries employ 515,000 persons. Of these,
250,000 are in the iron and steel industry, and 86,000 in the manufacture ol
iron castings, 52,400 in the manufacture of aluminium and aluminium alloys,
and 63,800 in the copper, brass and other base metal industries. Exports of
iron and steel products and non-ferrous metals in 1972 had an aggregate value
of £724 million.
Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking in
the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world s fifth
largest steel producing nation.
Output of crude steel in 1972 totalled 25-3 million ingot tonnes, 5 per cent
more than in 1971. Pig iron production in 1972 totalled 15-3 million tonnes.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 21*2 million tonnes in 1972. ihe
4-8 million tonnes of iron and steel products which were exported were worth
INDUSTRY
29I
£377 million; the United States (^72-3 million), India (^26 million) and Spain
(£24-4 million) were the main overseas buyers.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public super¬
vision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967 brought into public ownership
13 major steel companies together producing well over 90 per cent of Britain’s
crude steel and employing some 70 per cent of the manpower in the industry.
Their shares and securities were vested in July 1967 in the British Steel
Corporation (BSC), whose specific duties include promoting the efficient and
economic supply of iron and steel products, exports and research and develop¬
ment; it is also statutorily responsible for the finances of the nationalised
industry. In March 1970, the BSC was reorganised on the basis of four
product divisions covering iron and steel and two covering constructional
engineering and chemicals. The two latter divisions have since been converted
into wholly owned subsidiary companies of the Corporation.
The main producing districts are: Wales (34 per cent of total crude steel
output); Yorkshire and Humberside (24 per cent); Northern (16 per cent);
and Scotland (12 per cent). Wales concentrates mainly on the manufacture
of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the output of the north-east
coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel products (plates, sections
and rails), but a wide strip mill for sheet production is also in operation in

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Scotland. Production of special alloy and stainless steels is centred on Sheffield,
while Scunthorpe concentrates on heavy and medium products. The emphasis
in investment has been on improving efficiency rather than raising total
capacity and Britain has some of the most modern plant in Europe. Between
i960 and 1972 steel production by the basic oxygen steelmaking process
increased from 6 per cent of output to 44 per cent; by electric furnaces from
7 per cent to 19 per cent, while the share from older open-hearth processes
fell from 84 per cent to 37 per cent. Output per blast furnace has risen
markedly in recent years through improvements in efficiency, such as better
preparation of raw materials and the injection of oil and gas both to save
expensive metallurgical coke and to increase blast temperatures and by
improvements to blast furnace design. Outstanding development projects
completed in the last few years include a large-scale basic oxygen steelmaking
plant and a deepwater harbour/ore terminal at Port Talbot, and a basic
oxygen plant at Lackenby, Teesside. A major new steelmaking and finishing
complex at Scunthorpe was ready to commence operations early in 1973 74"
In December 1972 the Government approved a ten-year strategy by BSC
for the modernisation and expansion of its activities. This entails an invest¬
ment programme of £3,000 million (Cmnd 5226, see Bibliography, p. 478).
Expansion will take place at five existing sites—two in Wales at Llanwern and
Port Talbot, one at Ravenscraig in Scotland, one at Scunthorpe and one at
south Teesside where a new steelmaking complex will be constructed and the
existing Lackenby works expanded.
Total annual research and development expenditure by the industry is
about £14 million, most of which is incurred by BSC in its divisional and
corporate laboratories.
On 30th April 1973 the BSC adopted the European Coal and Steel Com¬
munity pricing system, under which the final price reflects differences in
transport costs from ‘basing points’ which vary according to product, through¬
out the country, and at which flat-rate prices, excluding transport costs, apply.
Some 800 foundries are engaged in the production of iron castings. Output
of castings in 1972—3-28 million tonnes—was 2 per cent less than in 1971.
The main users of iron castings are the motor vehicle industry, accounting for
nearly one-third of the total tonnage sold, the general engineering industry, the
manufacturers of pressure pipes and fittings, the building and associated
industries and the steel industry. Exports are included in the total for iron and
steel in the previous section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among Western countries. Output in 1972 included: aluminium, 171,480
tonnes of virgin metal and 184,800 tonnes of unwrought alloys; refined
copper, 49,200 tonnes of virgin copper and 130,800 tonnes of secondary metal;
lead, 159,760 tonnes; zinc, 74,200 tonnes of slab metal; and tin, 26,200 tonnes.
Mining in Britain is confined to the small-scale working of tin; three mines are
operating in Cornwall, and the possibility of reopening several more is being
evaluated. Selective grants to encourage exploration for a range of minerals in
Britain have been introduced by the Government.
In 1972 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at £347 million.
The main products exported, including alloys and semi-finished products,
were copper (£8i-8 million), nickel (£57-2 million), aluminium (^35-
million) and lead (£18-8 million). The Federal Republic of Germany (£44-

Agricultural

million), the United States (£44 million), and Switzerland (£32-5 million)
were the largest purchasing countries. Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres in¬
clude south Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth, where one of the
world’s largest zinc smelters (capacity 120,000 tons a year) was opened in
1968. Firms are engaged in smelting, casting and fabrication by rolling,
extrusion and drawing and the techniques of powder metallurgy and pressure
diecasting are also employed.
Two of the three major aluminium smelters whose construction was
approved by the Government in 1968 are now operational. When the three
smelters are in full production by 1974 they will provide over half of Britain’s
requirements for aluminium.
Britain is also a major producer of the newer specialised metals including
uranium, zirconium and beryllium for the nuclear energy industry; niobium
for aircraft production; and selenium, silicon, germanium and tantalum for
electronic apparatus. Scientific and technological research for the industry as a
whole is conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering, employing some 963,800 people, comprises a family
of industries including all types of machinery, machine tools, industrial
engines, mechanical handling equipment, construction equipment, industrial
plant, and ordnance and small arms. Vehicle engines are included in the section
on vehicles (p. 299). The aggregate value of the main products of all sections
other than small arms was about £4,590 million in 1972. Exports of non¬
electric machinery were valued at £2,054 million in 1972.
There are over 400 firms, employing 25,800 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including six large firms employing well over 1,500 workers.
In 1972 deliveries were valued at £77 million and exports were worth £45 •!
million; the main overseas markets were the Irish Republic, France, the
United States, the Federal Republic of Germany and South Africa.
The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters, pick¬
up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1972 included 5,666 combine harvesters, 4,792 milking machines,
and 854 grain and grass driers.
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry. The industry’s
output today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to
machines weighing hundreds of tons, and to numerically controlled machine
tools giving accuracies of one-ten-thousandth part of an inch. Almost 4,000
numerically controlled machine tools have been installed in Britain. The
Government, through the Department of Trade and Industry, is assisting the
industry in various ways, including a pre-production order scheme, and the
placing of research and development contracts.
The pattern of machine tool production is highly cyclical; deliveries in 1972
were valued at £162 million, including numerically controlled tools worth
£n-6 million. Exports of complete machines in 1972 had a value of £83-5
million, and of the orders on hand at the end of 1972 (£99‘2 million), 43 per
cent were for export; the Soviet Union (£8-9 million), France (£7-6 million),
United States (£6*i million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£5-6 million)
and Australia (£4-9 million) were the main overseas markets in 1972. The
seven major groupings in the industry’s 200 or so companies provide about
half of total deliveries, although because of the high degree of specialisation
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
small firms are numerically predominant. Centred mainly in London, the
Midlands, Yorkshire and Lancashire, the industry employs about 67,500
people.
The Machine Tool Trades Association is the representative body of most
manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the international machine
tool exhibition held in Britain every four years, the next being due in 1976.
The industry is served by its own research body, the Machine Tool Industry
Research Association.
Pumps, Valves
and
Compressors
Industrial pumps and valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are
vital components in many industrial processes particularly in the chemicals,
oil and electric power industries. The total work force is some 79,000 and
there are 450 companies of which ten employ more than 1,000 people. In 1972
deliveries of pumps and valves were estimated at £170 million and those of air
and gas compressors and fluid power equipment at £52 million and £62
million respectively. Exports of all types of equipment were an estimated £170
million.
Industrial Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of internal
Engines combustion engines (including parts) had a value of £142 million in 1972
and exports (including parts and marine engines) were worth £61-1 million.
The brake horse-power of the internal combustion engines produced ranges
in size from under 3 b.h.p. to over 4,000 b.h.p. Production is concentrated
among the large firms in the industry, and a total of 27,800 people are employed.
Textile The textile machinery industry produces machines and accessories for the
Machinery and manufacture and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of natural and
Accessories man-made fibres. Comprising about 500 firms, four of which account tor
more than one-half of the total output, the industry has some 35,800 employ¬
ees and is situated mainly in Lancashire, Yorkshire, Northern Ireland,
Leicester and Nottingham. In 1972, the industry’s exports (£i39-6 million)
accounted for roughly two-thirds of total deliveries. Principal markets were the
United States {£27-6 million), the EEC (£23-4 million), the Commonwealth
(j£22'i million) and South America (j£i6*3 million).
Construction and
Earth-moving
Equipment
Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
produced, including crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers, dozer
equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing, pulveris¬
ing and screening plant. The labour force numbers 36,600.
The value of deliveries from the industry was £307 million in 1972 of which
/150 million was for export; earth-moving machinery accounted for 80 per
cent of total deliveries. France, Spain and Australia are important markets.
Mechanical
Handling
Equipment
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment, which
extends from individual units and accessories to complete operating systems.
The value of deliveries in 1972 was some £289 million, the main products
being cranes and bridge transporters, lifts, escalators, conveyors, elevators,
hoists and powered industrial trucks. Exports of mechanical handling eclulP-
ment (including industrial and works trucks) in 1972 were valued at £76
million. There are some 640 firms in the industry, four-fifths of which have
fewer than 100 employees; the labour force totals 61,200.

The office machinery industry comprises some 70 firms, 11 of which account
for about three-quarters of total output. Deliveries have been expanding
rapidly and in 1972 were valued at £127-2 million (excluding computers and
copiers). Exports of all office machinery (including electronic computers and
data processing equipment) were valued at £203-4 million. The most important
overseas purchasers were the Federal Republic of Germany (£35-5 million),
France (£31-6 million) and the United States (£21-6 million). British sub¬
sidiaries or associates of overseas firms are prominent in some sectors of the
industry. There are 30,400 persons employed.
British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork and in 1972 the estimated value of equipment deliveries was £500
million, of which £95 million was for overseas markets. Of particular impor¬
tance are chemical and oil refining (process) plant, steam-raising boilers,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, lime and cement kilns,
nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and fabricated steelwork
for bridges, buildings, and industrial installations. The industry, comprising
both equipment manufacturers and plant contractors, has many large-scale
enterprises, including nine with over 2,000 workers, and in all employs 167,100
people.
British companies delivered shell boilers and other boilerhouse plant to the
value of £108 million in 1972. Water tube boilers of advanced design and of
large steam-raising capacity are produced for power stations, whereas shell
boilers are used for steam-raising and heating in factories and buildings.
Exports of steam generating boilers in 1972 amounted to £io-i million, and of
boilerhouse plant to £10-9 million.
The steelworks plant industry, in association with firms producing rolling
mills, provides almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1972 was £143 million. This industry consists of a
small number of firms, which often collaborate or form temporary consortia
to carry out particular projects. Finland, South Africa, Canada and Brazil
are a few of the countries in which British firms have undertaken major plant
projects.
The design, engineering, construction and commissioning of complete process
plants for the chemical, petrochemical, oil refining and gas industries has
expanded rapidly in recent years. There are now 30 process plant contracting
groups in Britain, half of which are United States subsidiaries. In 1972 expen¬
diture on plant in Britain by the process industries amounted to £200 million
and export contracts were worth an additional £100 million.
In March 1973 the Government announced that a new £10 million single
British nuclear reactor construction company was to be formed to replace the
two consortia formed in 1968 for this purpose. The largest British electrical
engineering company holds 50 per cent of the capital, members of the two
existing consortia have been given the opportunity to buy into a separate
organisation to hold 35 per cent and the remaining 15 per cent is held by the
Government through the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (see
p. 405).
A wide range of specialised equipment for industrial plant is produced.
Deliveries in 1972, valued at some £112-2 million, included distillation

In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in the preceding
section there are about 2,200 enterprises whose principal product is a type
of machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery (deliveries worth £106 million in 1972); printing, bookbinding
and paper goods machinery (^67 million); non-domestic refrigerating
machinery (£44-4 million); space-heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment (^151 million); food and drink machinery (^66 million), and
miscellaneous machinery (some ^43° million). There are some 229,700 workers
employed in these industries.
Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are about 4,900 enterprises, employing 185,600 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting, fabricating and repair work.
(Some enterprises are included because the mixed character of their work pre¬
cludes their classification under any single industry.) The sector includes ten
large undertakings with more than 2,000 employees. Ball and roller bearings,
and chains, are important products; exports of the former were valued at
£26-3 million in 1972 and exports of chains at ^9-2 million.
With a product range extending from scientific instruments to photographic
equipment and timepieces, instrument engineering is an important sector of
the engineering industry. Aggregate output was valued in 1972 at some £522
million and has increased, in volume terms, by 50 per cent since 1963* In a^>
some 155,700 people are employed in this sector.
The scientific and industrial instruments industry has a labour force number¬
ing 101,200. Deliveries of scientific instruments in 1972 some ^34^ million
—comprised: optical instruments, £29 million; electronic instruments, ^159
million; and non-electronic instruments, ^158 million.
Exports of scientific instruments have risen from ^27-9 million in i960 to
£145-1 million in 1972. In addition to various government research labora¬
tories the Sira Institute conducts research on behalf of the industry.
Deliveries of photographic, cinematographic and document copying equip¬
ment in 1972 totalled £68-8 million, and exports totalled £74 million.
The present industry has largely developed since the 1940s. It employs 13,300
people, and many of its factories are located on new industrial estates in the
older industrial areas, particularly in Scotland. Output in 1972 included
watches (£16-7 million), clocks (£io-6 million) and time recorders and parking
meters (£i-3 million); export sales, including parts, were valued at £16-4
million.
The electrical engineering industry, with a labour force of 780,400, is engaged
in the manufacture and installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment,
including all types of generating, transmission and distribution equipment;
motors; telecommunications and broadcasting apparatus, television and radio
receivers; computers; specialised electronic equipment; and domestic appli¬
ances. The volume of output has risen by 77 per cent since 1963 and the total
value of production in 1972 was estimated at almost £3,300 million.

Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1972 were
valued at ^662 million. Products are exported to all parts of the world; in 1972
South Africa (^42-6 million), the United States (3£39,2 million), the Federal
Republic of Germany (£38-9 million), France (£29-5 million) and Australia
(^29-1 million) were the main markets.
The industry’s leading representative organisations are the British Electrical
and Allied Manufacturers’ Association and the Electronic Engineering Associ¬
ation ; industry-wide scientific and technological research is carried out by the
Electrical Research Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today.
In 1972 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at £527 million,
comprising £92 million worth of generating equipment, ^49 million worth
of transformers, ^177 million worth of switchgear and control gear and
£209 million worth of other electrical machinery, including electric motors.
Exports of electric power machinery (generators, motors, converters, trans¬
formers and rectifiers) amounted to ^94’2 million in 1972, the main purchasers
being Australia (£7-7 million), Canada (^7-4 million) and South Africa
(^7-2 million). Switchgear, starting and control gear exports were valued at
£69-2 million.
Almost 570 firms manufacture electrical machinery, but recent mergers
have led to the creation of one of the leading electrical engineering groups in
Europe, while a number of smaller firms have been reorganised into larger
units. The total labour force numbers 136,500. Manufacture takes place in
many areas, including Birmingham, Manchester, Rugby, Tyneside and
Stafford.
The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its pro¬
ducts include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of
materials. It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the expanding output
of electric power in Britain (see p. 281). The value of deliveries in 1972 was
£315 million. Exports of electric cables, wires, and similar products, were
worth ^46-9 million; the main purchasers were Hong Kong and South Africa.
Most of the industry’s labour force of 44,900 are employed in five major
groups.
Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1972 included domestic electrical
appliances, £327 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles and air¬
craft, £167 million; batteries and accumulators, £110 million; electric lamps,
j£6i million; and miscellaneous electrical goods, ^113 million. In terms of
volume, deliveries included: 0-9 million electric blankets, 2-5 million vacuum
cleaners, 1-2 million domestic washing machines and 2-1 million electric irons.
In 1972 exports of domestic electrical equipment were valued at ^52-5 million,
including washing machines and parts (^12-7 million), space heating equip¬
ment (£13'2 million) and vacuum cleaners (^9-i million); the main markets
were the Federal Republic of Germany and the Irish Republic. Exports of

batteries and accumulators in 1972 were valued at ^177 million. The industry
has a labour force of 196,600.
Electronic Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
and Radio British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
Equipment basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, which made amplifi¬
cation possible, the development of radar, the first public transmission tele¬
vision service, and the ‘printed circuit’, which has led to far-reaching changes
in the radio industry. Total deliveries in 1972, valued at £1,665 million, were
207 per cent up on 1971; export deliveries totalled £400 million. The industry
employs 317,500 people.
Capital Equipment Deliveries of electronic capital equipment in 1972 were valued at £658 million
(39 per cent of total output), including £248 million for export. (Indirect
exports incorporated in ships, aircraft and machinery are not included in this
figure but are also considerable.) Computers are the most important item of
capital equipment; the computer equipment industries include a number of
plants owned by United States multi-national, as well as British-owned,
companies. Output and export figures in 1972 were the highest yet recorded.
Total deliveries were valued at £246 million in 1972 and exports at £102
million.
Deliveries of radar and navigational aids were valued at £114 million in
1972, over six times the i960 level, and over one-third of total output was ex¬
ported. Three-quarters of the world’s radar-fitted merchant ships use British
equipment, as do most of the world’s civil airports outside the American
continent. All-weather landing systems, inertial (automatic) navigation
systems and marine radar based on solid-state electronics are among recent
developments. Other important items of capital equipment include electronic
control equipment (£93 million), radio communications equipment (£75
million) and electronic measuring and testing equipment (£48 million).
Components Deliveries of components (£345 million in 1972) comprised active components
at £177 million and passive components at £168 million. The industry s
increasing emphasis on miniaturisation has led to the replacement of conven¬
tional valves by transistors, and this development has led to microcircuits in
which large numbers of individual circuits are accommodated on a single
small slice of silicon.
Consumer Goods The consumer goods sector of the industry manufactures radio and television
sets, audio equipment, radiograms and tape recorders. The industry is
dominated by several large firms. Output of television sets in 1972 rose to
3 million (including 1-5 million colour television sets compared with 830,000
in 1971). Production of radios and radiograms numbered 1*9 million in 1972
and total sales were worth £31 million: the value of production of stereo
systems, estimated at £500,000 in 1971, has been doubling annually. Deliveries
of tape recorders amounted to over 446,000 worth nearly £6 million.
Telecommunications Only a part of the telecommunications industry is concerned with electronic
equipment, but it is normally considered as a sector of the electronics industry.
The degree of involvement in electronics is, however, increasing and will con¬
tinue to do so with the advent of new switching systems. Britain is a major
exporter of telegraph and telephone equipment with overseas sales valued in
1972 at £49 million. Research and development work is done by firms in the
industry in co-operation with the Post Office. The industry employs 84,900
people, and three firms are responsible for almost all the output.

The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft are an important
source of overseas earnings; exports of transport equipment in 1972, valued
at £1,300 million, formed some 13 per cent of total exports. The labour force
numbers 952,500 and includes: 487,700 in motor vehicle manufacture,
201,000 in aerospace construction and repairing, 176,900 in shipbuilding and
marine engineering, 43,200 in the manufacture of locomotives and railway
wagons and carriages, 26,500 in wheeled tractor manufacturing and 17,200 in
the making of cycles and motor cycles.
The largest section of the vehicle industry comprises the manufacture of cars
and commercial vehicles.
At one time located mainly in the Midlands and the London area, the in¬
dustry, during the last decade, has built manufacturing and assembly plants on
Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the four largest firms—
British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ford, Chrysler United Kingdom and
Vauxhall—which account for over 95 per cent of complete vehicle production;
the balance is in the hands of smaller, specialist producers of heavy com¬
mercial vehicles, omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal
trade association is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, which
holds a motor show annually in London and a commercial vehicle exhibition
every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association carries out collec¬
tive research on vehicles and components.
Output of passenger cars in 1972 totalled 1*92 million units, compared with
1-74 million units in 1971. Exports in 1972 amounted to 630,000 cars valued
at £332 million. The United States (£65 million) was again the largest single
purchaser, followed by Belgium (£26*7 million), Canada, Iran and New
Zealand.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis, totalled 408,000 in 1972.
Exports in 1972 of new commercial vehicles (including chassis) numbered
150,000 worth £189 million. South Africa (£16 million), Nigeria (£11 million),
Australia and the Irish Republic were the main markets. Since 1961 Britain
has been one of the world’s largest exporters of commercial vehicles. The pro¬
totype of a gas-turbine-powered commercial vehicle is being evaluated.
Prototype battery electric buses are being evaluated in public service.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles, including
bodies, chassis and engines, had a value of some £375 million in 1972; caravan
and trailer exports totalled £28-9 million.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 134,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
1972, 103,000 (77 per cent) for export. Exports of new agricultural and track¬
laying tractors were valued at £145*9 million in 1972; South Africa (£13*9
million), the United States (£8*2 million), Canada (£7 million), Finland
(£6-6 million), Australia (£67 million) and Denmark (£67 million) were the
main buyers. Production is dominated by two large organisations. Britain has
one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world (see p. 323).
Sales of bicycles amounted in 1972 to 2 million. Most of British manufactur¬
ing capacity is in the hands of a single group of companies concentrated in the
Nottingham area. Some 1 -i million cycles worth £17*9 million were sent over¬
seas in 1972; the United States (£87 million) was the largest single market.
