BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Sales of motor cycles in 1972 amounted to 44,100. Manufacture is dominated
by one large group. Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled £20-6 million in
1972, with the United States (£147 million) much the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomo¬
tives, carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for
export.
The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in 1972 was £22-5
million; Malaysia, South Africa and Kenya were the largest purchasers.
The turnover of the aerospace industry totalled £988 million in I972, terms
of sales to final buyers, output in 1972 was valued at some ^672 million; about
41 per cent of this was accounted for by complete aircraft and airframe parts,
about 43 per cent by engines and parts and some 15 per cent by guided
weapons and space activities. The most notable turbo-prop aircraft in current
production and operation is the Hawker Siddeley °f which over 270 have
been sold or are on order. A second generation of jet airliners, the medium-
haul Trident and the BAG One-Eleven, the world’s first jet transport designed
to operate economically on short-haul routes, have been in service for over
eight years. Other civil aircraft in production include the HS125 executive
jet, the Skyvan all-purpose light transport, the luxury commuter version, the
Skyliner, and the Islander and Trilander, economical feeder-line aircraft.
Flight trials of the Concorde, the western world’s first supersonic airliner,
developed jointly by Britain and France, are at an advanced stage.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft, including the
Jaguar, in collaboration with France, and the Harrier vertical take-off strike
aircraft, 90 of which have been ordered for the United States Marine Corps.
Britain, the Federal Republic of Germany and Italy are jointly developing a
supersonic multi-role combat aircraft (MRCA) to meet the needs of their aii
forces during the late 1970s and 1980s. The industry is producing or has under
development about 18 types of guided missile for use by the armed services
of Britain and several overseas countries. Its space activities include sounding
rockets, scientific and communications satellites and work on the United
States programme to develop a space shuttle craft.
Hovercraft, a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being
increasingly used throughout the world. Britain has built a number of types,
including the 190-ton SRN4 which now carries over 20 per cent of cross-
Channel passengers and car traffic. Military craft are in service particularly in
the Middle East.
In 1972 exports of the aerospace industry totalled £418 million. Exports of
new aircraft and parts in 1972 (excluding electrical equipment) had a value of
£1927 million, 19 per cent more than in I971, Leading buyers included
France (^39’2 million) and the United States.
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers and one helicopter concern; outside these groups are a few important
smaller companies. Besides extensive research work by the industry, research
on a substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their engines is carried out
by the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft Establishment and the
National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farnborough, and the Royal
Aircraft Establishment at Bedford. The industry has over 50 collaborative
agreements with overseas governments and companies.
Exports of aero-engines and parts have provided well over ^1,300 million in

Shipbuilding

Merchant

Marine

overseas earnings since 1946, and in 1972 were valued at £191‘5 million, 36
per cent more than in 1971: major customers were the United States (^78-8
million), France (^267 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany
(£15-6 million). More than 12 different types of British jet engines power
aircraft currently in production overseas. Famous engines include the econo¬
mical Dart turbo-prop, the Spey turbo-fan, the revolutionary Pegasus lift-
thrust engine for vertical take-off and landing (VTOL) aircraft, and the
Olympus, the power plant for the Concorde and the advanced technology
RB211 which powers the Lockheed Tristar.
Almost all of Britain’s aero-engine manufacture is in the hands of Rolls-
Royce (1971) Ltd., a publicly owned company, to which the essential assets of
Rolls-Royce Ltd. were transferred in May 1971.
The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main areas:
the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of England
and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast build
smaller vessels such as naval ships, fishing vessels, yachts and harbour
craft.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters on the
river Tyne.
Since the publication in 1966 of the report of the Shipbuilding Enquiry
Committee, many British shipyards have embarked on programmes of
modernisation and reorganisation. In many cases this was facilitated by
assistance from the Shipbuilding Industry Board (SIB) which was in operation
from 1967 to 1971. Shipyard modernisation has been paralleled by major
structural changes. A series of mergers has led to the creation of two major
groups on Clydeside (one of which has been reorganised following its liquida¬
tion), three in north-east England, one in eastern Scotland and one in southern
England. Together with one firm on the River Mersey and one in Belfast—
where the world’s largest building dock is now operational—they accounted
in 1972 for more than nine-tenths by gross tonnage of the industry’s new
orders for merchant vessels.
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1-5 million gross tons
was halted in 1964, and launchings in 1972 totalled 1-24 million gross tons.
British launchings were the fourth largest in the world in 1972 accounting for
4-6 per cent of the world total. Thirteen oil tankers, totalling 360,000 gross
tons, were launched in 1972. Launchings also included 14 bulk carriers
totalling 442,000 gross tons and 42 cargo ships amounting to 306,800 gross
tons. At the end of 1972 orders on hand for merchant vessels of over 100 gross
tons were 220 (256 in 1971) totalling 4 million gross tons with a value of £643
million. Of these vessels, 49 (1-4 million gross tons) were for export.
There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the larger
shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work. Repair yards and dry docks are
situated in all the large ports.
Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, constructing various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One independent firm is taking part in the
design of a large slow-speed diesel engine. There are two other independent
builders of slow-speed engines. Steam turbines of the highest powers are also
built.

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 552,600
in 1972; the main groups were engineers’ small tools and gauges (65,000
persons), bolts, nuts and screws (38,900), wire and wire manufactures
(38,400), cans and metal boxes (27,500), jewellery, plate, and the refining of
precious metals (19,300)* hand tools and implements (20,300), cutlery (14,100),
and other metal industries (329,000). The total value of exports in 1972 was
about j£2oo million.
The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry, deliveries having nearly doubled in value since i960. Totalling £115
million in 1972, they included jigs and fixtures (£20 million), press tools and
moulds (£21 million), hard metal-tipped tools (£16 million) and other metal
cutting tools (£52 million). Export deliveries in 1972 totalled ^24 million.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms are mainly
small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1972 was £18 million,
including export sales of ^7-9 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, south
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1972 was £30 million, of which £9-8 million were sales for
export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades,
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was ^55-2 million in 1972, of which £17 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at £54 million and £16 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is
the largest of these. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares, including coins and medals, and electro-plated nickel
silver wares in 1972 was £63 million, of which ^i5’2 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 424,000, comprises the manu¬
facture of: general chemicals (140,000 employees), pharmaceutical chemicals
and preparations (74,100), toilet preparations (24,800), paint (26,200), soap
and detergents (15,400), synthetic resins, plastics materials and synthetic
rubber (45,900), dyestuffs and pigments (18,200), fertilisers (11,409), and other
chemical products (67,900). The industry is capital intensive, its fixed capital
expenditure, excluding mineral oil refining, amounting to almost £2,428

million during the eight years 1964-71, and totalling £310 million in 1972. A
significant proportion of this investment has been devoted to sectors with the
fastest changing technologies, notably petrochemicals and plastics. The value
of exports in 1972 was ^962 million, or 9-9 per cent of total British exports.
Production in the general chemicals industries rose by 69 per cent between
1963 and 1972.
Over half the output of the inorganic chemicals industry consists of a limited
number of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda,
chlorine and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic
materials for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any
chemical and 3-5 million tonnes were produced in 1972. The remaining output
of this sector consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity.
Substantial quantities of inorganic chemicals are used in the manufacture
of such products as fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. About one-
sixth of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 93 per cent between 1963 and 1972. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1972 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for over four-fifths of the total output of organic chemi¬
cals; deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 6-3
million tonnes in 1972 compared with 0-3 million tonnes in 1959. The most
important products (by weight) in 1972 were ethylene (1-12 million tonnes) and
propylene (542,000 tonnes). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics
materials, solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents.
Production of dyestuffs is geared primarily to demand by the textile industry;
about 51,000 tons of synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1972.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to £254-3 million
in 1972. Major purchasers were: the Netherlands (£36-8 million), the United
States (£27-4 million), France (£14-2 million) and the Federal Republic of
Germany (£12-5 million).
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
antibiotics, sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products,
anaesthetics, vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir
Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridine (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more recently, the
isolation of the penicillin nucleus and the development of several semi¬
synthetic penicillins and the cephalosporin antibiotics. Several of the larger
pharmaceutical companies in Britain are subsidiaries of overseas firms.
In 1972 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products and goods rose
by 7 per cent to £180-8 million, of which £22-4 million worth were antibiotics.
The largest purchasers were the Irish Republic (£11-2 million) and Japan
(£10-4 million).
The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and patented
in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries include
polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing sections of the
economy. Output of synthetic resins has doubled since 1963 and total produc¬
tion in 1972 was 1-2 million tons including o-8 million tons of thermoplastic
resins.

Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PVC and used for a wide
range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene (a material
used for toys, light mouldings and many consumer goods). One of the newer
thermoplastic materials is polypropylene, which can be fabricated as mould¬
ings, films and fibres. A new family of plastics materials reinforced with
carbon fibres is now in commercial production in Britain; they are up to three
times the strength but only half the weight of steel. Rapid expansion of capa¬
city for all the main types of plastics materials is planned. Exports in 1972
amounted to about 680,000 tonnes, valued at £176 million. The main pur¬
chasers were Australia (£13-1 million), Sweden (£13 million), the Irish
Republic (£12-8 million) and South Africa (^n-i million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is
manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1972 amounted to 306,824
tonnes, most of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant at Hythe, near
Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex were worth £257
million in 1972.
The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Production is
dominated by three firms and there are a number of firms marketing com¬
pound fertilisers from the principal constituents—nitrogen, phosphorus and
potassium. Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen content)
has been increasing and in 1971-72 totalled 760,000 tons, while 466,000 tons
(in terms of phosphate content) of phosphatic fertilisers were produced; pro¬
duction of compound fertilisers amounted to over 3 million tons in 1971-72.
The use of ammonium nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium phosphate,
and, to a limited extent, urea (mostly 45 per cent nitrogen) is resulting in more
concentrated fertilisers. The value of exports of manufactured fertilisers,
mainly nitrogenous, was ^7 million in 1972-
Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective hor¬
mone weed-killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual
general herbicide. Sales of pesticides and allied products were valued at £90
million in 1972, over double the 1971 total; herbicides (£21 million) were the
largest single category. Exports of insecticides, fungicides and disinfectants in
1972 totalled j£33'5 million.
Manufacturers’ sales of paint and varnish during 1972 amounted to some 606
million gallons (including 29 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at £193
million. Britain is one of the largest exporters of paints in the world; exports ot
pigments, paints, varnishes and related materials in 1972 amounted to £52 7
million. Indirect exports in the form of surface coatings for finished goods are
considerable. . j • 1 j-
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, including
new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments, quick-drying paints and paints
needing only one application.

Sales of toilet preparations were provisionally valued at .£178 million in 1972,
including export sales of ^28-2 million; home market sales of hair preparations
totalled about £46 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw
materials used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in deter¬
gents; the other main constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic
sources. Sales of synthetic detergents amounted to 524,000 tons in 1972,
including 36,000 tons for export. Deliveries of soap totalled some 243,000 tons.
Sales of polishes in 1972 were valued at £20 million, including floor and
furniture polishes worth j£ii million. Exports of perfumery and toilet pre¬
parations, soap and associated products were valued at ,£54*7 million.
Radioisotopes are processed and marketed by The Radiochemical Centre Ltd.
at Amersham, one of the new companies set up under the Atomic Energy
Authority Act 1971 (see p. 405). In the year ended March 1972 sales of radio¬
isotopes were valued at .£6 million, of which 62 per cent represented exports,
the highest proportion so far.
In recent years, the boundaries between the various fibre-based sectors of the
textile industry have become indistinct and considerable vertical integration
has taken place, connected with the rapidly developing technology of man¬
made fibres. Large multi-fibre, multi-process groups have been formed, four
of which now control the bulk of spinning and warp knitting.
The industry has a labour force of 558,000, half of whom are women;
35,700 are engaged in the production of man-made fibres, 63,500 in the spin¬
ning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made fibres, 49,000 in the weaving
of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 107,000 in the woollen and worsted
trades, 127,500 in hosiery and knitted goods, 50,600 in textile finishing and
43,000 in carpets. The total value of textile exports in 1972 was £445 million.
Production of textiles rose by 4-6 per cent in 1972 and was 28 per cent higher
than in 1963. The industry’s main research body is the Cotton, Silk and Man¬
made Fibres Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing low-cost competi¬
tion has cut progressively into British markets and a global limit has been in
force on imports of cotton textiles from most countries since 1966.
Output in 1972 consisted of: 268 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 180
million lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 166 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 215 million lb. of textured man-made fibre continuous filament
yarn, 561 million linear yards of woven cotton cloth, and 514 million linear
yards of man-made fibre and mixture cloth. In 1972 exports of cotton yarn
(excluding man-made fibres) were worth £11-7 million, exports of woven
cotton fabrics were valued at £29 million, with the Irish Republic the most
important market.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool the chief port of entry for
raw cotton.
The wool textile industry, one of the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. The small or medium-sized
business predominates, with only a few large firms. While the West Riding of

Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the west
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1972 output included 75 million kg. of wool and hair tops and 131
million kg. of woollen yarn. Deliveries of worsted and semi-worsted yarn
amounted to 102 million kg. and of woven fabrics to 220 million square yards.
In addition, large, but declining, quantities of raw wool are scoured and
cleaned in Britain. Consumption of raw wool in 1972 was 152 million kg.
Exports in 1972 included wool yarns (£27-3 million), woollen fabrics (£40
million) and wool worsted fabrics (£23-5 million). The main buyers of woollen
and worsted fabrics were Japan (^9'3 million), the Federal Republic of
Germany and Canada. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other
animal hair and tops exported had a value of £44 million. Research is carried
on mainly by the Wool Industries Research Association.
Much of the early development of viscose rayon and acetate took place in
Britain. Production is spread throughout the country with Northern Ireland
of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the industry. There has
been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the 1972 total of 627,000
tonnes being 67 per cent more than in 1964. Output consisted of 363,000
tonnes of staple fibre and 264,000 tonnes of filament yarn in 1972. Of the
staple fibre, 178,000 tonnes, and of the continuous filament, 196,000 tonnes,
were of fully synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1972 totalled 4537 million lb. The
world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (north Wales), with an
annual output of over 260 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at
Grimsby and Preston. Almost all the rayon produced in Britain is made by a
single company and its subsidiaries.
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963.
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second world
war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with wool.
A group of fibres of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a
British discovery) and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex
fibres, which are man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch
and recovery, are now produced commercially.
Exports of man-made fibre synthetic and regenerated yarns had a value of
£95 million in 1972, and woven fabrics ^25-4 million. The United States,
Switzerland, Sweden and the Irish Republic were the most important pur¬
chasers of yarns.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
enterprises. Although widely distributed, the industry is centred in the east
Midlands, the north-west of England and in Scotland. Sales of knitted goods
were valued at £474 million in 1972 including £180 million worth of outer¬
wear and £97 million worth of socks, tights and stockings. Sales of knitted
fabrics were worth ^197 million in 1972. Exports of knitted or crocheted
clothing and accessories were valued at £5 5 "9 rmllion in 1972; the largest

knitted and crocheted fabrics amounted to £43-3 million. The Hosiery and
Allied Trades Research Association, with laboratories at Nottingham, under¬
takes collective research.
The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns and the lighter
types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of coarse linens and
canvas, although household types are also produced. Northern Ireland manu¬
facturers produced 23*4 million linear yards of cloth in 1972, while weavers in
Great Britain delivered 25-9 million square yards, including 9-8 million
square yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1972 included ^6-6 million
worth of linen fabrics and £3-8 million worth of flax yarns and linen thread.
Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry. Jute yarn is used in the manufacture of carpets,
cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for a wide range of applications in the
packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and motor car industries.
New uses for jute, as a plastics reinforcement for example, have been deve¬
loped. In 1972, 94,000 tons of raw jute were used, and exports of jute fabric
and yarn totalled ^2-4 million.
Sales of finished lace goods amounted to j£i8*i million in 1972. The most
important lace product is manufactured on warp knitting machines, with
sales valued at ^7-3 million. Exports of principal products were worth £4-1
million in 1972.
In addition to the products mentioned above, British textile firms manufacture
a wide range of other goods, including many special yarns and fabrics, net,
household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and curtains, and floor cover¬
ings other than carpets. Sales of floor coverings of linoleum, vinyl and other
synthetic materials were valued at nearly £40 million in 1972; just under one-
sixth was for export. The cordage industry is one of the largest in Europe.
Exports of ropes, cordage, nets and netting in 1972 were valued at ^4-8
million.
Almost 150 enterprises are engaged in the manufacture of carpets and rugs,
including several large groups. Total sales in 1972 amounted to some 180
million square yards worth about £290 million. Over half of the volume of
sales is accounted for by tufted carpets, in the production of which the pile,
usually with a high man-made fibre content, is inserted into a pre-woven
backing; woven carpets, such as Axminster and Wilton make up most of the
remainder of sales, and form over one-third of the value of exports—£51-6
million in 1972. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster
(in Worcestershire), Halifax and Bradford (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several towns in Northern Ireland.
About one-quarter of the carpets produced (by quantity) are made pre¬
dominantly of wool and a growing proportion of traditional woven carpets
contain some man-made fibre.
There are 470,700 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 337,900 are in the clothing industry, 87,800 in the footwear trade and
45,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1972 was £109 million.
goB BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Clothing The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries of
made-up clothing have increased by 21 per cent since 1963. Exports in 1972,
excluding knitted goods, were valued at £65-1 million; the Irish Republic
(£7-6 million) was the main purchaser.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. The Clothing Export
Council, representing some 220 companies, organises promotions for various
sectors of the industry.
Leather Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1972 the industry s
output totalled £157 million; exports were valued at £41’9 million. The United
States (£7-3 million) is the largest single market, followed by Canada (£47
million) and the Federal Republic of Germany.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from
the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting, to high quality
leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. Collective research is
carried out by the British Leather Manufacturers’ Research Association.
Footwear The British footwear industry is among the largest in the world. In 1972
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 184 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of ^32-i million; the United States (£5*2 million), the
Irish Republic and Canada were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on pro¬
duction of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region of
Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on women’s and girls
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.
FOOD, DRINK The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 729,800 people in the pro-
AND TOBACCO Auction of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports in
1972 was £619-5 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for £266 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £46-4 million; cereal
and cereal preparations for £33-9 million; fruit and vegetables for £31-4
million; and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for £50-6 million.
Many of the industry’s leading firms have been involved in mergers in
recent years.

and Biscuits
The household consumption of bread, which has been falling, averaged about
2 lb. 2 oz. (0-96 kg.) per head per week in 1972. The trend is heavily towards
concentrating production in large mechanised bakeries; about two-thirds of
the bread is made in these bakeries, which specialise in sliced and wrapped
loaves; three groups have a dominant position. In the smaller bakeries produc¬
tion of cakes and other flour confectionery is usually allied to bread production.
There are 121,100 employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry
and a further 24,300 in grain-milling. ,
There are 43,700 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
about 600,000 tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 10-7 oz. (0-3 kg.) in 1972. British biscuits have
gained a world-wide reputation, and, despite the problem of import restnc-

The cocoa, chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 73,000
employees, is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and
many medium-sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the
industry are sugar, cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of
chocolate and sugar confectionery was 766,000 tons in 1972. Consumption of
chocolate and sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is among the
highest in the world, being equivalent to 8 oz. (0-23 kg.) per head per week.
The value of exports in 1972 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was ^26-4 million and ofsugar confectionery ^21-9 million. The United States
and Canada were the main markets for sugar preparations. An estimated 30
per cent of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Fruit and vegetable products include canned, frozen and dried fruit and vege¬
tables, jam, marmalade and pickles. The labour force numbers 54,700. Output
of jams and marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000
tons in 1956, has since remained little changed, totalling 181,000 tons in 1972.
Raspberry, strawberry, apricot and blackcurrant jams are the most popular.
Exports of jams and marmalade in 1972 were valued at ^2*5 million.
In 1972, 785,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Beans in tomato sauce (297,000 tons) and
processed and fresh peas (255,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand as
canned products. In addition, output in 1972 included 62,000 tons of canned
and bottled fruit. Strawberries, rhubarb and plums are the most important
fruits used for canning, followed by prunes, gooseberries and fruit salad.
Sales of prepared fruit pie fillings are increasing.
Nearly 235,000 tons of vegetables were processed by quick freezing in 1972.
The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and pre¬
serving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the pre¬
paration of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 108,800. Output of
canned meat and canned meat products in 1972 totalled 135,000 tons, and the
quantity of bacon and ham cured was 272,000 tons. Quick-frozen fish output
amounted to some 104,000 tons in 1972; small quantities (15,000 tons in 1972)
are also canned. Exports of fish and fish preparations had a value of £29-3
million in 1972 and those of meat and meat products were worth ^49-4
million.
The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 127,200.
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) totalled 69 million proof
gallons with a value of ^228 million in 1972; almost half went to the United
States (j£ioi million). Scotch whisky was first distilled in the fifteenth century.
It is blended from 20 or more different types, some from malted barley and
some from other grains. Whisky requires several years to mature, and the
172-3 million proof gallons of Scotch whisky produced in the 1972 distilling
year will not be on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky amount to more than
600 million proof gallons, representing 10 years’ consumption. About four-fifths
of annual sales are to overseas buyers.

Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The main
distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion of
total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports had a value of £14-1 million in 1972.
There are 69,200 employees in the brewing and malting industry. There are
seven major brewery groups which market their products throughout the
country. In 1972, 35-3 million bulk barrels of beer were produced, the highest
since 1920, and consumers’ expenditure on beer amounted to £1,650 million.
Exports in 1972 of malt beer were 431,000 bulk barrels, worth £6 million.
Firms have introduced new production methods, including continuous brew¬
ing processes, and automated batch production plants are well established.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers and malt extract manufacturers. British
malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1972 amounted
to 83,000 tons, worth £5 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be seasonal. Output in 1972 included 71 million gallons of
concentrated liquid, and 291 million gallons of unconcentrated drinks. Though
there has been some amalgamation in recent years, there are still several
hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two very large firms
among about 20 producing widely advertised brands which are marketed on a
national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by firms in the pro¬
duction of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based drinks, squashes
and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted drinks (in which the
whole fruit is used).
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other tobacco
goods sold in Britain. In 1972 the industry’s total sales were valued at £1,658
million. Exports worth £46-8 million (of which cigarettes accounted for
90 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas markets; Saudi Arabia,
the Netherlands and Belgium being the most important. The main centres of
production are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London, Manchester,
Newcastle, Nottingham, Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest manufacturing
groups account for over 90 per cent of total output. The industry has 34,200
employees.
The tobacco industry used 291-4 million lb. (132-2 million kg.) of un¬
manufactured tobacco in 19725 all of which was imported. In 1972 the main
sources were the United States, Canada and India. Output included 254*5
million lb. (115-4 million kg.) of cigarettes, including 205-7 million lb. (93-3
million kg.) of tipped cigarettes; 4-5 million lb. (2 million kg.) of cigars; and
29 million lb. (13-2 million kg.) of pipe and other tobacco.
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 294,900 which includes 48,400 in
the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 72,400 in the glass industry
and 53,600 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
INDUSTRY
Pottery
Glass
Cement
311
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabrica¬
tion to highly mechanised systems. In 1972 about 6,940 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, made mainly in the Bedford and Peter¬
borough areas. Refractory goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks
and chrome-magnesite bricks) are manufactured mainly for home use.
The pottery industry, supplying almost all home needs for domestic and
industrial pottery, is a long-established and complex industry, largely located
in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Almost all of its raw material is
indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon and
Cornwall.
Domestic pottery, including china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rock¬
ingham, accounts for about half of the industry’s output; the other main
divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and such specialised
industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics and laboratory
porcelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of British pottery are
Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton, Minton, Coalport and
Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery were ^77*1 million in 1972
including record export sales of ^36 million; the United States and Canada
are the leading markets.
There has been considerable re-equipment in the industry; kilns fired by
gas or electricity have replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns, and new decorat¬
ing techniques and automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been
introduced.
Britain’s glass industry is one of the largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which, developed in Britain and perhaps the most marked
advance in the history of glass-making, has been licensed to glass makers
throughout the world. The use of glass for internal decoration and as a finish
for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years. Large
quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other products
include tubular glass (produced on a large scale), mirrors, lamp and bulb
glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres, and all types of glass
containers (most of which is made automatically). A traditional product is
hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality.
Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of ^49-3
million in 1972. Those of glass were worth £28-2 million, the most important
markets being Australia, the United States and South Africa. The figure
included ^I0’4 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
The cement industry of the United Kingdom, with 14,600 employees, is chiefly
concerned with the manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph
Aspdin and patented in 1824, this material and the methods of its production
have been the subject of continuous technical improvement and intensive
research. The capacity of the industry has expanded substantially in recent
years. The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an important producing
area. Output totalled 17-9 million tonnes in 1972.

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The paper, printing and publishing industries have 572,600 employees,
including 70,900 in the manufacture of paper and board, 84,500 in the
production of packaging materials, 139,300 in the printing and publishing of
newspapers and periodicals, and 211,700 in other types of printing and
publishing.
The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as long ago as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is one of the largest in Europe. Total
production in 1972 of all types of paper and board amounted to 4-4 million
tonnes. Of this, newsprint accounted for 469,000 tonnes and other printing and
writing papers for 1-07 million tonnes; 1-24 million tonnes was board and the
remainder was made up chiefly of wrapping papers, industrial and special
purpose papers and tissues. Exports of paper and boaid reached a new record
level of ,£68-9 million in 1972 and exports of manufactured paper items were
valued at ^32-9 million. The main purchasers were the Irish Republic,
France, the Federal Republic of Germany and the Netherlands.
Total sales of household paper products, including facial tissues, have risen
sharply to £65 million. In 1972, sales of cardboard boxes and cartons were
valued at £170 million while those of fibreboard packing cases totalled £175
million; sales of manufactured stationery amounted to £198 million in 1972.
Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by two firms; a recent development
has been the introduction of plastics and plastics-coated wall coverings.
The main raw materials are woodpulp and waste paper. Woodpulp pro¬
duced in the UK is of increasing importance although it still represents only
a small percentage of total supplies (some 975,000 tonnes per annum of home¬
grown pulpwood are used in its manufacture). The amount of waste paper
consumed by paper and board mills in 1972 was i’9 million tonnes, most of it
collected as salvage in this country.
There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada, other parts
of the Commonwealth and Europe.
Research is undertaken by The Research Association for the Paper and
Board, Printing and Packaging Industries.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Three large firms each employ more than 15,000 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.
Book publishers’ turnover in 1972 is estimated at £197 million, of which
export sales accounted for £69 million. Book titles published in 1972 totalled
nearly 33,000, over 25,000 of them new ones. Popularity of paper-backed
books has increased rapidly in recent years. Exports of printed matter, manu¬
scripts and typescripts were valued at ^119*8 million in i972> including books
and pamphlets (£69-2 million), and newspapers and periodicals (£18-1
million), but these figures do not include parcel post shipments, which are
possibly as large again as the recorded totals. The United States, Australia and
the Netherlands are the most important overseas markets. The Book Develop¬
ment Council of the Publishers’ Association promotes the supply and use of
INDUSTRY
313
British books overseas. Firms have introduced the latest developments in
high-speed printing equipment, including electronic engraving machines and
advanced processes of photographic reproduction, and several newspapers are
now set by computer.

Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
270,200 employees, rubber manufacture, with 114,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures employs some 216,700 including 113,000 in
plastics moulding and fabricating.

Tyres and tubes represent more than half the output of the industry but firms
also make a variety of goods, the most important being rubber footwear,
conveyor belting, cables, hose, latex foam products and other vehicle com¬
ponents and accessories.
In 1972 the industry’s consumption of rubber totalled 464,100 tons, com¬
prising 173,500 tons of natural rubber, 269,400 tons of synthetic rubber and
21,200 tons of reclaimed rubber; the proportion of synthetic rubber used is
increasing. In i972> 230,000 tons of rubber were used in the production of
tyres and tyre products. Tyre manufacturers include several subsidiaries of
United States and other overseas companies. The largest tyre group in Europe
came into being in January 1971, following the merger of Britain’s leading
tyre producing company and its Italian equivalent. Direct exports of rubber
and rubber manufactures in 1972 were worth ^96-4 million, with Sweden,
the United States and Australia as the main markets. This figure included
tyres and tubes valued at £52-5 million, but excluded large indirect exports on
vehicles. In addition, the industry exported about £4-6 million worth of
rubber footwear and £4 million of rubber gloves and other miscellaneous
products. Tyres are now being developed which remain safe after puncturing.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by nearly 60 per cent in volume between
1963 and 1972, and in the latter year their value was an estimated £315 million.
Exports of all furniture were worth .£35 million in 1972. Numerous enterprises
manufacture furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office,
school and other furniture) and the labour force is of the order of 88,000. The
bedding industry employs 21,300 people; sales of new bedding in 1972 by
larger manufacturers were valued at £57 million. Scientific research and
technical and other information services are provided by the Furniture
Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research Association.
The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft units. The value of sales in
1972 was £43 million, of which jCys million was for export.
The timber industry employs 92,700 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at £253 million in 1972) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber was about 610,000 cubic metres in 1972. Other
products include plywood and chipboard.
Toys, Games
and Sports
Equipment
The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
and children’s carriages in Britain is 42,000. Sales of toys and children’s
carriages in 1972 were worth £102 million and exports had a value of ^32-5
million. The Federal Republic of Germany and the United States were the
main overseas markets. The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £9
million and that of sports equipment £32 million.
15 Agriculture, Fisheries
and Forestry
THE LAND AND
ITS USES
Size of Farms
AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for nearly half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest
and most important industries. It occupies 647,000 people or 2-8 per cent of the
total in civil employment, provides about 2-9 per cent of the gross national
product, and uses 47 million of the 60 million acres (19 million of the 24
million hectares) of land.
The soils of the country are varied (see p. 5). Land used for farming is
conventionally divided into land suitable for cultivation (crops and grass) and
rough grazing. In hill country the area of cultivated land is often small, but is
usually supplemented by grazing on a comparatively large area of hill land.
In Britain there are 30 million acres (12-2 million hectares) under crops and
grass. Cultivated land, rough grazing, woodlands (ancillary to farming) and
other land used for agriculture together represent 79 per cent of the land area.
The rest is mountain and forest, or put to urban and kindred uses. The area
available for farming is gradually decreasing to meet the needs of housing and
industry; so far, the loss has been offset by the increase in output from what
remains. The ratio of rough grazing—used for stock, mainly sheep to better
quality agricultural land varies considerably throughout Britain. In the
southern half of England, for example, it constitutes only about one-tenth of
the total acreage, increasing to a quarter in Northern Ireland, about a third
in the hill regions of England and Wales and nearly three-quarters in Scot¬
land.
There are about 293,400 statistically significant farming units in Britain. Some
44 per cent are very small units, mostly farmed part-time, and accounting for
less than a tenth of the industry’s total output. Of the 165,000 full-time farm
businesses some 37,500 are classified (by standard man-days) as large farm
businesses (capable of employing four or more men full time): these, account¬
ing for some 13 per cent of the number of holdings, produce nearly half the
industry’s total output. There are about 55,000 medium-sized (two-three
men) and 72,000 small farm businesses. The total is falling by about 2 per cent
Amalgamation of small farms into larger, more viable units has been en¬
couraged by successive governments. The average size of full-time holdings
in Britain is 232 acres (94 hectares) of crops and grass (including rough
grazings). . • tvt u
Some 35,000 of the total of significant farming units are in Northern
Ireland: about half of these provide a full-time occupation for the owner and
produce over four-fifths of the total output. The typical farm size is between
40-70 acres (16-28 hectares). Other holdings, of which there are about 27,000,
are either extremely small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or
grazing).
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
Types of
Farming
AGRICULTURAL
PRODUCTION:
CROPS AND
LIVESTOCK
Production
3i5
The increasing use of intensive methods of production both in crops and in
animal husbandry has led to greater specialisation. Three-fifths of the full¬
time farms in Britain are devoted mainly to dairying or beef cattle and sheep.
One in six is a cropping farm and the remainder specialise in pigs, poultry or
horticulture or are mixed farms. In England the farms devoted primarily to
arable crops are in the eastern part of the country—in East Anglia, Kent,
Lincolnshire and the East Riding of Yorkshire. In Scotland the rich lowlands
of the east coast are also primarily arable. Potato and vegetable growing on a
substantial scale marks the farming of the Fens (south Lincolnshire and
Cambridgeshire), the alluvial areas around the rivers Thames and Humber
and the peaty lands in south Lancashire. Early potatoes are an important crop
in Pembrokeshire and the south-west. Elsewhere, horticultural crops are
widely dispersed amongst agricultural crops.
Dairying occurs widely, but there are concentrations in south-west Scot¬
land, the western parts of England and south-west Wales, where the wetter
climate encourages the growth of good grass. Sheep and cattle are reared in the
hill and moorland areas of Scotland, Wales and northern and south-western
England. Beef fattening takes place partly on better grassland areas and partly
in yards on viable farms.
In Northern Ireland dairying is the main occupation on 40 per cent of the
full-time farms, while a further 30 per cent concentrate on beef and sheep
production. The remainder are either specialised cropping and horticultural
holdings, intensive pig and poultry units or mixed farms with no predominant
single enterprise. Oats and barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock
feeding, and the only important cash crop is potatoes.
The increase in production which has occurred over the past decades is a
result of the effort of individual farmers, of farmers’ organisations, of research
workers and advisers and of government action. The role of the Government
is described on pp. 323-26.
The steady expansion in production and in yield per acre of arable land which
has taken place since 1936 is summarised in Table 29. Apart from a slight
decline between 1961 and 1964, and another in 1968, total cattle stocks have
risen each year since 1957, to reach a record figure of nearly 14 million at the
end of 1972. The milk-producing herd, having been fairly constant in size
since i960, has begun to expand, and the beef herd is also expanding. Numbers
of sheep and lambs reached their highest level in 1966; although they later
declined, some expansion is now evident again. Numbers of pigs have in¬
creased by one-quarter during the past decade, as have those of poultry.
Arable production has shown a greater diversification since the second world
war. Total cereals production has increased considerably since i960, reaching
a record of over 15 million tons in 1972-73. Potato production is susceptible
to weather conditions but, on average, adequate supplies are maintained.
Between 1963 and 1972-73 output of pigmeat increased by nearly one-quarter
and eggs by one-tenth; these increases, together with those in beef and milk,
resulted in higher consumption of feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources.
Between 5 and 6 million tons of concentrated feeds are imported each year,
depending on the size of the home crop of cereals.
The index of agricultural net product (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 it: was some 56 per cent above the immediate pre¬
war average; it rose a further 36 per cent between 1954-57 and 1964-67.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
Grassland

Cereals
Fodder Crops
Sugar Beet
Potatoes
Dairy Farming
31?
With the average of 1964-67 as a base, the index for all commercially signi¬
ficant holdings reached 118 in 1971-72; 117 is forecast for 1972-73.
The British climate suits grassland farming. Grassland forms an important
section of the economy of most farms, whether as permanent grass, mostly
occupying land less suitable for cultivation, or as sown grassland (leys), often
part of the arable rotation. A wide range of herbage species and varieties are
used.
Grassland production has been enhanced over recent years by the develop¬
ment and application of new techniques, notably the increased use of fertilisers
(especially nitrogenous), methods of grazing control, improved herbage con¬
servation for winter feed and irrigation. Rough grazings remain as semi¬
natural grassland used for extensively grazed flocks and herds, producing
young animals for fattening elsewhere.
Wheat is grown mainly in the eastern half of the country. About 47 million
tons were harvested in i972> with average yields estimated at 34 cwt. per acre
(4-3 tonnes per hectare). Between one-third and one-half of the wheat crop
is used for flour milling, the remainder going mainly for animal feed.
Since 1961 the area under barley has increased by nearly 50 per cent and in
general production has risen faster because yields have also increased. The
malting and distilling market currently absorbs about one-sixth of the crop;
most of the remainder is retained by farms or sold for animal feed.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also often
used on a co-operative basis.
In Great Britain the total area of fodder crops has fallen because in many
cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically by increased grass
production and improved methods of conservation. The principal fodder crops
are beans and kale in England and turnips and swedes in Scotland.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire under contract to the
British Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices
and also provides technical advice and assistance. More than three-quarters
of the crop is mechanically harvested.
Potatoes are grown in most parts of Britain. First supplies of early potatoes
normally come at the end of May. The lifting of main crop potatoes usually
starts in September. Seed potato production for Britain and for export is
chiefly centred in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
Britain is normally self-sufficient in main-crop potatoes. As yields are
increasing, requirements, including the increased demand for processed
potatoes, can be met from a declining acreage. The area planted with potatoes
has declined from 829,000 acres (335,000 hectares) in i960 to 584,000 acres
(236,000 hectares) in 1972. The average yield per acre from the 1972 crop was
11 tons, resulting in an overall balance of supply and demand. Although potato
production is becoming increasingly mechanised, much hand labour is still
needed.
Milk is more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when con¬
verted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk is
produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the greater
part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Average consumption of
liquid milk per head is 4-6 pints per week.
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by about
14 per cent and now average some 888 gallons a year. Freedom from tuber¬
culosis has reduced herd wastage, and a campaign to eradicate brucellosis is
under way. The Friesian breed is dominant in the dairy herds of England,
Wales and Northern Ireland, and the Ayrshire breed in Scotland. Average
herd size is 34 cows. Milk production has been stimulated by advances in
grassland management, intensive grazing techniques and new methods of
making high quality hay and silage. Most dairy farmers practise some degree
of intensive grass management, but hay or silage of the traditional type supple¬
mented with purchased concentrates remain the basic winter feeds.
A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. Substantial sales of animals and semen are made to
overseas buyers seeking to replenish and improve their herds and flocks.
British breeds have recently been joined by a number of continental breeds.
Artificial insemination plays an important part in cattle breeding, nearly
two-thirds of the dairy herd in Great Britain being bred in this way, through
centres operated by the Milk Marketing Boards and other organisations.
In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle are kept, especially of the Gallo¬
way and Welsh Black breeds and their crosses; in marginal land and lower
areas the sires used are predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus and Hereford
breeds. About two-thirds of home-fed beef production derives from the dairy
herds, some females being mated to beef sires. There is a large and complex
trade in store cattle (increased by animals imported from the Irish Republic),
a typical movement being from the upland west to grazing areas in the Mid¬
lands. The demand for lean tender beef at an economic price has stimulated
the development of intensive and semi-intensive systems of production.
Britain has a long tradition of sheep production. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a particular area. Research has provided vaccine and sera protection
against nearly all the epidemic diseases.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages; first, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more rapidly
maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on to the more genial low¬
land conditions, where they become crossed again with Down rams for fat
lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the lowland sires
fecundity and early maturity. Fat lamb production provides the main source
of income for sheep farmers but wool is also of considerable importance,
especially to farmers in hill areas.
Pig production is carried on in most parts of Britain but is particularly
important in the eastern and southern counties of England and in Northern
Ireland, where numbers have doubled since about I950, There is an increasing
concentration into specialist units and larger herds. The most frequently used
breeds are the Large White and the Landrace though considerable cross¬
breeding takes place. Pig improvements are fostered through research by the
Meat and Livestock Commission and by leading commercial firms. Artificial
insemination is available nationally.
About 30 per cent of the pig meat is used for bacon and 70 per cent tor
pork and manufacturing into sausages and other processed forms.
Poultry
Horticultural
Industry
Fruit
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 319
The British poultry industry has expanded rapidly in recent years, largely
owing to the application of improved husbandry and management techniques
in intensive production units and to genetic improvements in stock. Only a
small proportion of total production is in the hands of the smallest producers—
more than three-fifths of the laying birds on farms are in flocks of 5,000 or
more while two-thirds of the broilers are in flocks of 50,000 or more. The
average yield of eggs per bird is about 230 a year and nearly all eggs consumed
in Britain are home-produced. About 330 million broilers and other special
table chickens were produced in 1972.
The horticultural industry produces a wide variety of fruit, vegetables and
flower crops which are together worth nearly 12 per cent of the total from
agriculture as a whole—an estimated £333 million in 1972-73 out of a total of
£2,841 million.
At the June 1972 census the land on which these crops were grown amounted
to nearly 674,000 acres (272,000 hectares), just over 2 per cent of the land used
for crops and grass. Of crops in the open, fruit accounted for 191,000 acres
(77,500 hectares), vegetables, excluding potatoes, for 441,000 acres (179,000
hectares), and flowers, bulbs and nursery stock for 38,000 acres (15,400
hectares). Crops under glass, including mushrooms, occupied 5,000 acres
(2,000 hectares).
Horticultural crops are largely grown on specialised holdings where soil,
climate, skilled labour and water can produce maximum yields of high quality
crops and where access to markets or good roads enable them to be sold at
economic prices. Most horticultural enterprises are expanding with the help
of improved planting material, new techniques of cultivation and environ¬
mental control and the widespread use of machinery. Some horticultural crops
form parts of general farm rotations but the returns from increased specialisa¬
tion favour separate horticultural enterprises. Traditional market gardening,
which once flourished around the large centres of population, has declined over
the years, mainly due to the growth in the field-scale production of vegetables
to meet the demands of the processing industries.
Of the 191,000 acres (77,500 hectares) used for fruit growing in 1972, 45,000
acres (18,200 hectares) were devoted to small fruit and the remainder was
under orchards. Dessert apples are the most widespread fruit crop, covering
some 55,000 acres (22,200 hectares), mainly in Kent and neighbouring
counties, in East Anglia and to the north and south of Bristol. Recent plantings
are largely of the autumn and winter variety of Cox’s Orange Pippin; many of
the new orchards consist of closely planted dwarf trees which can be efficiently
pruned, sprayed and picked. England and Northern Ireland are among the
few countries which grow varieties of apples especially suitable for cooking,
the best-known of which is Bramley’s Seedling. Cooking-apple orchards
cover 24,000 acres (9,700 hectares) in England and about 7,000 acres (2,800
hectares) in Northern Ireland. There are nearly 13,000 acres (5,300 hectares)
under varieties of cider apples.
Although pears thrive best in the warmer Continental climate, in the east
and south-east of England where somewhat similar conditions prevail the
Conference pear and a few high quality varieties are produced. Cherries and
plums are grown in Kent, and plums also in the Vale of Evesham and parts of
East Anglia. Around Perth in Scotland is the largest concentration of raspberry
plantations in the world. This forms the basis of an important processing
industry.

Nursery Stock

Vegetables

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Strawberries are the most widespread small fruit, accounting for some 20,000
acres (8,100 hectares), the main-crop areas being in Kent and East Anglia.
Blackcurrants are also widely grown in Britain, mainly for the preparation of
juice for the manufacture of soft drinks and flavours for confectionery. Other
fruits include gooseberries, red and white currants, loganberries and black¬
berries. Almost all the nuts consumed in Britain are imported but a few cob
nut and filberts are still grown in parts of Kent.
Much of the glasshouse sector of the horticultural industry has been re¬
equipped since the mid-1960s with the aid of grants under the Horticultural
Improvement Scheme. There are now, in many parts of the country, large
units with automatic control of light, heat, ventilation, water and the carbon
dioxide content of the atmosphere. Tomatoes form the most important glass¬
house crop, either as a single crop or in rotation with others, and together with
lettuce and cucumbers represent some 95 per cent of the total value of
glasshouse vegetable output. There is increasing demand for sweet peppers
and aubergines, two crops which were formerly hardly grown or consumed in
Britain. Cucumbers are extensively grown in the traditional glasshouse area
in the Lee Valley to the north of London. Mushrooms, which have a farm-
gate value of over £20 million annually, are grown in specially constructed
sheds in several parts of the country.
Bulbs and hardy nursery stock each occupied some 17,000 acres (6,900
hectares) in June 1972; flowers in the open took 4,000 acres (1,620 hectares).
Many nurseries concentrate on the production of popular plants in containers
for sale through the garden centres which have been established on the out¬
skirts of many towns.
Cut flowers are grown and bulbs cultivated in many areas but particularly
in the Holland area of Lincolnshire, Norfolk, the east of Scotland, Cornwall
and in the Isles of Scilly where more than 50 per cent of the cultivable land is
devoted to bulbs which flower there from November to May.
Vegetables and outdoor salad crops are grown in the traditional areas of the
Thames Valley, north Kent, Vale of Evesham, south Lancashire and the West
Riding of Yorkshire, but newer areas, especially suited through soil type or
climate to production of a particular crop, have come into prominence. West
Cornwall, south Devon, Pembrokeshire and Kent send winter cauliflowers and
spring cabbage to most urban markets while almost half the summer and
autumn cauliflowers come from the intensive horticultural holdings in Lin¬
colnshire. The light soils of Norfolk and Cambridgeshire are especially suit¬
able for carrots and onions, and the Holland area of Lincolnshire accounts for
almost a third of the onion acreage. Brussels sprouts are grown extensively in
Bedfordshire; their production has also extended from the Vale of Evesham
into Gloucestershire and well up the east coast of England wherever freezing
factories are sited for the processing of fish as well as vegetables. Peas and
dwarf beans are largely sold frozen, canned or dried and so are grown close to
factories in the east of England and in Scotland. Celery is mainly grown on the
deep soils of south east Lancashire, Norfolk and the fens of Cambridgeshire.
Nearly three-quarters of the early rhubarb is produced in the West Riding of
Yorkshire, where plants grown in the open are then forced in unlit sheds.
Hops for the brewing industry are grown in Kent and Sussex, Herefordshire
and Worcestershire. They occupy only about 17,000 acres (6,900 hectares) but
have a very high yield per acre and value by weight.

pattern of food consumption has tended to stabilise but with a more pro¬

Of all farm expenses, purchased feedingstuffs amount to nearly one-third,
wages to nearly one-fifth and machinery (including depreciation) and equip¬
ment to over one-sixth. Since i960 male agricultural earnings have more than
doubled, offsetting the manpower economies made possible by mechanisation
and increasing farm size, while labour productivity has risen by about 6 per
cent a year since 1964-65.
The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmer,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.
In 1972 provisional ‘fixed capital’ totalling £167 million was added to the
value of buildings and works and ^180 million was invested in new plant,
machinery and vehicles. The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the
farms is provided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an important source of
outside capital, both fixed and working; about two-thirds of the total bank
advances to agriculture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural
merchants are also an important source of short-term credit. Mortgage loans

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 323
form the chief source of long-term credit and are provided by specialised
financial institutions (see p. 326) and private sources.
Accounts of some 3,000 farms in Britain, collected by agricultural economists
in 1972, show average valuations of occupiers’ capital ranging from about £2
per acre (^y4 per hectare) on hill farms with extensive rough grazings to over
£80 per acre per hectare) on some lowland farms. On all types of
farm investment in machinery is a heavy item: on dairy and arable farms it
averages about £20 per acre (£50 per hectare); on stock-rearing farms it may
amount to £8 per acre (£20 per hectare).
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with 512,000
tractors in 1972 or one to every 35 acres (14*2 hectares) of arable land. Power-
take-off implements now characterise arable farming; and some 60,000
combine harvesters were in use in 1972. A wide variety of machines for
harvesting and preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are
installed on all except the smallest farms.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are about 1,700 farmers’ machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment with¬
out tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out by
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wide, varying with
the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the occupier.
The average net income for farms in England and Wales of different types is
generally within the range of £2 to £35 per acre (^12 to £86 per hectare) with
the exception of pig and poultry farms and horticultural holdings, which are
more intensive in their use of land. Net income per acre on dairy and arable
farms has nearly always been higher than on stock-rearing farms, which are
generally larger than the other types and are situated on poorer land. In
Scotland incomes per acre range from about £1 on hill farms to £23 (£56-8 per
hectare) on dairy farms.
The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
by the agricultural ministers; for England and Wales the Minister of Agricul¬
ture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretary of State for Wales, for Scotland
the Secretary of State for Scotland, and for Northern Ireland the Secretary
of State for Northern Ireland. The Advisory Council for Agriculture and
Horticulture in England and Wales provides the minister and his department
with independent advice on any agricultural or horticultural subjects remitted
to it.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food operates through func¬
tional divisions. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly
through its local offices, grouped in England in regions, with regional man¬
agers. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh Secretary with similar
functions and with special responsibility for Welsh affairs.
In 1966 an Economic Development Committee for agriculture was estab¬
lished, comprising representatives of farmers, workers and landowners, as well
as official and independent members.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
