Principal Ports
About 80,000 people are employed in Britain’s port transport industry ; of
these, 36,000 dockers, responsible for the physical and mechanical handling
of cargo, were registered with the National Dock Labour Board at the end of
T Q72
The system of casual labour common among dock workers in the past has
gradually been superseded. In 1947 the National Dock Labour Board was
established to administer a scheme under which registered dock workers
received a minimum wage for attendance even when no work was available.
In 1967 each registered dock worker was placed in employment on a per¬
manent basis with an employer licensed by the port authority, u^der 1 e
provisions of the Docks and Harbours Act 1966. In recent years there has been
a continuous decline in employment opportunities in the industry, due to
improvements in cargo-handling methods, and voluntary redundancy schemes
have been in operation since 1967 to encourage surplus workers to leave the
industry.
Nearly 350 million tonnes of cargo a year pass through the ports of Great
Britain. Of this total, coastal traffic accounts for 100 million tonnes consisting
mainly of petroleum and coal. Of nearly 200 million tonnes of imports from
overseas some 127 million tonnes consist of petroleum and petroleum pro¬
ducts. Manufactured goods form about two-fifths of exports.
A large proportion of the general cargo traffic through British ports is
handled by unitised transport methods in containers and roll-on goo s
vehicles, which carried 19 million tonnes of goods in 1971. British ports
handle more containers than the rest of northern European ports together and
account for the largest share of the container traffic across the North Atlantic.
London, with traffic rising by 12 per cent to 2-6 million tonnes was the
leading port for unit load traffic in 1972; Liverpool, Southampton, Dover and
Felixstowe also handled large amounts.
Britain’s largest port is that of London. In 1972 some 54 million tonnes of
goods were handled, including 27-5 million tonnes of petroleum and nearly
4 million tonnes of coal. . .
Liverpool is a very important export outlet, especially to deep-sea trad g
areas. Some 26 million tonnes of goods are handled annually, about one-half
consisting of dry cargo—grain, chemicals, iron and steel, and other manu¬
factures.

Terminals
HOVERCRAFT
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 347
Southampton is the chief port for ocean passenger traffic, and has a growing
general cargo trade. In 1972 it handled 31-3 million tonnes of goods, including
petroleum, fruit and vegetables, cereals and manufactured goods. It has the
advantages of deep water and double tides. Bristol, with Avonmouth, has a
large traffic in grain imports, and is Britain’s main port for imports of animal
feedingstuffs. The south Wales ports, which in 1972 handled 217 million
tonnes of goods, import much of Britain’s requirements of iron ore, especially
through Port Talbot.
Swansea is important for the export of coal, iron and steel and tinplate and
oil. Milford Haven, handling over 46 million tonnes, is Britain’s major oil port.
The inland port of Manchester, reached from the Mersey via the 36-mile
(58-kilometre) Manchester Ship Canal, has at Eastham Britain’s largest oil
dock, covering 19 acres (8 hectares), and exports manufactured goods and
chemicals.
In Scotland the Clyde is the principal port, serving the central industrial
area and possessing a crude oil terminal at Finnart. On the Forth, Grange¬
mouth is associated with petroleum, petro-chemicals and timber.
Newcastle and other ports on the Tyne serve England’s industrial north¬
east, and the port of Tees and Hartlepool handles iron ore, steel and engineer¬
ing products, and chemicals, especially fertilisers. Hull and Grimsby on the
Humber handle about 36 per cent of the wet fish landed in Britain and are
among the largest white fish ports in the world. With Immingham they serve
the industrial areas of northern England and the Midlands, especially in trade
with Scandinavian and Baltic ports. Belfast is the principal port of Northern
Ireland and with Larne handles the main traffic across the Irish Sea.
Most of the oil tankers coming to Britain to discharge crude oil are berthed at
special tanker terminals owned and operated by the oil companies to serve
their own refineries.
British ports offer the deepest water access in Northern Europe for fully-
laden tankers to pipe crude oil direct to refineries. Milford Haven can accom¬
modate fully-laden vessels of 250,000 deadweight tons on all tides at four
private oil company terminals. Finnart on the Clyde will accept vessels of
325,000 deadweight tons and can be readily adapted to accept the half-million-
ton tankers of the future; it is frequently used in lightening operations to
allow part-laden vessels to proceed with shallower draft to other ports in
Northern Europe. At Tetney Haven off the mouth of the Humber, fully-laden
tankers discharge at Britain’s first offshore mooring monobuoy, a large buoy
anchored in deep water with a connecting pipeline to the shore.
Pipelines connect Finnart with the refinery at Grangemouth on the Firth
of Forth, Angle Bay with the refinery at Llandarcy (near Swansea) and Stan-
low (Merseyside) with the refinery at Heysham (Lancashire). A ^7 million
crude oil terminal to handle tankers of 250,000 deadweight tons is to be built
at Hound Point, near Edinburgh. Crude oil will be piped from the Forties
Field (see p. 275) to Cruden Bay and thence by land pipeline to Grangemouth.
The hovercraft, a vehicle invented in Britain which rides on a cushion of air
over both land and water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service
around the coasts of Britain since 1965. Services are run by several privately
owned firms, these include Hoverlloyd Ltd., which has a purpose-built
hoverport at Pegwell Bay in connection with its car and passenger ferries
between Ramsgate and Calais, and Hovertravel Ltd., which operates across
the Solent to the Isle of Wight and has a subsidiary which does training and
348
BRITAIN 1974" OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
charter work. Two publicly owned bodies, the British Railways Board and the
Scottish Transport Group, have hovercraft interests. British Railways
subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd. (‘Seaspeed’), was set up in 1966, and
is the world’s largest commercial hovercraft operator. It runs regular services
across the Channel between Dover and Boulogne, and Dover and Calais,
carrying passengers and accompanied cars. It also operates two services across
the Solent, and takes on charter work. During i973 a privately operated
hovercraft service was started on the Thames between Greenwich and West¬
minster. The service, which is primarily intended for commuters, is being
financially assisted by the Government and the Greater London Council.
INLAND TRANSPORT
The dense passenger and freight traffic of Great Britain is carried mainly by
road and rail, although coastal shipping and, to a lesser extent, pipelines and
inland waterways are important in carrying certain types of freight, particu¬
larly bulk goods. A small proportion of freight goes by air.
Part of the inland transport system of Great Britain is publicly owne .
the railways, a large proportion of road passenger and some road haulage
services, most of the inland waterways and some of the vessels on them. Road
haulage is largely, and coastal shipping almost entirely, in the hands of private
^Indie third quarter of 1972 there were 16-1 million vehicles licensed for
use on the roads. Of these 127 million were motor cars, 970,000 motor cycles
and i-6 million road goods vehicles; about two-thirds of the 77,000 pub ic
road passenger vehicles (excluding taxis) were publicly owned.
In 1972 about 64 per cent of freight, in terms of ton-mileage/ travelled by
road, 18 per cent by rail, 16 per cent by coastal shipping, and 2 per cent by
pipeline and inland waterway.
Since 1945 the rapid growth of private and commercial motor traffic, causing
congestion problems of increasing severity, especially in cities and towns, and
the changing pattern of demand for transport services have led successive
governments to undertake or commission fundamental studies of probab e
trends in transport and problems which may arise therefrom. The Buchanan
report, published in 1963, was the result of a study group set up to examine t e
problems of traffic in urban areas which proposed radical measures to rebuild
and adapt cities and roads to handle the growth of traffic. It is expected that
the number of vehicles on the roads will double by the year 2000
Total passenger mileage is expected to increase by about a third during the
next ten years with most of this increase being due to private transport To a
freight ton-mileage is expected to increase substantially, although fuel traffic
will fall as a result of structural and technological change.
Research is being carried out into new forms of inter-urban travel, such as
high-speed passenger trains, which incorporate new forms of suspension, and
vertical take-off aircraft. . . , , 1
The railway network has been reduced by over a third in the past decade
but it was decided in 1967 to fix a basic network of some 11,000 route-miles
(I7,70o route-kilometres) for modernisation and development.

war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated into four
large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they suffered
from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition from road
transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act 1947
brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise, British
Railways. Under the Transport Act 1962 the British Railways Board was set
up and came into existence in 1963 with sole responsibility for managing
railway affairs.
In spite of technical and operational advances the board’s financial position
remained unsatisfactory and, following a detailed review of railway policy,
the 1968 Transport Act made far-reaching changes. Capital debt was written
down from £1,627 million (of which £705 million had already been suspended
under the 1962 Act) to £365 million. Grants were introduced for loss-making
rail passenger services which it was considered desirable to maintain for social
or economic reasons; £68-1 million was so paid in 1972. Grants not exceeding
a total of £50 million were paid to the board on a gradually diminishing scale
during the years 1969 to 1973 towards the cost of maintaining surplus track
and signalling equipment pending their elimination; £8 million was paid in
1972. Deficit financing ceased and the board was then expected to pay its way.
During 1972 the board’s financial position again deteriorated following a
dispute with the railway workers, resulting in a substantial pay award, and a
miners’ strike which severely reduced carryings of coal. The Government has,
in this case, provided a substantial grant.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 6,677 mdes (10,746 kilometres) to
11,537 miles (18,567 kilometres) of standard-gauge route since 1961. A total
of 754 million passenger journeys was made and 175 million tons of freight
traffic conveyed on the railways in 1972; total railway receipts amounted to
£632*4 million. The board made a loss of £26*2 million following interest
payments of £51*1 million. At the end of 1972 it employed 256,000 people.
In 1972 a subsidiary, British Transport Hotels Ltd., owned 33 hotels of
which it managed 31. It also managed the catering facilities on trains and in
station refreshment rooms.
A subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., runs regular hovercraft services
(see p. 348).
British Rail’s Shipping and International Services division, which carries
more sea-going passengers than any other fleet in the world, operated in 1972
a fleet of 60 vessels, providing passenger and freight services on most of the
important routes between Britain and the Irish Republic and on the short-sea
routes to the continent of Europe, as well as on some domestic routes. Owner¬
ship of domestic services in Scotland was transferred to the Scottish Transport
Group under the Transport Act 1968; its two shipping subsidiaries own some
32 vessels between them.
The board’s second five-year corporate plan was produced in 1972. Plans are
revised annually and provide a comprehensive analysis of the perform¬
ance and investment requirements of all sectors of the business. In recent
years the most important developments have been the replacement of steam
by diesel and electric traction completed in 1968; the improvement of inter¬
city passenger services with the emphasis on speed, reliability and comfort;
the introduction of express freight services (‘freightliners’) enabling freight
to be handled throughout transit in standard containers (the responsibility

At the end of 1972 there were 3,683 diesel and 317 electric locomotives. In
addition there were 3,467 diesel and 7,071 electric passenger-carrying multiple
unit vehicles.
The board’s current programme includes the replacement of old passenger
coaches by new stock with improved amenities, and the construction of new
electric multiple unit stock to replace old vehicles. On certain sections of the
London-Bristol-south Wales line and of the London-Edinburgh line pass¬
enger trains are permitted to run up to 100 mph (161 kph). Similar speeds are
also in operation on the London Midland Region’s sendees on the electrified
line between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool. This electri¬
fication scheme, costing some £160 million and completed m 1967, was the
largest individual capital investment project ever undertaken by the British
Railways Board and included station reconstruction, bridgeworks, a new
colour-light signalling system and new rolling stock. An approximate increase
of 150 per cent in numbers of passengers has followed. Electrification is being
extended by 235 route-miles (378 route-kilometres) to Glasgow at a cost of
/25 million; a £30-4 million route rationalisation and resignallmg scheme is
associated with it. A £10 million scheme, due for completion in 1974, is to
provide an extension to the Mersey underground railway in central Liverpool.
Motorail services (carrying both passengers and cars) have an annua
capacity of 100,000 cars on 31 services.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new vehicles come into
service and as facilities for concentrating traffic at fewer and better equipped
and sited marshalling yards and terminals are completed. The freighthner
services, the responsibility of Freighthners Ltd. (see p. 35i)> serve a network
of 28 main terminals. Services are operated throughout the country and to t re
continent of Europe. The first freightliner ran in 1965.
The London International Freight Terminal links the British Railways
Board container port of Harwich with the main freighthner network. New
terminals were opened in 1972 at the docks at Southampton, Barking (London)
and Felixstowe. The first fully cellular container ships built m a British yard
are being used in the board’s container services between Harwich and Zee-
brugge, opened in 1968.
The Total Operations Processing System, a computer system allowing
constant and close control of all freight trains, is to be introduced in south¬
west England in 1973 and extended to the whole of Great Britain by 1975.
The most important freight commodities are coal and steel. The long-haul
carriage of many products in bulk is increasing. Long-term contracts are m
operation for the carriage of cars, oil, china clay, milk, grain, newspapers, steel,
chemicals and other goods. Coal is fed direct from collieries to power stations
in ‘merry-go-round' trains, on which coal is loaded and discharged automati-
cally from high-capacity wagons.
British Railways Board’s subsidiary, British Rail Engineering Ltd., had in
1972 14 main workshops, employing some 35,300 people, mostly on repairs
and construction of rolling stock, locomotives and containers.
The Railway Technical Centre at Derby covers 20 acres (8 hectares) and
employs about 2,000 people. Work is proceeding on a large number of pro¬
jects, a major one being the development of a 155 mph (250 kph) advance

system and some smaller projects, it is being given government financial help.
The National Freight Corporation was set up under the 1968 Transport Act
to provide and promote the provision of integrated road and rail freight
services, making the maximum economic use of rail. The corporation took
over all the road haulage and most of the shipping interests of the Transport
Holding Company, disposing of its shipping interests in 1971, and from the
British Railways Board the depots, vehicles, warehouses, containers and other
equipment, though not the actual trains used, in the freightliners and sundries
sendees, and also the board’s road haulage vehicles. It has a capital of about
£110 million, and employs 52,000 people; annual turnover amounts to some
£203 million.
Freightliners Ltd., a company jointly owned by the Freight Corporation
and the British Railways Board (with 51 per cent and 49 per cent of the shares
respectively), is responsible for the marketing and management of freight-
liner sendees. The British Railways Board makes a charge for providing and
hauling the trains, and profits are divided between the board and the corpora¬
tion in proportion to their holdings.
A Freight Integration Council, set up under the 1968 Act, advises the Depart¬
ment of the Environment and the Secretary' of State for Scotland on the pro¬
vision of integrated freight services by publicly owned bodies. It consists of
several independent members with an independent chairman, the chairmen
of the Freight Corporation and the British Railways Board, and members
representing union interests.
Following completion of final studies into the financial and technical feasibility
of a bored rail tunnel under the Channel, the British Government announced
in September 1973 that it intended, subject to Parliamentary approval, to
proceed with the project in association with the French Government and an
international group of banking and other interests. The tunnel would provide
ferry7 train sendees for road vehicles in addition to through rail services.
A large and steadily expanding road-building programme has been in progress
since 1955. Public expenditure on the construction and improvement of roads
in Great Britain is estimated at over ^600 million in 1973-74.
Roads are classified according to their traffic value. Trunk roads provide
a national network of routes for through traffic; other roads are divided for
grant purposes into principal and non-principal roads. Motorways are roads
specially designed for high-speed traffic only.
In June 1973 Great Britain had nearly 211,000 miles (339,000 kilometres)
of public highway. There were 9,000 miles (15,000 kilometres) of trunk roads,
of which 1,059 miles (1,704 kilometres) were motorways; 20,000 miles (33,000
kilometres) of principal roads, of which some 34 miles (55 kilometres) were
motorways, and 181,000 miles (291,000 kilometres) of other roads, including
unsurfaced roads.
At the end of June 1973 in England 941 miles (1,514 kilometres) of motorways
had been opened for traffic and construction had started on a further 235 miles
(378 kilometres). Schemes for an additional 548 miles (882 kilometres) were
being prepared. In Wales 27 miles (43 kilometres) were in use. In Scotland
about 91 miles (146 kilometres) of motorway had been opened and construc¬
tion had started on a further 16 miles (26 kilometres), while schemes for an

A government programme aims to complete by the early 1980s a comprehen¬
sive network of 3,500 miles (5,633 kilometres) of strategic trunk routes, in¬
cluding about 2,000 miles (3,219 kilometres) of motorway, serving the major
ports, airports and industrial centres and linking remote regions to the motor¬
way network.
A large programme of bridge and tunnel building has been undertaken in
recent years. The bridges include the suspension bridge across the Firth of
Forth, the Severn Bridge incorporating major advances in suspension bridge
design, the 7,000-ft (2,134-metre) bridge across the Firth of Tay and the
3,200-ft (975-metre) Weaver Viaduct in Cheshire. The new ^5-5 million
London Bridge over the river Thames was officially opened in 1973. A £26
million bridge across the river Humber, with a span of 4,626 feet (1,410 metres)
—longer than any existing bridge span in the world—is to be completed in
1976-77.
Among several major tunnel schemes is a second Mersey crossing of which
the first of the twin tunnels was opened in 1971; the second is due for comple¬
tion in 1974. A second crossing of the Thames at Hartford, Kent, is also under
construction.
The Secretary of State for the Environment is the highway authority for
trunk roads in England and on these roads he administers expenditure, which
is provided wholly from central government sources, although for many pur¬
poses he employs local authorities as his agents. The Secretary of State for
Scotland has corresponding responsibilities for roads in Scotland and the
Secretary of State for Wales for roads in Wales. Work on major trunk road
schemes in England, including motorways, is controlled by regional road con¬
struction units, manned jointly by Department of the Environment and county
council staff. The highway authority for principal roads is, in general, the
council of the county or county borough in whose area the roads lie. The
Secretary of State makes specific grants towards approved expenditure on con¬
struction and major improvement of these roads and contributions from public
funds towards maintenance and other expenditure are made through grants to
local authorities. Roads other than trunk and principal roads are entirely the
responsibility of the local authority in whose area they lie.
Research on roads is carried out at the Transport and Road Research Labora¬
tory (see p. 395). The laboratory provides technical and scientific advice and
information to help in formulating, developing and implementing government
policies relating to roads and transport, including their interaction with urban
and regional planning. Work is concerned with planning, design, construction
and maintenance of roads and structures such as bridges and tunnels; safe,
efficient and convenient movement of people and goods, including road layout
and transport networks, control of traffic flow, study of road accidents and
methods of reducing their frequency and severity; assessment of existing and
projected passenger or freight transport systems and investigation of technical
developments and their environmental effects.
In 1972 there were 16-1 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great Britain’s
roads. Of these i-6 million were goods vehicles and 105,000 were public road
passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).

BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Road Traffic Act 19301 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas
each under the control of three traffic commissioners. The commissioners are
responsible for ensuring the fitness of vehicles used in public road passenger-
transport, and for licensing services in order to secure proper co-ordination
and to eliminate unnecessary competition; to this end they may fix routes,
timetables and fares.
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing for
road haulage vehicles designed to restrict vehicle operations to proved needs.
A new goods vehicle licensing system, aimed solely at improving safety, has
been introduced as provided under the i ransport Act 1968. I hose opeiating
vehicles of over 3^ tons gross weight now require an operator’s licence,
obtained on showing ability to maintain vehicles properly and control loading
and hours worked by drivers. It may also be necessary to demonstrate adequate
financial resources for compliance with these conditions. Licences are granted
by independent, quasi-judicial licensing authorities, and may be revoked,
suspended or curtailed if necessary. Regulations concerning the fitness and
loading of vehicles have become more stringent under recent legislation.
Holders of operators’ licences may carry their own or other people’s goods and
are free of statutory control over their charges. Over 900,000 goods vehicles
not exceeding 3^ tons gross laden weight are exempt from operators’ licensing.
European Community rules setting new requirements for drivers’ hours, rest
periods, records and daily distances applied in Britain from April 1973 to
commercial vehicles on international journeys. Journeys entirely within Great
Britain, regulated under the Transport Act 1968, will become subject to the
Community rules from 1st January 1976 with the exception of most bus
services. The European Community rules limit drivers in general to eight
hours’ driving a day.
From 1956 to 1963 the nationalised road haulage services were controlled by
British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British Transport Commission,
and operated through five companies, which together owned about 16,000
vehicles. Under the Transport Act 1962, these organisations operated com¬
panies incorporated under the Companies Act, with their own boards, and
were grouped together under the Transport Holding Company, responsible
to the then Minister of Transport. The road haulage interests of the Holding
Company have been transferred to the National Freight Corporation (see p.
351), which operates some 24,000 vehicles.
The 1968 Transport Act enables Passenger Transport Authorities (PTAs) to
be set up to control and co-ordinate the different forms of transport in any
particular area. Five PTAs have been set up in south-east Lancashire-north¬
east Cheshire, Merseyside, the west Midlands, Tyneside and Greater Glasgow.
The constituent local authorities appoint most of the members, but up to one-
seventh may be appointed by the Secretary of State for the Environment (or
by the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales). Each appoints its own
chairman, with the relevant Secretary of State’s approval. The PTAs control
policy and finance, and appoint professional executives—Passenger Transport
Executives—to be responsible to them for day-to-day operations. The execu¬
tives may operate services themselves and enter into agreements with other
bodies, such as the British Railways Board or the National Bus Company, to
1 Consolidated in the Road Traffic Act i960.

Road Safety
355
operate others; they have taken over all the former municipal bus undertakings
in their areas. In 1972 the four English PTAs became responsible for local
rail services in their areas and have since reached agreement with the British
Railways Board on their future operation. The Greater Glasgow PTA will
eventually assume a similar responsibility. From April 1974 the role of the
PTAs will be assumed by the new metropolitan county councils in England
and two new PTAs will be set up for the metropolitan counties of South
Yorkshire and West Yorkshire.
The National Bus Company was formed to take over the former bus
operating and manufacturing subsidiaries of the Transport Holding Company
in England and Wales, and operates through locally based subsidiaries.
A separate Scottish Transport Group was set up to control bus and some
shipping services in Scotland, and took over the relevant interests of the
Transport Holding Company, operating through subsidiaries.
The National Bus Company and the Scottish Transport Group operate
some 20,000 and 4,500 vehicles respectively. The PTAs control some 6,250
vehicles and London Transport a further 6,000. In addition, there are 68
local authority undertakings operating 10,600 vehicles and 5,053 privately
owned fleets (of which 3,721 have five vehicles or less) comprising some
25,300 vehicles.
Capital grants may be made by the Government towards the cost of invest¬
ment in public transport, at rates of up to 75 per cent of approved cost. Eligible
schemes include improvements or extensions of railway lines, new fixed track
rail and bus systems, interchanges, stations, car parks, urban and suburban
railway rolling-stock, resignalling, train control systems and automatic fare
collection. Grants at the rate of 50 per cent are available towards the cost of
new buses complying with specifications approved by the Department of the
Environment. Local authorities may assist unremunerative bus services in
rural areas and where they do so the Government reimburses half their expen¬
diture. The Government also refunds part of the tax charged on fuel used on
local bus services, both urban and rural.
Britain has one of the highest densities of road traffic in the world but a rela¬
tively good accident record, the fatal accident rate per vehicle being lower
than that in most other European countries. In 1972, 7,800 people were killed
on the roads and about 91,000 seriously injured. Road accident statistics are
compiled and published by the Government Statistical Service from reports
made by the police.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. Measures directed primarily towards
road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 mph (48 and 64 kph) in built-up
areas and 50 mph (80 kph) on certain trunk and important classified roads in
rural areas; a 70 mph (113 kph) speed limit on all motorways and on all other
roads where no lower limit applies; the provision of pedestrian crossings; and
the system of road markings and traffic signs which are being replaced by
improved signs in accordance with general European practice. A centrally
controlled, computerised signalling system is being installed on motorways
to warn motorists of advisory speed limits in certain conditions and of lane
closures.
The design of vehicles, their use on the roads, and the maintenance of their
mechanical condition are controlled by regulations. The regulations are kept
under constant review, and amended whenever necessary in the interests of
0 BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
safety or for control of pollution and noise. The fitting of seat belts to the front
seats is compulsory for cars first registered in or after 1965 and for light goods
vehicles first registered in or after 1967. Private cars and light vans which are
three or more years old must be tested annually at private garages authorised as
test stations. Heavy goods vehicles are tested annually at government test
stations. Public service vehicles must be specially approved before being
licensed to carry passengers, and are tested at regular intervals. Any vehicle
may be stopped on the road at any time by the police and examined.
All drivers of motor vehicles, unless they have either held a full British
licence or passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the
test before being granted a full licence to drive. Until they pass the test they
must obtain a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’
(Learner) plates on their vehicle. With the exception of solo motor-cycles and
motor-cycle combinations, where vehicles are constructed to carry passengers,
learner drivers must be accompanied by a qualified driver. (Newly arrived
residents of Britain may drive under their overseas driving licences for three
months before becoming subject to these rules.) A learner driver of a solo
motor-cycle is restricted, until he passes the driving test, to a machine not
exceeding 250 cc. Professional driving instructors must be approved by the
Department of the Environment. There is a scheme for special licensing and
testing of drivers of heavy goods vehicles.
The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 26
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users and a summary of the requirements of
the law are set out in easily understandable form in the Highway Code. A failure
to observe the code does not of itself render a person liable to criminal pro¬
ceedings but may be taken into account in any such proceedings. The Road
Safety Act 1967 made it an offence to drive with more than a prescribed level
of alcohol in the blood, at present 80 milligrammes of alcohol per 100 milli¬
litres of blood. The wearing of safety helmets by all riders of motor-cycles,
scooters and mopeds was made compulsory in 1973.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads are
conducted by the Department of the Environment and the Royal Society for
the Prevention of Accidents with assistance from the local authorities, which
also help by arranging courses of instruction, especially courses for children.
Control of Traffic The Road Traffic Regulation Act 1967 empowers traffic authorities to make
orders regulating traffic and imposing parking control. With the exception of
trunk roads, which are the concern of the central Government, traffic is the
responsibility of local authorities. Extensive schemes are being undertaken
for the improvement of road safety and the relief of traffic congestion. These
include: ‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet roads from cities; and traffic
management measures, including comprehensive control of street parking,
‘one-way’ systems, peak hour ‘clearways’ prohibiting waiting on busy roads,
the restriction of traffic in some streets to buses, taxis and delivery vehicles,
and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements. Lanes reserved for buses are being introduced
in many large towns. A Traffic Advisory Unit within the Department of the
Environment advises local authorities. In most town centres street parking is
permitted for limited periods only; in London and many other towns schemes
for payment at parking meters or residents’ parking spaces are under the
supervision of traffic wardens. Disc schemes providing free but limited parking
facilities are in operation in some towns, including Cheltenham, Devizes,

LONDON

The London

System
INLAND
WATERWAYS
Harrogate and Ripon. The Government is identifying and acquiring a national
network of long-distance lorry parks. A computer-controlled system to
regulate traffic was installed in west London in 1968. Similar systems are
operating in Glasgow and Liverpool. The Government is devising, in co¬
operation with local authorities, a system of advisory lorry routes. In the
interest of environmental improvement, long-distance and in particular heavy
goods traffic, is being diverted from many towns and villages; from October
1973 lorries of 40 feet (12 metres) and longer will be banned from travelling
into central London except for delivery purposes.
London is one of the world’s largest cities. The area known as Greater London,
within a radius of about 15 miles (24 kilometres) from Charing Cross, contains
7-3 million people.
The Greater London Council (GLC) is the transport planning authority for
London as a whole and has responsibility for the central bus and Underground
rail services. These services are managed and operated by the London Trans¬
port Executive, appointed by and responsible to the GLC. The buses serving
areas around London and the long-distance Green Line coach services are run
by London Country Bus Services Ltd., a subsidiary of the National Bus
Company.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of the British Railways Board, the Green Line coach services, London Country
Bus Services and the taxicabs. Some 10,000 taxicabs that ply for hire in the
streets are privately operated by companies or owner-drivers and are licensed
annually by the Metropolitan Police. There are about 14,000 licensed cab
drivers. In addition, numerous car-hire firms are in operation.
London Transport’s railway network stretches over 20 miles (32 kilometres)
from north to south and 35 miles (56 kilometres) from east to west. In January
1973 the total length of the railway over which London Transport trains
operated was 252 miles (406 kilometres), of which 99 miles (159 kilometres)
were underground. London Transport trains serve 279 stations and its buses
travel over 1,722 miles (2,772 kilometres) of roads. To carry traffic over all this
area London Transport owns 4,357 railway cars and 6,342 buses. The total
staff employed is over 57,000.
Improvements being carried out by London Transport have included
extension and modernisation of parts of the Underground system, and the
introduction of automatic fare collection and automatic trains. One-man
operation of buses is being steadily extended over a period of years. The
first one-man-operated double decker buses were introduced in 1969; there
are to be some 1,500 of these by 1975. Experimental ‘minibus’ services are in
operation.
Work on a 14-mile (23-kilometre) underground railway—the Victoria
Line—between Walthamstow in north-east London and Brixton in south
London was completed in 1971 and work begun on a scheme to link Heathrow
airport with the Underground railway system. Construction of the first stage
of the new Fleet Line began early in 1972.
London Transport operates an international advisory service for city trans¬
port.
Since 1963 control of the majority of inland waterways has been vested in the
British Waterways Board. Under the Transport Act 1968 a grant-in-aid is
358
The System
Development
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
being paid primarily to enable the board to maintain an extensive network of
amenity waterways; in 1972 £3 million was paid and a further £1 million for
improving bridges.
There are about 2,500 miles (4,023 kilometres) of navigable inland waterways
in Great Britain, some 2,000 miles (3,219 kilometres) of which belong to
the British Waterways Board; the remainder are mainly in the hands of local
authorities or private companies. Many of the board’s canals are narrow water¬
ways which can generally be used only by boats not exceeding 7 ft (2-13 metres)
in width; the remainder are broad waterways and canalised rivers, some of
which can be used by craft of up to about 750 tons capacity. The Caledonian
and Crinan Canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the inland waterways
under the control of the British Waterways Board some 340 miles (547
kilometres) are commercial waterways, which are mainly canalised river
navigations. A substantial additional mileage (1,100 miles—1,770 kilometres—
known as cruising waterways) is being maintained for recreational purposes; a
statutory Inland Waterways Amenity Advisory Council advises the Secretary
of State for the Environment and the British Waterways Board.
Engineering, commercial and estate work is directed from the board’s head¬
quarters in London. There are also principal offices at Leeds and Gloucester.
In Scotland the Caledonian Canal and the other Scottish canals are, for en¬
gineering and estate purposes, under the control of the board s office in
Glasgow, with direction as a whole from London.
In 1972 traffic on the board’s waterways amounted to just over 4-9 million
tons, of which i*8 million tons were coal, 1*4 million tons liquids in bulk and
1 *7 million tons general cargo. Some 96 per cent of the traffic is carried on the
commercial waterways.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying operator,
most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders in their
own craft. The board at the end of 1972 owned 460 freight-carrying craft
(including tugs) with a carrying capacity of 20,300 tons. It operates 3 docks
and 19 warehousing depots.
In Northern Ireland, the only inland waterway which is still used tor com¬
mercial transport purposes is the Lower Bann Navigation.
The British Waterways Board is developing its cruising waterways for purposes
of recreation and amenity. Among the most popular are the Llangollen branch
of the Shropshire Union Canal, the Oxford Canal, and the Leeds and Liver¬
pool Canal. The principal commercial waterways are the river navigations and
broad canals in the Yorkshire-Humberside area, the Trent Navigation, and the
Gloucester and Sharpness Canal. Freight traffic is declining, but some im¬
provements to facilities are being carried out. The board has devised and is
already operating on some of its commercial waterways a specially designe
interlocking modular barge system. A European consortium is building a
ship capable of carrying the barges between Britain and the rest of Europe.
The total turnover of the British Waterways Board in 1972 amounted to
fc-q million, of which £0-2 million arose from the board’s own freight¬
carrying activities, £1-4 million from warehousing and terminal services, and
/i-2 million from the docks. The sale of water for industrial and agricultural
purposes brought in nearly £1 million. Receipts from pleasure boating were
£246,700. The number of pleasure craft licensed or registered in 1972 was
18,025.

PUBLIC

IN NORTHERN
IRELAND
Roads
The operation of the railway service and Government-owned bus service in
Northern Ireland is the responsibility of the Northern Ireland Transport
Holding Company. The Northern Ireland Railways Company Ltd., a subsi¬
diary of the Holding Company, operates the railway service. Improvements to
the rail system under a modernisation scheme involve the re-opening of several
stretches of line closed in earlier years and the introduction of new rolling
stock.
Ulsterbus Ltd., another subsidiary of the Holding Company, provides all
public road passenger services, apart from those of the City of Belfast. A new
company, Citybus Ltd., has been set up in Belfast combining the city opera¬
tions of the bus services of Ulsterbus and Belfast Corporation. A number of
privately owned bus companies now operate in addition.
There is a licensing system for road haulage operation. About 1,600 operators
and 3,600 vehicles are licensed, the biggest single operator being Northern
Ireland Carriers Ltd., owned jointly by the Northern Ireland Transport
Holding Company and the British National Freight Corporation.
On 31st March 1973 there were 14,189 miles (22,835 kilometres) of public
roads in Northern Ireland, comprising 317 miles (510 kilometres) of trunk
roads, 1,026 miles (1,651 kilometres) of Class I roads, 1,737 miles (2,795
kilometres) of Class II roads, 2,887 miles (4,646 kilometres) of Class III roads
and 8,222 miles (13,232 kilometres) of unclassified roads.
The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and construction work on
these roads. From October 1973 the Ministry will also be responsible for the
other roads, at present the responsibility of the local authorities; its Road
Executive will have local offices throughout the Province.
In addition to major construction schemes on trunk roads, an extensive
system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway system in
Belfast. About 60 miles (97 kilometres) of motorway were in use by September
1973. The most recently opened length of motorway is a 2^-mile (4-kilometre)
section, constructed mainly on land reclaimed from the Belfast lough fore¬
shore; it has a dual four-lane carriageway, the widest motorway in Europe.
The estimated gross capital expenditure on all roads in the financial year to
31st March 1972 was £12 million, and expenditure on maintenance and minor
improvements was about £8 million. Gross capital expenditure in the five-year
period 1970-74 is expected to be about £100 million, compared with about £62
million in the five-year period to 31st March 1969. Expenditure on main¬
tenance and minor improvements in the five-year period to 31st March 1972
was ^40-4 million.
CIVIL AVIATION
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited and this company pioneered the commercial development of inter¬
continental air routes. By 1929 there was a through service from England to
India. The first passenger service to Australia started in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation (BOAC), a public corporation,
took over the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways
Limited in 1940. British European Airways (BEA) was established under the
Civil Aviation Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United
Kingdom and Europe.
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
BOAC and BEA have become divisions of British Airways (see p. 362) follow¬
ing a major reorganisation of the control of British civil aviation through the
Civil Aviation Act 1971. Under this Act were created the Civil Aviation
Authority (CAA) and the British Airways Board (BAB—to run British
Airways—see p. 362). The new bodies became fully operative on 1st April
1972.
The Secretary of State for Trade and Industry is responsible for international
matters (including negotiation of air service agreements with other countries,
the licensing and control of public transport operations into Britain by over¬
seas operators and British participation in the activities of the International
Civil Aviation Organisation and other international aviation bodies), amenity
matters such as aircraft noise, and investigation of accidents. The Secretary
of State appoints the chairman and other members of the CAA, and is
empowered to give written guidances on the general policies to be followed. The
guidances must be approved by both Houses of Parliament, and the CAA is
then bound by them.
The Secretary of State may also give directions, after consultations, to the
CAA, concerning Britain’s relations with other countries, membership of
international organisations or adherence to international agreements, or to
deal with problems of noise, vibration, pollution or other disturbances arising
from the activities of civil aviation. He may also give directions, after consulta¬
tion, to the BAB concerning matters affecting the public interest. He has
powers to make funds available to the BAB, with the approval of the Treasury
and within limits laid down by Parliament (see p. 362).
The Civil Aviation Authority is separate from and largely independent of the
Government, and responsible for the economic, technical and operational
regulation of the industry, the provision of air navigation services and the
operation of Aberdeen Airport and the Scottish Highlands and Islands aero¬
dromes. It issues licences and certificates to airlines, aircraft, aerodromes and
personnel, including pilots, air traffic controllers and maintenance engineers.
The CAA has been given the objective of recovering, by 1977-78, the whole
of its costs and a reasonable return on capital from the users of its services.
Because it does not itself fix charges for navigation services and because inter¬
national agreement is necessary on charges for navigation services made during
the course of a journey it will take some time to reach this objective, meanwhile
the Government is to pay a diminishing grant to meet its deficit on revenue
account, to be assessed annually in advance; it amounted to some £29 million
in the first year.
The Civil Aviation Authority operates an air services licensing system, within
which British operators, both state-owned and independent, apply on an equal
footing for licences for scheduled and charter services, or for revocation or
variation of existing licences. It determines categories of licence, content of
applications, and conditions and tariff provisions of licences. It also has power
to exempt particular flights or categories of flights from licence requirements.
In issuing licences the CAA must consider the applicants’ financial resources,
staffing and organisation, the need for the proposed services, their adequacy
and possible effect on existing services, and any representations made by
interested parties. Appeals may be made to the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry. A new CAA scheme for licensing air travel organisers came into
operation in May 1973*

The CAA is responsible for ensuring the safe operation of civil aircraft, and
initiating relevant preventive measures and research. Its Airworthiness Divi¬
sion is responsible for the code, British Civil Airworthiness Requirements,
with which all aircraft built in Britain must comply. Continued airworthiness
is ensured by regular inspection and by requiring aircraft to be maintained in
accordance with a schedule approved by the CAA. The authority is advised by
an Airworthiness Requirements Board representing the users.
Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the CAA when
it is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure the safe operation of his
aircraft. It is advised by the flight operations inspectors (who are experienced
airline pilots). In addition to British Airways 55 independent air transport
operators hold an Air Operator’s Certificate.
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
In order to increase the supply of well-trained pilots for civil airlines, the
College of Air Training was set up at Hamble in i960. It is now sponsored by
the Government and British Airways. Commercial pilots must attend a course
of training approved by the Civil Aviation Authority. Such courses have been
approved at the training schools at Carlisle, Oxford and Perth, in addition to
Hamble. An engineering apprentice school was set up at Cranebank, near
Heathrow, in 1970.
An Air Transport and Travel Industry Training Board has been established
under the Industrial Training Act 1964.
Responsibility for policy planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the National Air Traffic Services, under the joint control of the Civil
Aviation Authority and the Secretary of State for Defence.
In 1950 a system of airways covering the main traffic routes with control zones
around the major airports was introduced. Subsequently, the airway system
has been revised and extended to meet traffic requirements, employing
principally very high frequency omnirange beacons as the primary navigation
aid. There are three main air traffic control centres: at London for southern
England, at Preston for the north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for
Scotland and the Atlantic Ocean to 3o°W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic. During
the next few years, under a scheme which will eventually cost over £50 million,
virtually the whole of the airspace over Britain above 5,000 feet (1,500 metres)
will be brought under surveillance by the latest types of primary and secondary
radar equipment, which will provide data to be used in two air traffic control
centres, located at West Drayton (near London) and Prestwick. The first
stage was introduced in 1971. A subsidiary centre will be located at Manchester
to deal with traffic in the Manchester terminal control area. Extensive use will
be made in these centres of automatic data processing and other advanced
electronic techniques.
Britain has pioneered the development of all-weather landing systems, based
on an improved version of the standard instrument landing system used at all

major airports. The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft
Establishment at Bedford and private industry have worked towards fully
automatic landing. Both VCios and Tridents now make regular automatic
landings on scheduled flights.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency concerned
with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of high-flying,
high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the higher flight
levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating according to civil
procedures.
Since 1971 all new types of subsonic aircraft using British airports have been
required to hold a ‘certificate of quietness’. The noise standards laid down in
the certificate follow the recommendations of the special meeting held by the
International Civil Aviation Organisation in Montreal in 1969.
Noise abatement measures in force at various airports include limitations
on noise levels at take-off, route restrictions, procedures designed to lessen
noise on the ground, and limits on the number of jet movements during
summer nights.
The British Airways Board (BAB) controls the activities of the seven divisions
of British Airways—British Airways Overseas Division, British Airways
European Division, British Airways Regional Division, British Airways
Associated Companies Ltd., British Airways Helicopters Ltd., British Air¬
ways Engine Overhaul Ltd. and International Aeradio Ltd. The chairman
and members of the BAB are appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry. Its total borrowing and investment limit is fixed at £56° million; it
may be increased up to £700 million by statutory order. During the year
!972-73 the board earned ^539 million revenue and made a net profit of £5
million. British Airways has the largest route network in the world, almost
500,000 miles (800,000 kilometres), covering 200 destinations in 88 countries.
The Overseas Division is engaged on long-haul operations. Its scheduled ser¬
vices link Britain with continental Europe, the Middle East, the Far East,
Australasia, Africa and North and South America, and also provide complete
round-the-world services. The capacity offered on the division’s total services
reached 2,922 million capacity-ton-miles in the year ended March i973>
some 49 per cent of which was on the western routes to North and South
America. It has a charter subsidiary, BOA Charter Ltd.
The European Division operates on short-haul and medium-haul services in
Britain and the rest of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. It also
operates BEA Airtours Ltd., a charter subsidiary.
The Regional Division is responsible for the secondary domestic services and
for a network of services to Europe operated by Cambrian Airways, Northeast
Airlines, Scottish Airways and Channel Islands Airways. Its services in Britain
include a number which meet a vital social need, mainly the services to and
from the Highlands and Islands of Scotland.
British Airways Associated Companies Ltd. is responsible for the group’s
investments in some 40 hotel companies and ten airlines in different parts of
the world. The helicopter division—British Airways Helicopters Ltd.—
operates a scheduled service between Penzance, Cornwall, and the Isles of
Scilly, undertakes charter work and provides links between oil rigs in the
North Sea and the mainland. Engine overhaul work for British Airways and

The British Airways fleet of some 220 aircraft in May 1973 is the world’s
largest passenger fleet operating international services. Aircraft in the Overseas
Division consist of Super VCios (16), VCios (11), Boeing yoy-436?, (11),
Boeing 707-3363 (11), and 13 Boeing 747s. The European Division contains
BAC One-Elevens (18), Trident Threes (26), Trident Twos (15), Trident Ones
(20), Vanguard g^is (1) and Vanguard g^gs (5). BEA Airtours have Boeing
707-4363 (7) and 3 Comet 4BS. British Airways is converting the Vanguard air¬

Regional Division’s fleet consists of BAC One-Elevens (4), Viscounts (35),
Trident Ones (4) and Sky liners (2). Helicopters in the helicopter division
include Sikorsky 6iNs (7), Bell Jet Rangers (1) and Bell212s (1). Orders include
five Concorde supersonic aircraft and two Boeing 747s for the Overseas Division
and six Lockheed TriStars for the European Division.
Although the public sector had a statutory monopoly up to 1961 there has been
a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number of passengers
and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services operated by
the independent operators. The independent companies compete with British
Airways over several domestic routes, including the busiest internal route in
Europe, from London to Glasgow. In 1972 they carried some 4 million
passengers on scheduled services. British Caledonian Airways, the ‘second
force’ airline, has a fleet of some 32 aircraft, used on chartered and scheduled
passenger and freight services, and carries about one million scheduled service
passengers a year. It was formed in 1970 by a merger of British United Air¬
ways and Caledonian Airways. The Government intends British Caledonian
to continue as the principal independent scheduled airline, and the CAx\ is
required in exercising its licensing functions to provide it with adequate
opportunities to build up its route networks. In April 1973 British Caledonian
began operating scheduled services from London to New York and Los
Angeles.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction. About 30 companies
carry out air-taxi operations.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services by British airlines rose by 18
per cent in 1972 to reach 5,650 million capacity-ton-miles. In 1955, 2-5
million passengers entered or left Britain by air, compared with 5-7 million
who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there were for the first time more air
than sea passengers, and by 1972 the figures were 28-1 million by air and 12
million by sea.
Freight traffic in 1972 amounted to some 649,000 tonnes, 22 per cent higher
than in 1971. This growth is reflected in the figures showing the proportion
of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air. In 1956, 1-7 per cent of imports and
2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were carried by air. In 1972 the corresponding
percentages were 14 for imports and 16 for exports, and the total value of
exports, imports and re-exports by air was £3,132 million. The chief export

items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle parts, and
electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large proportion
of the total value of re-exports.
The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is 1,828 while approximately 734 are owned by
clubs, groups and training schools. About 16,800 private pilots hold licences.
About 85 companies use corporate aircraft and 62 companies are members of
the Business Aircraft Users’ Association. There are some 9,000 glider pilots.
The Civil Aviation Authority has a general responsibility for licensing civil
aerodromes. It controls directly Aberdeen and eight small aerodromes in the
Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Aerodromes which are municipally or
privately owned and which are used for the public transport of passengers and/
or flying instruction are subject to licensing, inspection and regulation by the
authority, which is also responsible for navigation facilities at a number of
main municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority (BAA), an independent statutory body
operating on a commercial basis, took over in 1966 the ownership and manage¬
ment of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick), Prestwick in
Scotland and Stansted in Essex. In April 1971 it took over Edinburgh airport.
At these airports the Civil Aviation Authority is responsible for the provision of
navigation services; the Department of Trade and Industry directs the BAA to
take measures to control noise and vibration.
There are approximately 140 civil aerodromes in Britain; in addition, 50
Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under civil control include
9 directly controlled by the Civil Aviation Authority, 3 Channel
Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by the local island governments,
and 41 aerodromes licensed for public use, of which 22 are owned by munici¬
palities. Most of the remainder are owned privately. Two of the CAA s
aerodromes and 32 others are designated customs airports; limited customs
facilities are available at a further 36 aerodromes.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in recent years, and in 1972 Britain’s civil airports handled 40
million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft engaged on com¬
mercial transport operations was 670,000.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the mam
airports, and Heathrow is the busiest centre of international travel in the
world. The number of passengers handled at Heathrow, 14 miles (22 kilo¬
metres) west of central London, has increased from 5*4 million in i960 to
187 million in 1972 of whom most were international passengers. To accom¬
modate the rapid expansion expected in freight movements, £25 million has
been invested in a cargo terminal and associated developments, which came
into use in 1969. Facilities costing some 3^13 million have been provided for
handling Boeing 747 (jumbo jet) aircraft, which began to use the airport early
in 1970. Work is proceeding on the extension of London s Underground rail¬
way to Heathrow. The London Airport Cargo Electronic-data-processing
scheme (LACES) came into full operation at Heathrow in 1971, making Britain
the first country to control incoming cargo by computer. A £7 million computer
system to replace the European and Overseas Divisions’ computer systems is to
be installed by British Airways by 1974-75*The new system will be designed to
accommodate the forecast passenger traffic growth over the next ten years.

The airport at Gatwick, 28 miles (45 kilometres) south of London, was
opened in 1958 as the second airport for the London area. Built alongside the
main London to Brighton railway and the A23 road, Gatwick airport was the
first in the world to contain road, rail and air transport in one unit. In 1972 it
handled 5*4 million passengers.
It is planned to open the third London airport, to be built at Maplin, Essex,
in 1982. The Maplin project includes reclamation of land from the sea, con¬
struction of an airport and seaport, road and rail access routes and a new town.
A Maplin Development Authority is to be set up to reclaim land and to make it
available for the airport and seaport.
A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft. Already one of the best equipped freight airports in the world, a
new cargo terminal is being built there. The airport at Abbotsinch, owned and
run by the Glasgow Corporation, handled 1*9 million passengers in 1972. A
new main runway and passenger terminal are planned for Edinburgh. Luton
airport handled 3*1 million and Manchester airport handled 2-5 million
passengers in 1972; while Belfast handled over a million passengers. Birming¬
ham, Edinburgh, Prestwick, Liverpool and Newcastle each handled over
500,000.
THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides postal, public telecommunications,
data processing and Giro services. It was set up as a public authority under the
Post Office Act 1969, having previously been a government department.
The Post Office is headed by a chairman and board, appointed by and respon¬
sible to the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications. It has some 420,000
employees and over 24,000 post offices. The postal, telecommunications and
data processing services are now managed separately.
The Post Office has authority to borrow up to £3,800 million with provision
for an increase to £4,800 million, if necessary. At 31st March 1973 it had
borrowed £2,789 million. Over 90 per cent of total expenditure on fixed
assets is accounted for by telecommunications. The Post Office plans to invest
some £4,000 million in the period 1973-77.
Some 10,800 million items of correspondence and about 194 million parcels
are carried annually by the inland postal services. An increasing amount of
correspondence is sent by air, reaching 425 million items in 1972-73; 2-5
million parcels were sent by air in that year.
New highly mechanised sorting office buildings are being opened in Britain.
Letter segregating and facing machines have been installed at some 39 centres.
Postal address coding (postcode) is in operation for almost the whole country
—postcodes have been allocated to over 95 per cent of addresses. Some £50
million is being invested in an improved parcels service.
‘Datapost’, a package collection and delivery service for computer data and
important packages, introduced in 1970, provides over 10,000 services each
week.
The British Postal Consultancy Service offers professional advice on all
aspects of postal business to overseas administrators and to business organisa¬
tions. Subjects covered include management methods and systems, postal

BRITAIN 1974' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
circulation systems, containerisation, planning of buildings and mechanisation.
Work was done in 1972-73 for 12 overseas postal administrations.
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, a person can draw a pension or a family allowance, buy a licence for
his dog, a licence for his television receiving set, renew a car licence, buy
national insurance stamps, use the savings and investments facilities (see p.
222) and the money transmission services of the National Giro. In much of its
counter service the Post Office acts as agent for government departments and
local authorities.
Britain has one of the most up-to-date telegraph systems in the world and is
directly connected to most of the principal overseas telegraph offices. With the
exception of those offered by the small number of foreign telegraph companies
licensed to operate in Britain, all international telegraph services from Britain
are operated through the provincial and London offices of the Post Office
International Telegraph Service. Direct connection via the Centex system
between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, France, the
Federal Republic of Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Italy and Nor¬
way minimises delivery delay. In addition, the Post Office has been well to the
fore in the development of telegram retransmission techniques and is planning
to open a computer-based telegram retransmission centre in 1974.
The Telex Service combines the speed of the telephone with the accuracy of
the printed word. Calls may be made direct between the rapidly increasing
number of telex users in Britain (estimated at 46,000 by the end of 1973) and
also to well over 500,000 subscribers throughout the world. Britain is linked to
over 161 countries by telex. The British telex service is fully automatic.
Connection is made by direct dialling to any subscriber within the country,
and about 97 per cent of international calls are also directly dialled. These
include calls to virtually the whole of Europe. Calls to countries not available
through the automatic service are connected through the International Telex
Exchange in London. International telex traffic increased by 15-5 per cent in
1972-73; P°st Office planning for a system of about 100,000 United
Kingdom subscribers by 1980. A radioteleprinter service extends the use of
telex to ships at sea (see p. 368).
The demand for facilities enabling digital data for computers to be transmitted
over telephone and telegraph lines has greatly increased; to meet it the Post
Office has developed a range of datel services providing for transmission at
speeds of up to no bits per second over telegraph-type circuits and up to
2,400 bits per second over speech-type circuits. Speeds of 48,000 bits per
second can be accommodated by special arrangement. Most of the datel
facilities are available internationally and over telegraph or speech-type circuits.
In the year ended March 1973 the number of British Post Office datel terminals
amounted to some 24,450.
At the end of March 1973 there were 6,499 local telephone exchanges and
17-6 million telephones. During 1972-73, 0-9 million new lines were installed.
All London’s exchanges are now automatic. Trunk dialling by subscribers
(STD) began in Bristol in 1958; by March 1973 the facility had been extended
t° 4,359 exchanges, serving 96 per cent of subscribers, all of whom should
have STD by 1974.
Hull Corporation is the only municipality to exercise its option of operating

its own service under licence from the Post Office; this service is connected to
the Post Office trunk network.
The first operational electronic exchange in Europe was opened at Amber-
gate, Derbyshire, in 1966. There are now over 400 such exchanges in Britain.
Large electronic exchanges with capacities of up to 40,000 lines are due to come
into service in major cities by the mid-1970s. Mobile electronic exchanges
were introduced in May 1973.
Pulse code modulation systems are being used to increase the circuit capacity
of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. Over 2,300 should be
installed by the end of 1973. A new time-division electronic switching system
for interconnecting routes equipped with pulse code modulation systems has
been used experimentally. Research is proceeding into a new digital trans¬
mission and waveguide system to increase capacity.
International subscriber dialling operates from London and other major
cities to most of western Europe, the United States and Canada. Britain has
two automatic international telephone exchanges in use and a third under
construction. It is expected that by 1978 callers will be able to dial international
calls from 80 per cent of telephones, compared with 61 per cent in 1972.
Operator-connected calls are handled at London international exchanges,
which are connected to over 3,500 direct telephone circuits to European
countries. Direct links via transatlantic and Commonwealth cable networks,
communications satellites and high frequency radio provide service to over 50
countries outside Europe. Almost every country can be reached from the
international exchanges, via intermediate points where necessary.
A radio tower, 620 feet (189 metres) high, in London provides microwave
radio links for carrying long-distance telephone and television circuits. There
are over 100 Post Office communications masts and towers in use, including a
tower of 500 feet (152 metres) in Birmingham.
Several specialised services are available by telephone, including the ‘999’
emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as quickly
as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade services.
A public radiotelephone service operating in London and south Lancashire
enables users of vehicles fitted with suitable equipment to make or receive calls
to or from any telephone in the United Kingdom network. Recorded informa¬
tion services include: the speaking clock, weather forecasts, motoring informa¬
tion, recipes, ‘Test match’ cricket scores, Financial Times share index and
business news summary, and ‘Dial a Disc’. In London a recorded service
provides details in five languages of events taking place, and a similar service,
in English only, is provided in Edinburgh during the summer.
There are over 158,000 private circuit stations not connected with the public
exchange networks. These are associated with circuits rented for private use
for telephone conversations, teleprinter connections, photo-telegraphy, tele¬
vision, music, or for the transmission of signals which represent data for
computers or operate other devices.
There are some 42 submarine cable links between Britain and the rest of the
world, covering about 14,000 miles (22,800 kilometres). Cable systems using
transistors in place of thermionic valves have been developed by British manu¬
facturers in consultation with the Post Office Research Station and are used
in many new systems. A comprehensive Commonwealth telephone cable plan
was agreed upon in 1958 and carried out by Cable and Wireless Ltd. in

co-operation with the Post Office. The plan covered the construction of three
long-distance telephone cable systems: CANTAT 1 (2,100 nautical miles),
from Scotland to Canada, was opened in 1961; COMPAC (8,130 nautical
miles), connecting Canada, Hawaii, Fiji, New Zealand and Australia, opened
in 1963; and SEACOM (7,070 nautical miles), connecting Australia, New
Guinea, Guam, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, was completed in
stages from 1965 to 1967. The submarine cables are linked overland across
Canada and Australia by radio microwave systems. CANTAT 1 was the first
single-cable ocean telephone system to use the new lightweight cable and rigid
two-way repeaters, both developed by the Post Office.
Since CANTAT 1 was laid between Britain and Canada telephone calls
have risen substantially. CANTAT 2, which will enter service in 1974, will
double telephone links across the Atlantic, with its 1,840 circuits. It will cover
2,700 nautical miles between Cornwall and Nova Scotia.
The Goonhilly satellite communication earth station in Cornwall was brought
into operation in 1962, and took part in the first experiments in satellite
communications using the Telstar and Relay satellites. A second aerial was
introduced in 1968 and a third was brought into use in 1972. The three aerials
provide commercial telephone and television circuits via high-capacity, geo¬
stationary satellites positioned over the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. At the
end of 1972 Britain operated some 640 satellite telephone circuits to 30
countries. The satellites used in the global communications systems are pro¬
vided by the International Telecommunications Satellite Organisation (see
p. 407) of which Britain is the second largest shareholder.
In addition to the radio stations for overseas telecommunications, the Post
Office has n coast radio stations in the United Kingdom which provide
radiotelegraph and radiotelephone communications with ships at sea at ranges
of up to some 500 miles (805 kilometres) and 250 miles (402 kilometres)
respectively. There is also the long-distance radiotelegraph and radio¬
telephone station, Portishead Radio, which communicates with ships in all
parts of the world. Traffic handling capacity is being increased under a six-
year modernisation programme due for completion in 1974.
These coast stations play an important part in the services concerned with
safety of life at sea. They keep continuous watch on the international radio¬
telegraph and radiotelephone frequencies for distress calls from ships or
aircraft and take immediate action to obtain assistance for any vessel in distress.
During 1972-73 the stations handled 488 urgency and distress calls.
In addition to the services for safety of life at sea, the stations exchange
radiotelegrams with ships and connect radiotelephone calls between telephone
subscribers ashore and suitably equipped ships; they also broadcast naviga¬
tional warnings and weather bulletins.
The stations operate a free medical advice service whereby the master of a
ship of any nationality may obtain advice from appropriate medical authorities
on the treatment to be given in cases of sickness or injury aboard ship. During
1972-73, 563 medical cases were dealt with in this service.
Since the Post Office in 1957 set up an installation to process payroll, pensions
and statistical work, it has become one of the largest users of automatic data
processing equipment and techniques in Britain. Its computer organisation is
divided into two parts: the Post Office Data Processing Service for its own
‘Confravision’
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 369
internal services, and the National Data Processing Service for services to
business firms and other external users.
In addition to stock control and telephone billing, computer systems are
used for large-scale document and information retrieval systems, the Giro
system, scheduling of mail vans in London, the LACES import-handling
system at Heathrow airport (see p. 364), and control of revenue collection from
television licences. In its 13 regional computer centres the Post Office Data
Processing Service operates 26 computers and is processing over 150 projects.
Techniques and equipment employed by the staff of over 4,000, of whom some
700 are systems analysts and programmers, include optical and magnetic ink
character reader/sorters; direct keying of data on to discs and magnetic tapes;
and the direct recording of data from magnetic tapes to micro-film.
The world’s first purpose-built system of conferences by television, ‘Confra¬
vision’, was introduced by the Post Office in September 1971. Using Post
Office video circuits the service allows private communication between studios
in London, Birmingham, Bristol, Glasgow, and Manchester.
The Post Office is spending over £20 million a year on research and develop¬
ment, in collaboration with industry and the universities. A new £8 million
research centre is being built at Martlesham Heath, Suffolk, to replace
eventually the laboratories at Dollis Hill.
