Highland Games
Badminton
Basket Ball
Billiards and
Snooker
Bowls
Boxing
The Highland Games, traditional gatherings of local people in the Highlands
of Scotland, at which sports (including tossing the caber, putting the weight,
and throwing the hammer) and dancing and piping competitions take place,
are unique spectacles which attract large numbers of spectators from all over
the world. Among better known Highland Games are the Braemar Gathering
(traditionally attended by the Royal Family), the Argyllshire and Cowal
Gatherings and the meeting at Aboyne.
The origins of badminton are not clear, but the Badminton Association of
England—which together with the Scottish and Welsh Badminton Unions
today organise the sport in Great Britain—was formed in 1893 and the first
tournament was promoted five years later. By 1914 the game had spread to
many other Commonwealth countries and it is now played throughout the
world (the national bodies in Great Britain were among the founder members
of the International Badminton Federation).
Basket ball is played in Britain both indoors and outdoors, primarily by men
and boys. There are about 1,000 senior clubs and the game is played in many
schools. The Amateur Basket Ball Association, organises championships and
is affiliated to the Federation Internationale de Basket Ball Amateur.
Although references to billiards in England survive from the sixteenth
century, the character of the present game was acquired at the end of the
seventeenth century. The Billiards and Snooker Control Council is the game’s
controlling body (for professionals and amateurs) and holds the copyright of
the rules. In the early 1930s snooker (a shorter game offering more diverse
incidents) began to acquire popularity, often at the expense of professional
billiards, and today, although both games are played widely at amateur levels,
snooker forms the essence of the professional game.
Bowls has been played in Britain since the thirteenth century. Nowadays the
game is regulated, as far as the English Bowling Association (EBA, founded in
1903) is concerned, by the International Bowling Board (IBB). The Bowling
Associations of Ireland, Scotland and Wales also play to the IBB’s laws, but
there are other bowling associations in England—the English Bowling Federa¬
tion, the Crown Green Association and the English Women’s Bowling
Association—which are not under the IBB’s control. During the summer
bowls is played on bowling greens in the open; in winter it is played on indoor
greens, which are increasing in number. At one time regarded as a pastime for
the elderly, the game is now played by people of all ages. Over 2,640 bowling
clubs are affiliated to the EBA. International, inter-county matches and national
championship competitions of singles, pairs, triples and fours are played.
Boxing as a British sport probably originated in Saxon times. Its modern
form, which has been adopted in many overseas countries, dates from 1865
when the Marquess of Queensberry drew up a set of rules eliminating much of
the brutality that had characterised prize fighting, and making skill the basis
of the sport. Nowadays, many boys learn to box at school and in boys’ clubs,
and there are various amateur boxing competitions carried out according to
the rules of the Amateur Boxing Association, which controls all amateur
boxing, including schoolboy boxing, club and association boxing, and boxing
in the armed services.
Professional boxing is controlled by the British Boxing Board of Control,
452
Canoeing
Cricket
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
founded in 1929. The board’s strict medical regulations provide for an
examination of boxers before and after each contest, an extensive annual
medical examination and the appointment of inspectors, medical officers and
representatives of the Board to ensure that the regulations are observed and to
guard against over-matching and exploitation.
Championships at fixed weights have been the rule in boxing contests since
the presentation of the Championship Challenge Belts by the late Lord
Lonsdale in 1909. Amateur championships are decided at 11 weights: light
flyweight, flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight, lightweight, light welter¬
weight, welterweight, light middleweight, middleweight, light heavyweight
and heavyweight. In professional boxing there is no light flyweight category.
Canoeing, the world’s oldest type of boating, dates as a modern sport from the
mid-nineteenth century; a canoe club was founded in 1866, and in 1867 a canoe
regatta was held on the Thames. The International Canoe Federation was
formed in 1936; in Great Britain, the British Canoe Union (a member of the
federation and established in 1936) promotes canoeing in all its forms and
assists the interests of its members.
Cricket, sometimes called the English national game, has uncertain origins,
but it is known to have been played at Guildford Grammar School in 1550,
and after the Restoration (of 1660) it became fashionable with the nobility,
who competed with each other to sponsor matches for very large sums of
money. Among the many clubs founded in the eighteenth century was the
famous Hambledon Club in Hampshire, whose members supported the most
brilliant players of the day. Towards the end of the century the Marylebone
Cricket Club (MCC) was founded in London and reframed the ‘Laws of
Cricket’. It has since had considerable influence on the development of the
game in Britain. Its headquarters, Lord’s (named after Thomas Lord, who
rented the first headquarters), were opened in 1787, and moved to the present
site in 1814. Nowadays, cricket in Britain is governed by the Cricket Council,
made up of representatives of the MCC, the Test and County Cricket Board
(representing first-class cricket) and the National Cricket Association (rep¬
resenting club and junior cricket). The MCC retains its world-wide responsi¬
bility for the laws of cricket.
The game is played in schools and universities, and most towns and villages
(as well as industrial sports clubs) have teams which play at least one match a
week from late April to early September. In the London area a large number
of pitches are provided by local authorities to augment those leased or owned
by clubs. In the Midlands and the north of England there is a network of
League cricket, contested by teams of Saturday afternoon players reinforced
by professionals, often distinguished overseas players.
The focus of the season centres on a series of ‘Test matches’ played between
England and a touring team from overseas (or sometimes two teams). The
first of these matches was played in Melbourne between England and Australia
in 1877. Since then international tours have taken place regularly between
countries of Test status, which now number seven. The matches last 30 playing
hours spread over five days and arouse great popular interest.
In addition to the Test matches, a First-Class County Championship,
decided on a points system, is contested by 17 counties, each playing 20
three-day matches. The counties not deemed first-class and second elevens of
the first-class counties play in a Minor Counties Championship. The univer¬
sity teams of Oxford and Cambridge rank as first-class and play an annual
SPORT
453
Croquet
Cycling
Fencing
Field Sports
Hunting
match at Lord’s. The counties also compete in two sponsored knock-out
competitions and a sponsored Sunday League. All three consist of one-day
matches.
Cricket is also played by women and girls in Britain, the governing body
being the Women’s Cricket Association, founded in 1926.
Croquet was introduced into Britain in the middle of the nineteenth century
and has developed into a game played by people of all ages on the lawns of local
croquet clubs and private gardens. Some 80 clubs are registered with the
Croquet Association—formed in 1896—which promotes the sport in Britain
and maintains links with croquet associations in other countries.
In Britain the internationally recognised body for cycle racing is the British
Cycling Federation which has 700 affiliated clubs and provides third-party
insurance and a legal aid and touring service for its members. It controls
track and massed-start road racing in Britain, and is concerned with the
cycling events in the Olympic and Commonwealth Games and the annual
world championship. Time trials are controlled by the Road Time Trials
Council.
The principal organisation promoting touring by bicycle is the Cyclists’
Touring Club (CTC), the oldest touring club in the world, with a membership
of some 20,000. CTC representatives in all parts of Britain offer help to touring
cyclists; its 50 district associations arrange holiday and week-end tours and
competitions, rallies and rides of all kinds; and its travel department provides
touring itineraries for members both at home and overseas, and maintains a
full travel agency service. Other benefits include a touring magazine, a members’
handbook, legal aid and third-party insurance.
Fencing as a sport has made considerable progress throughout Britain during
the past 25 years. The Amateur Fencing Association (founded in 1902) has
over 600 clubs, and many classes are organised and financed by local authori¬
ties. Fencing is also practised in most universities and an increasing number of
schools. Under the auspices of the association, national championships and
international tournaments are held every year.
The most popular field sports—hunting, game shooting and fishing—have a
long history, and still play a considerable part in the life of the countryside.
The British Field Sports Society looks after their interests.
In Britain hunting means primarily fox hunting on horseback with a pack of
hounds; but it also includes stag hunting (in Devon and Somerset), hunting
the hare, either on foot with beagles or with harriers when the followers are
mounted, and otter hunting along river banks. Hunting depends not on right
but on the goodwill of small landowners and farmers, most of whom support
their local hunt by allowing it to ride over their property.
Fox hunting became a widespread activity in the English countryside some
200 years ago. Originally a sport mainly for the landed gentry and local farmers,
it has gradually widened its appeal, in spite of the fact that it is an expensive
pastime for those who ride to hounds. The sport is not without its critics, but
an ever-larger number of people, including many townsmen, take a keen interest
in it. Most hunts meet two or three times a week and an estimated 25,000 to
30,000 people ride to hounds weekly, many others following in cars, on bicycles
or on foot. The fox hunting season starts in early November and lasts until
454
Game Shooting
Fishing
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
April; it is preceded by cub hunting (the hunting of young foxes) when young
hounds are trained. At the end of the season most hunts organise steeplechases
(point-to-points) which attract large crowds. There are over 190 packs of
hounds in England and Wales, some 3 in Northern Ireland, and 11 in Scot¬
land. Hunts are financed mainly by the subscriptions of their members (£15 or
less to £50 or more), by ‘caps’ (contributions paid by non-subscribers), and by
the proceeds of such annual events as the point-to-points and the hunt ball.
Sometimes the Master of Fox-hounds, who is in charge of the hunt, bears a
proportion of the cost.
Game shooting as an organised country sport may be said to date from the
early part of the nineteenth century; nowadays, game consists mainly of
grouse, partridge, pheasant, snipe and woodcock. There is virtually no free
shooting in Britain. A certificate (for which a fee is payable) must be obtained
from the local police by anyone who possesses, purchases or acquires a shot
gun1; and it is necessary to have a licence to kill game. Nearly all game birds
are found on privately owned land, shot over either by the owner and his
friends or by syndicates which have leased the shooting rights. However, in
some parts of the more remote countryside, rough shooting may be enjoyed in
a less formal way. Much of the country’s wild-fowling is controlled by the
Wildfowlers’ Association of Great Britain and Ireland, through its numerous
clubs. The Game Conservancy, formed by landowners, farmers and others
interested in game conservation and research, collects information on a
national scale and studies factors controlling game population.
Grouse, partridge, pheasant and certain other birds are protected by law
during a ‘close season’ and allowed to breed in security, often under the care of
privately employed gamekeepers on numerous estates. Grouse shooting takes
place mostly in Scotland, northern England and north Wales; partridge and
pheasant shooting in nearly all regions of Great Britain, the former mainly over
farm land, and the latter in or near woodland; and wildfowling on the marshes
and fenlands of the coastal areas.
Deer stalking is mainly a sport of the Highlands of Scotland. The deer are
preserved in privately owned ‘deer forests’, covering 9,000 to over 30,000
acres (3,642 to 12,140 hectares), and are protected during close seasons.
Fishing is the most popular of the country sports, being within the reach of
everyone in some form or another (from the small boy with his hook and
line to the experienced fly-fisherman). There are some 3-8 million anglers
in Britain. The outstanding forms of the sport are salmon and trout fishing.
There are trout streams in most parts of the country, and in Scotland many
hundreds of lochs also provide good sport. Salmon fishing may be enjoyed in
many regions of Britain, but the best salmon rivers are in Scotland. In England
and Wales the most widely practised form of fishing is for coarse fish such as
pike, perch, carp, roach, dace, tench, chub and bream, and the National
Federation of Anglers (NFA) has over 382,000 members in over 200 clubs
or associations. Match angling—competitive fishing for coarse fish by weight—
is a feature of the many angling clubs affiliated to the NFA, particularly in the
Midlands and north of England. A national angling championship, composed
of teams of 12 anglers, is organised annually by the NFA, and the NFA enters
a team in the International Angling Competition. As a rule, freshwater fishing
1 A shot gun is defined in the Firearms Act 1968 as ‘a smooth-bore gun with a barrel
not less than 24 inches in length, not being an air-gun’. Shot guns are subject to control
under the Act.
SPORT
Golf
Gymnastics
Hockey
455
has to be paid for and local enquiries made about any permit or licence required.
Most coarse fishing is let to angling clubs; trout and salmon fishermen either
rent a stretch of river, join a club, stay at an hotel with its own fishing rights, or
pay for the right to fish by the day, week or month. The cost of salmon fishing
is often high. Coastal fishing and deep-sea fishing for shark and tunny are
growing in popularity and are free to all (except for salmon and sea trout
fishing, which is by licence only).
The National Anglers’ Council is a central consultative and co-ordinating
body, representative of the various national bodies concerned with angling.
Golf originated in Scotland, where for centuries it has borne the title of the
Royal and Ancient Game, but it did not become really well known in other
parts of Britain until towards the end of the nineteenth century. Since then,
however, it has gained steadily in popularity (particularly since the mid-
1950s); nowadays there are golf courses in the vicinity of many towns and
villages in all parts of Britain—some owned by local authorities, but the
majority owned by golf clubs. The headquarters of the Royal and Ancient
Golf Club is St. Andrews, Scotland.
The main event of the golfing year is the Open Golf Championship, first
played in i860; other important matches include the Walker Cup (for
amateurs) and the Ryder Cup (for professionals), both played between Britain
and the United States; the Amateur Championship; the World Amateur Team
Championship; and the Ladies Championship.
Gymnastics involving bodily exercises and disciplines were originally de¬
veloped as a sport in ancient Greece; nowadays in Britain the sport is a non-
seasonal activity for both men and women and is controlled nationally by the
British Amateur Gymnastics Association (affiliated to the Federation Inter¬
nationale de Gymnastique and the British Olympic Association). The asso¬
ciation’s activities include the promotion of international and national
programmes (including the national tournaments at the Royal Albert Hall,
London) and of proficiency award schemes for people of all ages.
Variants of hockey (as distinct from ice-hockey) have been played in Britain
for at least five centuries, and some, like hurling in Ireland and shinty in
Scotland, are still played extensively. Modern hockey, however, dates from
the formation (in 1886) of the Hockey Association of England. The Inter¬
national Hockey Rules Board controls the rules of the game. There are some
1,500 men’s hockey clubs throughout Britain with at least 40,000 male adult
players; some 600 boys’ schools also play the game. A county championship is
held annually in England; in Wales there is a cup competition; and in Scotland
there is a cup competition and six local league competitions. Regular amateur
international matches are also played. Men’s hockey is an Olympic sport, and
team arrangements are made by the Great Britain Hockey Board.
The controlling bodies of women’s hockey are: the All England Women’s
Hockey Association (founded 1895) to which are affiliated some 800 clubs and
2,200 schools, representing a membership of about 25,000 adults; the Irish
Ladies’ Hockey Union; the Scottish Women’s Hockey Association; and the
Welsh Women’s Hockey Association. The first international women’s hockey
match took place in 1896. Nowadays such a match is played annually at
Wembley Stadium (in addition to those played in other parts of the country)
and attracts over 60,000 spectators.
456
Judo
Lacrosse
Lawn Tennis
Motor Sports
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Judo, an Olympic sport originating in Japan, has a large and growing follow¬
ing in Britain and is governed by the British Judo Association, which is
affiliated to the International Judo Federation under the rules of which judo
competitions are conducted. There are some 600 clubs in the association,
which has coaching schemes for some 30,000 registered members.
Lacrosse, adapted from the game played by the Iroquois Indians of North
America, is played mainly by women—in girls schools, at lacrosse clubs, and
at universities. Women’s international and regional matches are played under
the auspices of the All England Women’s Lacrosse Association, the All Wales
Women’s Lacrosse Association and the Scottish Women’s Lacrosse Association.
The men’s game, controlled by the English Lacrosse Union, is played in ten
universities, several colleges of education and by clubs and schools, mainly in
the London, Manchester, Leeds, Sheffield and Nottingham areas. Matches
played include county matches, an annual fixture between the North of
England and the South, the English Club Championship, and international
matches between Australia, the United States, Canada and England.
The forerunner of modern lawn tennis (the game known as 7^ de paume) was
introduced into England from France in the fifteenth century and a ‘tennis
court’, built by Henry VIII, is still in use at Hampton Court. The modern
game,’first played in England in 1873, quickly became very popular; in 1877
the first championships were played. The Lawn Tennis Association, the
game’s controlling body in Britain, was founded in 1888. The international
governing body of the game (the International Lawn Tennis Federation, with
headquarters in London) was founded in 1913.
The number of tennis players has greatly increased during the present
century, particularly since the game has spread to practically every country in
the world. In Britain the game is played in almost all girls’ and in many boys’
secondary schools, on private courts, in parks and recreation grounds and at
several thousand tennis clubs.
The annual Wimbledon fortnight, held during the summer, is the main
event of the lawn tennis season in Britain, and, in fact, in the world. These
championships, for players of many nationalities, draw large crowds; the
grounds at the All England Club at Wimbledon can accommodate over 30,000
spectators, including 14,000 round the Centre Court where the finals are
played. Other tournaments which attract a good deal of attention are: the
British Hard Court Championships, the British Junior Championships, and the
County Championships. There are also national competitions for boys’ and
girls’ schools. The most important international events are the Davis Cup (for
men) and the Federation Cup competition (for women). Women players from
Britain and the United States also compete for the Wightman Cup.
Motor racing is one of the most popular spectator sports in Britain, more
racing and sports cars have been built in Britain than in any other country,
and British drivers (including women drivers) have an international reputation
second to none. The Royal Automobile Club (RAC) is the governing body of
motor sport in Great Britain, and the 800 motor clubs registered with it
organise each year 5,500 motor sporting events, 260 of which are race meetings
held on 18 different racing tracks licensed by the RAC. The RAC also issues
yearly 28,000 competition licences covering all events from hill climbs and
autocross to full international race meetings; and it organises the British Grand
SPORT
457
Mountaineering
Netball
Orienteering
Polo
Prix which counts towards the Formula One World Motor Racing Champion¬
ship. Kart racing also comes under the RAC’s jurisdiction.
In addition to motor car racing, there is motor cycle racing—the most
important contest of the year is for the Isle of Man Tourist Trophy—for
which the controlling body is the Auto-Cycle Union (founded in 1903 and
represented on the Federation Internationale de Motorcycliste), with over 600
affiliated clubs in Great Britain. Motor cycle speedway racing, introduced into
Britain in 1928, is governed by the Speedway Control Board.
The popularity of mountaineering has grown considerably in Britain. Clubs
in the British Mountaineering Council (BMC) and the Mountaineering
Council for Scotland, the representative bodies of the sport, number over 190,
ranging from national clubs, such as the Alpine Club (founded in 1857, the
oldest mountaineering club in the world) and the Scottish Mountaineering
Club, to small regional clubs with 20 to 30 members. A number of local
education authorities, and national bodies such as the Sports Council and the
Outward Bound Trust have established mountaineering training centres.
Training courses are run jointly by the Sports Councils, and BMC, the Youth
Hostels Association and other bodies, and many universities and schools have
mountaineering sections.
British mountaineers have taken a leading part in exploring and climbing
most of the great ranges of the world, for example, the first ascent of the
Matterhorn in 1865, of Everest in 1953, andof Kangchenjunga in 1955. Regular
expeditions are sent to many of the world’s mountain ranges.
Netball is a popular game for girls and women. The controlling body in
England is the All England Netball Association to which clubs, colleges and
schools are affiliated through county netball committees. The women’s armed
services and national youth, university and college organisations are also
affiliated. National tournaments for counties, clubs, colleges and schools and
international matches are organised each year; and inter-Commonwealth tours
are also arranged.
Orienteering involving competitive wayfinding across country (usually on
foot) was introduced into Britain on a national basis in the early 1960s,
although similar activities had been promoted in the past (the armed forces,
for instance, often use wayfinding in training programmes). Both men and
women participate and the sport is organised for team and individual competi¬
tions by the British Orienteering Federation. Several schools have taken up
the sport, combining outdoor exercise with practical geography.
Polo, of which the earliest records are Persian, was first played by the British
in India, and brought to England in 1869. The sport’s governing body is the
Hurlingham Polo Association, to which many overseas polo associations are
affiliated. Polo players are a very small section of the community, for the cost
of keeping polo ponies is high. However, many clubs now own trained ponies
for hire to members at moderate cost. Over 400 players receive handicaps
from the association, but many less expert players take part in club games.
Public interest in polo has increased and spectators attend inter-club tourna¬
ments and matches between high-handicap teams with players from several
countries, including other Commonwealth countries, the United States and
Argentina.

Racing
Horse-racing
Greyhound Racing
Betting on
Racing
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Racing is a term which, in Britain, is taken to mean, first and foremost,
horse-racing. Other forms of racing include greyhound racing, coursing (a
form of hunting with greyhounds), pony racing, trotting races and pigeon
flying.
Horse-racing has been known in England since Tudor times and even earlier.
The Jockey Club (originally formed about 1750) controls all horse-racing in
Britain and its rules are the basis of universal turf procedure.
Flat racing is carried on from late March till the beginning of November
and steeplechasing and hurdle racing from August to June. The classic flat
races are: the Two Thousand Guineas for colts and fillies, and the One
Thousand Guineas for fillies only, both run at Newmarket; the Derby for
colts and fillies and the Oaks for fillies only, both run at Epsom; and the St.
Leger, for colts and fillies, run at Doncaster. The Derby is the outstanding
event in the racing calendar; it takes place annually in early June and is one
of the most colourful and exciting events of the sporting year. The most
fashionable race-meeting of the season is held at Ascot in Berkshire, in mid-
June, and is known as ‘Royal Ascot’, being traditionally attended by the
Sovereign.
The most important steeplechase and hurdle race meeting is the National
Hunt Festival Meeting at Cheltenham in March. The best-known single
steeplechase is the Grand National at Aintree, near Liverpool, run annually
since 1839.
In England and Wales there are 57 racecourses (which must be licensed by
The Jockey Club) and Scotland has six racecourses. Over 950 days’ racing
are held each year. There are some 10,000 horses in training in Great
Britain.
The racing of greyhounds after a mechanical hare started in Britain in 1926,
when the first modern greyhound track was opened at Belle Vue, Manchester.
There are now about 114 licensed tracks in operation, nearly all of them near
large towns, and meetings are held two or three times a week. The licensing
authorities for greyhound racing tracks are the county and county borough
councils. Some 8 million people a year watch greyhound racing, the rules
of which are drawn up by the National Greyhound Racing Club. The 46
greyhound racecourses which accept the rules of the club are the largest in
the country and account for approximately 93 per cent of the total attendance
and totalisator turnover.
Greyhound racing can be conducted only at a licensed greyhound racecourse
and only on 130 racing days in a licensing year (1st July-30th June). There
are some 10,000 greyhounds in training under the National Greyhound Racing
Club Rules.
Betting on racing is allowed for people of at least 18 years of age, subject to a
government betting duty (see p. 217)- Bookmakers (who must hold personal
permits) provide betting facilities both on and off racecourses and greyhound
tracks (bets laid off course in Great Britain comprise about 86 per cent of the
betting turnover, mainly through some 14,800 licensed betting offices). For
horse-racing, the Horserace Totalisator Board (HTB), a statutory body, runs
totalisator betting (a form of pool betting), both on and off the courses, for
greyhound racing there is no statutory body, but some 70 tracks are allowed to
run their own totalisators under strict control by local authorities. Book¬
makers and the HTB have to contribute a ‘betting levy’ to the Horserace
Betting Levy Board which promotes the advancement of veterinary science
Riding
Rowing
sport 459
and education and the improvement of breeds of horses (including the work of
the National Stud at Newmarket) and horse-racing in general.
The British Equestrian Federation, the authority responsible for equestrian
activities (other than racing) in Great Britain, co-ordinates the work of the
British Horse Society and the British Show Jumping Association (see below),
and runs the National Equestrian Centre at Stoneleigh, Warwickshire.
The British Horse Society is responsible for promoting the interests of horse
and pony breeding, furthering the art of riding, and encouraging horse-
mastership and the welfare of horses and ponies. It provides tests, lectures,
publications, a film library, courses and examinations, and employs a national
instructor who, together with riding schools approved by the society, helps to
promote horsemastership throughout the country. With some 21,000 members,
the society is also the parent body of the Pony Club and the Riding Club
Movement. The Pony Club (39,500 members) runs its own national champion¬
ships, arranges conferences, instructors’ courses and efficiency tests, and pub¬
lishes information on riding techniques and horse management. The Riding
Clubs (about 26,000 members) also hold national championships each year and
the Riding Club Horseshoe Long Distance Ride—a test of stamina for horses
and riders, held annually in different parts of Britain.
Under the auspices of the society, horse trials are held throughout Britain
during the spring and summer. The three-day events held each year—in April
at Badminton, Gloucestershire, in May at Tidworth, Hampshire, and in
September at Burghley House, Lincolnshire—are among the outstanding
equestrian events of the year. These trials include dressage, cross-country
riding and showjumping; some 60 one-day and two-day horse trials on similar
lines are held annually.
Affiliated dressage competitions are held throughout the year, many of them
as qualifying rounds for championships held at the Royal International Horse
Show and the Horse of the Year Show (see below) and for dressage champion¬
ships at the National Equestrian Centre.
Showjumping is promoted by the British Show Jumping Association, which
is responsible for drawing up the rules for the judging of jumping competitions
and prescribing the general standards and height of obstacles for show
jumping. It encourages showjumping events and keeps a register of horses and
ponies taking part at affiliated shows. The association seeks to improve the
standard of jumping and to provide for the representation of Great Britain in
international competitions. More than 800 shows are affiliated each year to the
association, which has a membership of over 9,000. The two major show
jumping events each year are the Royal International Horse Show and the
Horse of the Year Show.
Rowing is enjoyed by participants from all sections of the community and
attracts considerable spectator interest. The art of oarsmanship is taught in
many schools, universities and rowing clubs (including women’s clubs)
throughout Britain, where the governing bodies of the sport are the Amateur
Rowing Association and the Scottish Amateur Rowing Association and the
Ulster Branch of the Irish Amateur Rowing Union. Since the late 1940s, the
number of rowing clubs has doubled. The first rowing course in Britain built to
Olympic 2,000-metre standards has been opened at the National Water Sports
Centre in Nottingham.
The University Boat Race between eight-oared crews from Oxford and
Cambridge originated in 1829 an^ has been rowed on the Thames almost every

Sailing
Shooting
(Target)
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
spring since 1836. The Head of the River Race in March (also on the Thames)
is the largest assembly of racing craft in the world—more than 325 eights row in
procession. At Henley Regatta in Oxfordshire (founded in 1839) crews from
all over the world compete each July in various kinds of races over a straight
course of 1 mile 550 yards (about 2-1 kilometres). Many other riverside resorts
arrange summer regattas. The oldest annual event in the English racing
calendar is Doggett’s Coat and Badge, founded in 1716 and organised since
by the Worshipful Company of Fishmongers; originally for professional water¬
men and limited to six entrants, the race (along the Thames in London) is now
open to amateurs (who must still be apprentice watermen).
Rugby football is played according to two different sets of rules. Rugby Union
football (‘rugger’—in which there are 15 players in a team) is played through¬
out Britain under the auspices of English, Welsh, Scottish and Irish rugby
football unions.
International matches between England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, and
France are played regularly at the leading rugby football grounds of each
country, including Twickenham, London—the headquarters of the Rugby
Football Union (England)—and there are tours by international teams. Other
important rugby matches are the county championship competitions, the
annual match between the universities of Oxford and Cambridge, the Hospi¬
tals’ Cup Final, and the Inter-Services tournament. Membership of the
different Rugby Unions is confined to amateur clubs of which there are over
2,500 in membership, with over 2,000 schools.
Rugby League football—a 13-a-side game for professionals as well as
amateurs—is played mostly in the north of England. The game’s governing
body, the Rugby Football League (instituted in 1895) has its headquarters
at Leeds and regularly sends touring teams to Australia and New Zealand.
Annual international games, professional and amateur, are played against
France. The major match of the season—the Rugby League Challenge Cup
Final—attracts crowds of 100,000 at Wembley Stadium.
Sailing has always been popular on Britain’s inland and coastal waters but the
sport, and in particular small boat sailing, has recently widened its appeal. The
Royal Yachting Association (RYA), the national authority, has over 1,500 clubs
and 36,000 personal members. The RYA has many recognised schools giving
courses for novices, a National Sailing Centre where instructors are coached
and tested, and is responsible for the selection of Great Britain’s Olympic
team. One of the world’s main regattas takes place from Cowes in the Isle of
Wight annually during the first week of August. Other major events are held
at such sailing centres as Poole, Lowestoft, Harwich, Burnham-on-Crouch,
Plymouth, Falmouth and the Clyde. Racing is subject to the rules of the
International Yacht Racing Union, founded in 1907.
The Joint Shooting Committee for Great Britain, founded in 1955, represents
its member associations—the National Rifle Association (NRA), the National
Small-Bore Rifle Association (NSRA) and the Clay Pigeon Shooting Associa¬
tion (CPSA)—in the International Shooting Union and the British Olympic
Association. The committee sponsors all entries to international competitions.
Full-bore (7-62 mm and -303 in.) rifle and pistol (high power) shooting is
organised by the NRA, founded in i860. Some 80 county rifle associations, 100
schools and more than 500 rifle clubs are affiliated to the NRA. The annual
Imperial Meeting at Bisley Camp, Surrey—attended by some 2,000 competi-
SPORT
Skating
Skiing
Squash Rackets
Swimming
461
tors from Britain and other Commonwealth countries, including cadets from
schools—comprises (for individuals and teams) competitions for members of
the armed services and for schools, and target rifle competitions at county,
national and international level, concluding with the Queen’s Prize, which
attracts about 1,000 entries. The NRA also organises postal matches for British
and overseas teams, and sends teams to other Commonwealth countries.
Small-bore (-22 in.) rifle and pistol shooting—carried out either on indoor
ranges of 15 to 25 yards (14-23 m) in length or on open ranges up to 200 yards
(183 m)—and air rifle and pistol shooting (-177 in.) at 6 yards and 10 metres
(both indoors and outside) are also widely practised in Britain. Some 3,500
clubs are affiliated to the NSRA, which arranges inter-club and inter-county
competitions for teams and individuals. Clubs also compete in county and local
groups. The NSRA organises a National Bisley Meeting (usually attended by
more than 2,000 competitors), a Scottish meeting (some 600 competitors),
and the British Pistol Championships (some 600 competitors) at Bisley.
International small-bore rifle and pistol matches are held with teams from
overseas. The NSRA provides coaching and advisory services.
Some 400 clay pigeon shooting clubs are situated in all parts of Great Britain;
the sport is governed by the CPSA which represents Great Britain in major
international events.
The world’s first skating club was formed in Edinburgh in 1742 and the first
mechanically refrigerated ice rink was built in London in 1876. There are
now 31 artificial ice rinks in Britain, and where facilities exist many local
authorities provide skating tuition for school children. Over 60 ice clubs are
affiliated to the National Skating Association of Great Britain (which also
promotes roller skating), formed in 1879—one of the associations which in
1892 established the International Skating Union to supervise and standardise
ice figure, ice speed and (later) ice dance skating regulations.
When there is sufficient snow, skiing takes place in several parts of Britain.
The governing body of the sport is the National Ski Federation of Great
Britain; there are also regional ski associations in Scotland, Wales, Northern
Ireland and England. There are now over 60 artificial ski-slopes in Britain.
Winter sports centres have been established in Aviemore, Glencoe and Glen-
shee (all in Scotland) with ski-lifts and ski schools staffed by professional
instructors. There are half a million skiers in Great Britain and 162 ski clubs.
Squash rackets is thought to have originated at Harrow School in the 1850s;
the Squash Rackets Association, formed in 1929 to promote and organise the
game, was a founder member of the International Squash Rackets Federation.
A European Squash Rackets Federation was formed in 1973 on the initiative
of the SRA. The game, which is both amateur and professional, is played
mainly by men and boys (it is very popular in many boys’ schools and uni¬
versities), although an increasing number of participants are women. There are
national inter-county and a number of major area amateur and open cham¬
pionships.
Many children in Britain learn to swim at school, or during holidays at the
seaside, and swimming as a summer pastime is enjoyed by millions of people.
The existence of indoor swimming baths (mainly provided by local authorities)
makes all-the-year swimming possible, and instruction and coaching is pro¬
vided in some places by qualified teachers who hold certificates for elementary
462
Underwater
Swimming
Table Tennis
Tenpin Bowling
Volleyball
Water Skiing
Weightlifting
Wrestling
BRITAIN 1974: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
or advanced teaching awarded by the Amateur Swimming Association (ASA).
The ASA’s objects are to promote the teaching and practice of swimming,
diving and water polo and to stimulate public opinion in favour of providing
proper accommodation and facilities for them; and to draw up and enforce
uniform laws for the regulation of amateur swimming, diving and water polo
and synchronised swimming (a form of water ballet) championships and
competitions in England.
Underwater swimming (sub aqua), one of the fastest growing sports in Britain,
is governed nationally by the British Sub Aqua Club, which promotes under¬
water exploration, science and sport. Formed in 1953, the club has become
the largest in the world, with some 20,000 active members and 600 branches
in Britain and overseas.
Table tennis had its origins in Britain in the late nineteenth century and was
then often referred to as ‘ping pong’ (the name is derived from the sound of the
ball hitting the bat). In 1902 the Ping Pong Association was formed to organise
championships, and in 1927 it was reconstituted as the English Table Tennis
Association—the body which today controls the game.
Types of bowling are thought to have been played in ancient Egypt and have
been known in Europe for over 700 years. Tenpin bowling was re-introduced
in its present form from North America in i960 and rapidly became a popular
sport in Great Britain where the controlling body is the British Tenpin Bowl¬
ing Association, founded in 1961.
Volleyball, introduced into Europe from the United States, is growing in
popularity in England and Scotland where it is promoted by the English
Volleyball Association and the Scottish Volleyball Association. There are some
214 clubs affiliated to the English Association, and both associations are
members of the British Olympic Association.
The popularity of water skiing in Britain, both during the summer and at
suitable times in the winter, is increasing. The British Water Ski Federation,
formed in 1951, represents over 5,000 water skiers, several of whom have won
world and European titles. Over 100 clubs are affiliated to the federation.
Modern weightlifting with bar-bells and dumb-bells became popular towards
the end of the nineteenth century; the first championships open to the world
were held in London in 1891. The sport is regulated on a world-wide scale by
the International Weightlifting Federation, formed in 1920, and in Britain
by the British Amateur Weightlifters’ Association.
Wrestling is one of the oldest sports in the world. The style most commonly
used in Britain is the ‘free’ style, which evolved from the Catch-as-Catch-Can
or Lancashire style, but Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling is still
practised in the north of England and in Scotland, and Cornish style wrestling
(in which the contestants wear rough canvas jackets by which all holds must
be taken) takes place in Cornwall. Wrestling in the free and Graeco-Roman
styles features at the Olympic Games; in the Commonwealth Games only
free style is wrestled. Amateur wrestling in Britain is governed by the British
Amateur Wrestling Association, which is affiliated to the International
Amateur Wrestling Federation.

CURRENCY
The unit of currency is the pound sterling divided into 100 new pence (p). There
are six denominations: 50p; lOp; 5p; 2p; Ip; and ip.

publicising of the changeover to the international system of units for weights
and measures throughout the economy and educational system, mainly by 1975.

Thermometrical
Table
To convert “Fahrenheit into “Centigrade: subtract 32, then multiply by f;
“Centigrade into “Fahrenheit: multiply by f, then add 32.
0° Centigrade = 32° Fahrenheit.
100° Centigrade — 212° Fahrenheit.
Bibliography
This bibliography is in no sense comprehensive: it is only intended to be a guide to
further reading on the subjects covered in this handbook.
Readers are asked to note that in Britain the Central Office of Information refer¬
ence documents marked with an asterisk may be obtained, on payment of a small
charge, from the Central Office of Information, Reference Division Distribution
Unit, Hercules Road, Westminster Bridge Road, London SEi 7DU; and overseas
they may be obtained from British Information Offices.
Certain reference pamphlets produced by the Central Office of Information can
be purchased from Her Majesty's Stationery Office and its agents overseas. These
pamphlets are listed here with their respective prices {postage extra).
Acts of Parliament referred to in the text can be obtained at varying prices from
H.M. Stationery Office and its agents overseas.
International Standard Book Numbers {ISBN) should be quoted when ordering
publications. So that readers will be supplied with the latest edition no ISBNs are
given for annual publications.
OP means the book is out of print.

Most of the organisations concerned with sport publish year books covering results and
records of the previous season and future prospects; many weekly or monthly periodicals on
sport are also published. In addition some newspapers issue annual surveys of sport.
Index
Bold type in a sequence of figures indicates main references.
As the main purpose of this book is to inform readers overseas about Britain, organisa¬
tions and societies are generally indexed under their subject matter rather than under
Association of, British, National, Royal, etc. (that is, Accidents, Royal Society for the
Prevention of; Archives, National Register of). In cases where the first word is not
separable, however (for example, Royal Air Force, Royal Society), entries will be found
appropriately.
Items are indexed under England, Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales only where
they are matters peculiar to these countries; otherwise they are indexed under the
relevant subject headings.
